Siddur: Siddur - ftch đvr
sđvr - Introduction

v״h

The Online Siddur:

Vintage Wine in a Virtual Vessel

Guided by an inborn spiritual instinct, Jews from earliest times have given voice to the yearning that has stirred their souls by turning to G-d in prayer. Indeed, our forefathers, Avraham, Yitzchak and Yaakov, are each credited with instituting one of our three daily prayer services over three thousand years ago.1*

Afterwards, their individual strivings to connect to G-d were formalized in a Scriptural commandment to pray.2* Nevertheless, the very manner in which the Torah communicates this commandment pinpoints its essence. The Torah does not explicitly command us to pray. Instead, it gives the command “to serve HaShem with all your heart.”3* Our Sages ask:4* “What is meant by avodah shebalev, ‘the service of the heart’?” and they answer, “This is prayer.” They thus taught us what prayer is. It is not merely a recitation of words or an opportunity to make requests of G-d. It is the “service of the heart,” which, as chassidic tradition explains, means “in one’s heart and with one’s heart.”5*

Such service is a revered part of our tradition. As the Sages of the Mishnah relate, “the devout men of old used to pause for an hour before they began to pray.”6* During that time they reflected on the greatness of the Creator Whom they were about to address.

The concept of meditative prayer is, however, not reserved for such spiritual giants alone. On the contrary, the very structure of the prayer service was instituted to prompt such a process on the part of all Jews. With that intent in mind, our Sages framed the twice-daily Reading of the Shema with blessings,7* whose recitation is intended to help the worshiper attain an appropriate state of mind and heart. In due course they introduced further additions, such as the Verses of Praise8* that precede the above blessings.

In this manner, Jews have prayed for thousands of years. With time, however, despite those helpful preparatory rungs, fresh and focused praying sometimes grew stale, and could even lapse into rapid reading by rote. Our people’s spiritual leaders labored to counter such an approach saying, “Praying without proper intent is like a body without a soul.”9* Thus it is natural that as the Baal Shem Tov strove to rejuvenate the Jewish world, among the thrusts which he popularized was a renewed emphasis on davening with focused concentration10* and intense passion.11*

The Sages of the Kabbalah12* employ the metaphor of a bird’s flight to explain the process through which a mortal’s Divine service breaks free of worldliness and ascends aloft. To fly, a bird needs two wings. Similarly, our Divine service rises upward through two catalysts: an ardent love and an earnest awe of G-d.

One day, the Baal Shem Tov arrived at the door of a shul in a faraway town, and when he opened it he exclaimed: “This shul is filled with prayers and Torah study!” The disciples who accompanied him were most impressed – until he corrected them: “This shul is full of prayers and Torah study because over the years they were mouthed mechanically, without the wings of love and awe that should have borne them up and away….”

With Mind and Heart

The Baal Shem Tov established the ideal fervent avodas hatefillah as a cornerstone of the chassidic movement that he founded. The Alter Rebbe not only taught and wrote extensively about the Baal Shem Tov’s concept of prayer, but further developed it. He underscored that for the passion and intensity of prayer to be authentic, it must result from a mature appreciation of G-d’s greatness and majesty. The understanding that follows is to be infused into one’s prayers through disciplined meditation both before and during the course of davening. This activity in the mind will then hopefully trickle down into the heart and there give birth to a spiritual emotion, such as a love of G-d or an awe of G-d. Only in this manner, contends the Alter Rebbe, can the objective of praying – avodas halev, serving G-d “in one’s heart and with one’s heart” – be genuine, impactful and enduring.13* Indeed, when the process of davening is not generated by an intellectual and contemplative approach but is merely instinctive, one’s inspirational moments of prayer may well be capricious and transitory, depending on the spirit of the moment.

The degree of importance that the Alter Rebbe placed on devout concentration from the depths of the mind and heart during prayer is apparent from the serious anxiety he expressed in Tanya – Iggeres HaKodesh, Epistle One – about “anyone who has the ability and the time to worship at length and to meditate while at prayer, but is indolent [in doing so]….” Accordingly, in order to equip the worshiper with the necessary tools, much of the vast body of chassidic literature is devoted to explaining how the concept of G-d’s majestic awesomeness is actually embedded within the deeper meanings of our daily prayers. It is a wakeful knowledge of these chassidic concepts that enables a chassid to fully engage in a genuine “service of the heart.”

Enshrined in Tradition

This distinctive style of davening, in which the measured reading of the prayers is interspersed and enriched by deliberate meditation on related concepts, has long served as a hallmark of the Chabad chassid. The legendary Chabad chassidim of former times transmitted that tradition to succeeding generations, whether by personal example or via inspirational words exchanged in the informal setting of chassidic farbrengens. The previous Lubavitcher Rebbe’s Likkutei Dibburim is replete with descriptions of vintage chassidim who would spend hour after hour lost in their prayers. In fact, so vital is a chassidisher davening to the life-blood of a chassid, that a Chabad shul was traditionally designed with a chabadnitzeh – an adjoining alcove or small room, in which a pensive chassid could find a quiet corner and daven to his heart’s content, undisturbed.

A well-loved exemplar of this classic mode of davening, who passed away only two decades ago, was a mashpia of stature called Reb Avrohom Drizin, better known from the name of his hometown as Reb Avrohom Mayorer:

His preparations began well before davening. Like the chassidim of yore described in the Talmud, he would spend an hour or more pondering over his upcoming tefillos as lit up by the teachings of Chassidus, whether in a complex classical maamar or in a discourse recently delivered by the Rebbe. This meditative focus continued during his davening. At certain points it was clear that he had stopped for quite a time for structured meditation on the chassidic teachings that would continue to inspire him. A soft niggun would escape from under his tallis, a niggun that expressed spiritual yearning. Soon the niggun and the words of his davening merged seamlessly into an ecstatic harmony. And so, sentence after sentence, page after page, a Jewish soul voiced its nostalgia for its Creator.

He would sit and daven like this for hours on end, his tallis fully covering his face, feet slightly crossed, one hand gently stroking his beard, and his body swaying in silent emotion.14*

A Problem and a Solution

In recent times, “service of the heart” in this ideal mode has become less than universal, perhaps because of a humble awareness of the distance between the glowing ideal and one’s daily reality. In the pained words of the Rebbe Rayatz:15* “The first stage in a person’s spiritual decline (Heaven forbid) is a lack of effort when serving G-d in prayer. Everything becomes parched and cold. Even the routine performance of mitzvos16* becomes burdensome. One hurries [through their observance] and loses a taste for Torah study. The very atmosphere becomes more materially oriented. And it goes without saying that a person in such a state cannot positively influence others at all.”17*

However, a chassidisher davening is not a choice between extremes, in which one either soars to the loftiest spiritual heights or plummets to praying by rote. A legitimate and viable alternative is proposed in the introduction to Siddur MaHarid, authored by Rabbi Yitzchok DovBer of Liadi, a grandson of the Tzemach Tzedek. There, his sons write that their grandfather, Rabbi Chaim Shneur Zalman, related that his father, the Tzemach Tzedek, once said: “It would be most appropriate to compose a short commentary [of Chabad Chassidus] on the Siddur that would be accessible to all.” The intent of that commentary was specifically to enable a person to integrate concepts and meditations of Chabad Chassidus into his prayers.

With like intent, the eminent Reb Hillel of Paritch once said that there are three modes of davening. On the one hand, one can daven while seeking to understand the straightforward peirush hamilos,18* “the plain meaning of the words.” On the other hand, one can daven in the classic mode with full avodas halev, profound and prolonged meditation on a chassidic concept or theme, hopefully having one’s emotions impacted commensurately. Between those two options, one can daven with chassidishe peirush hamilos, thinking briefly about the deeper chassidic meaning of the words uttered in prayer.

Accordingly, the project presented here presents a choice selection of chassidishe peirush hamilos that are of inestimable value in upgrading one’s davening.

Many maamarim include at least one or two commentaries on some specific words or phrases of our prayers. Because these commentaries are often mentioned in the context of an entire chassidic discourse, one can easily fail to appreciate them as subjects that can be incorporated into his thinking while davening with chassidishe peirush hamilos. Experience has shown that those who incorporate these thoughts in their davening, even if they contemplate them only briefly, find their davening immeasurably enriched, springing to life as a vibrant event. While this might not completely fulfill the desire of the Rebbeim that chassidim should daven with full-blown avodas halev, it remains a legitimate form of davening with kavanah and chassidic meditation.

At the most basic level, a proper davening consists of clearly articulating every word and being mindful of what is being said. In the words of the Rebbe Rayatz:19* “Tefillah consists of using the spoken word to praise G-d and acknowledge His past kindnesses, as well as supplicating Him that in His infinite mercy He provide the individual with that which he lacks.... When one is in prayer before the King of all kings, the Holy One, blessed be He, no matter whether he is praising and thanking Him in prayer, or whether he is requesting His mercy, one’s prayer must be ordered, with every word enunciated deliberately and precisely. Moreover, one must not only hear his own words physically: his mind and heart must also ‘hear’ and understand the words of prayer that he is uttering, [for] the primary aspect of avodas hatefillah is that one should meditate on a G-dly concept until it arouses within him a love and awe of G-d.”

The value of a collection of chassidic peirush hamilos with which to invigorate one’s davening can also be glimpsed in the Mitteler Rebbe’s Introduction to the Alter Rebbe’s Siddur Im Dach,20* in which many passages of prayer are surrounded by maamarim on related themes that the Alter Rebbe delivered on various occasions. There the Mitteler Rebbe writes: “I have therefore felt impelled to urge, for the true benefit [of the chassidim], that they habituate themselves [to daven] with such peirush hamilos so that their hearts and mouths will be focused together on their Father in Heaven…, and the [resultant] G-dly light will illuminate their souls.”

Over the years, a number of other similar works have appeared, such as the Siddur MaHarid mentioned above and, in more recent times, the comprehensive anthology entitled Or HaTefillah. However, these works often pose an insurmountable challenge for those whose primary language is English or for those whose background in the study of the chassidic sources is not extensive. It is to such readers that the present project seeks to present a taste of the wealth of Chassidus on tefillah. The material is presented in adapted form in order to make it more readily accessible to the English reader, but in these cases, too, its content remains faithful to the original.

At the same time, this work is not intended to be used as a textbook for the study of Chassidus. Rather, it is intended for those who already possess some background in that field. The reader may even have encountered some of these teachings and concepts in the course of his studies, but seeks a way to incorporate them in his davening. It is suggested that he progress on this chassidic prayer-journey slowly and deliberately, one mile at a time, adding new peirushim to his davening only after he has become accustomed to regularly contemplating the previous peirushim.

The structure of the site makes this possible. Without the space limitations that would accompany a printed text, a wealth of peirushim have been made available. Moreover, the website enables the user to hyperlink from a brief citation to the original Hebrew text of the parent maamar if he so desires.

The current work grew out of a twice-weekly chavrusa that has continued over two years between myself and my dear friend and supporter Reb Yaakov Cohen, that focused primarily on studying peirush hamilos according to Chassidus. It was during that period, following a providential meeting with Rabbi Eliyahu Touger, that I had the zechus of conceiving this project and later guiding it through to its completion. Most of the material was researched, collected and translated by Rabbi Touger and edited by Rabbi Sholom Ber Wineberg.

I am grateful to my chavrusa, Reb Yaakov Cohen, for being the catalyst for much of the learning we do together and for enthusiastically agreeing to underwrite the cost of this project. This endeavor is not only an expression of his generosity but also of his life’s passionate pursuit of the knowledge of Chassidus and chassidishe davening. May he be rewarded from Above with fervent chassidishe tefillos for many years to come.

Rabbi Shmuel Kaplan

Siddur: Morning Blessings - älëf-beit
vrcht hshchr - Aleph Bet
älëf-beit: b v ǥ đ h v z ch t y k ch ch l m m n n s p f f ts ts q r sh s t t hännəqüdot: qamäts, pätach, tseirëh, sëgol, shəva, cholam, chirïq, qübots, shurüq, chätaf qamäts, chätaf pätach, chätaf sëgol
älëf-beit: b v ǥ đ h v z ch t y k ch ch l m m n n s p f f ts ts q r sh s t t

The letters of the Torah and of prayer are the letters of G-d's speech. Through these letters, the souls of the Jewish people cling to G-d, bonding with His very Essence. In a person’s inner spiritual makeup, the letters are rooted in the deepest reaches of his soul.1*2*bch)," is interpreted as referring to the 223*alef-beis, 4*Maamarei Admur HaRayatz).i*

The nekudos, vocalization signs,have their source in the highest levels of holiness. The Pardes5*explains that the vocalization signs that we use have been passed down in an uninterrupted tradition from Ezra the Scribe, who in turn received them in an uninterrupted tradition from Moshe, who received them at Sinai. As explained in that text and in the Tikkunei Zohar,6*the ten vocalization signs reflect the Ten Sefiros.

Developing that concept, the letters and the nekudos can be compared to the body and the soul, i.e., the letters parallel the body and the vocalization signs, the soul. Just as a body without a soul is lifeless, the letters cannot be pronounced without the vocalization signs.7*

Among the corollaries to this concept: The Torah consists only of letters. The Jews add the vocalization signs. This reflects a Jew's fundamental spiritual power: that he has the potential to give life to the letters of the Torah.

This concept also affects the approach to a child's education: First, a child should be taught the letters of the Torah, and then the letters as they are combined with their vocalization signs.

It is true that, as the Rebbe Rayatz taught,8*kamatz alef aw that a young child learns is connected with the kamatz alef aw of the word Anochi which begins the Ten Commandments and thus includes the entire Torah. Nevertheless, the alef alone without the kamatz connects a Jew to G-d as He is Ein Sof, utterly unlimited and indefinable. When a child is taught the alef without vocalization, he connects to this unbounded dimension of G-dliness and this becomes the source of all his subsequent Torah knowledge (Toras Menachem).ii*
Siddur: Morning Blessings - mođëh äni
vrcht hshchr - Modeh Ani
mođëh äni ləfanéicha më́lëch chei vəqeeiam, shëhëchëzä́rəta bi nïshəmati bəchëməlah.
I thankfully acknowledge You, living and enduring King, for You have compassionately restored my soul within me.
räbah ëmunatë́cha:
Great is Your faithfulness.
mođëh äni

In his Shulchan Aruch,9*the Alter Rebbe states: "It is proper for one to habituate himself to say Modeh Ani immediately upon waking….This will remind him of G‑d Who is standing over him, and he will then rise energetically." As such, the recitation of Modeh Ani serves as the foundation and the initial step in a person's Divine service over the course of that day. Additionally, the awareness aroused by this recitation should be extended throughout the entire day. At all times, "one should earnestly consider that the great King — the King of kings, the Holy One, blessed be He — stands over him and observes his deeds."10*11*'I have placed G‑d before me at all times.'”

Modeh Ani is recited at the beginning of the day, even before one washes his hands, when a spirit of impurity still rests upon them. Nevertheless, no force of impurity can taint the Modeh Ani of a Jew, because his Modeh Ani emanates from his yechidah, the very core of the soul that is eternally bonded to G-d with an essential connection. One may lack this or that [particular element in his Divine service], but his Modeh Ani remains wholly intact.12*

Although G-d's name is not mentioned in Modeh Ani, this does not reflect a deficiency. On the contrary, by its very nature, a name limits and defines. G‑d’s name does not appear in Modeh Ani because that prayer relates to a level of G‑dliness that transcends all definition. It is simply the essence of a Jew connecting to the Essence of G‑d.

This concept sheds new light on the simple meaning of Modeh Ani, i.e., that it expresses thankful acknowledgment for the return of one's soul after sleep. When a person is arousedby his yechidah, he is not merely thankful for the return of his vitality. He seeks that his vitality be energized by a bond with G-d. Indeed, without such a bond, he does not see his life as worth living. In that vein, it is related that the Alter Rebbe once blessed the chassid R. Yekusiel Liepler with long life. R. Yekusielreplied: "But not a peasant's years. Not years of those ‘who have eyes, but do not see; who have ears, but do not hear’13*14*(the Alter Rebbe's Shulchan Aruch; Kuntres Inyano Shel Toras HaChassidus).iii*
Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… äl nətilät yađáiïm
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Al Netilas Yadayim
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
äshër qïdəshánu bəmïtsəotaiv, vətsïvánu äl nətilät yađáiïm:
Who has sanctified us with His commandments and commanded us concerning the washing of the hands.
baruch ätah Adonai

Blessed are You, G-d… — When we address G-d as "You," we are speaking directly to His Essence. "Blessed" implies a process of drawing down influence.18*Havayah (translated as G-d) which relates to the Ten Sefiros of Atzilus. We are asking that G-d's Essence be drawn down from its essential and simple state and be expressed in the realm of Atzilus, and from there to be drawn down even further until He becomes "King of the world," i.e., that His sovereignty be revealed even in the limited realms of Beriah, Yetzirah, and Asiyah.

The blessing continues with the words “asher kidshanu —Who sanctified us."Asher,translated as "Who," refers to pleasure, as in the word Ashrei.19*mitzvos. For the performance of mitzvos binds us with G-d's very Essence and enables the indwelling of His presence (Torah Or).v*
Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… äshër yatsär
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Netilas Yadayim
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
äshër yatsär ët haađam bəchochəmah, uvára vo nəqavim nəqavim, chälulim chälulim,
Who has formed man with wisdom and created within him many openings and hollows.
galuy vyađ́uä lïfənei chïsse chəvođë́cha,
It is revealed and known before the throne of Your glory
shëïm yïssatem ëchađ mehëm, o ïm yïpatéäch ëchađ mehëm,
that if one of them were to be closed or if one of them were to be opened,
i ëfəshär ləhïtəqeeiem äfilu shaah ëchat.
it would be impossible to survive even for a brief time.
baruch ätah Adonai, rofe chal basar umäfəli lääsot:
Blessed are You, God, Who heals all flesh and acts wondrously.
äshër yatsär ët haađam

…Who created man… — On a simple level, this is a blessing of thanksgiving, for a person's system of elimination is essential to his well-being (the Alter Rebbe's Shulchan Aruch).xii*
Siddur: Morning Blessings - ëloqei nəshamah
vrcht hshchr - Elokai Neshama
ëlohei, nəshamah shënnatä́ta bi təhorah hi,
My God, the soul that You have placed within me is pure.
ätah vəratah, ätah yətsärətah,
You created it; You formed it;
ätah nəfächətah bi, vəätah məshämmərah bəqïrəbi,
You have breathed it into me, and You preserve it within me.
vəätah atiđ lïttəlah mïmmë́nni, uləhächäzirah bi lëatiđ lavo.
Ultimately, You will take it from me, and restore it within me in the Time to Come.
kal zəmän shëhännəshamah bəqïrəbi, mođëh äni ləfanéicha Adonai ëlohei velohei ävotei,
As long as the soul is within me, I thankfully acknowledge You, God, my Lord, and Lord of my fathers,
rïbon kal hämmääsim, äđon kal hännəshamot.
Master of all works, Lord of all souls.
baruch ätah Adonai, hämmächäzir nəshamot lïfəǥarim metim:
Blessed are You, God, Who restores souls to lifeless bodies.
ëlohei

The soul that You have given me is pure — "Giving" an article to another person transfers the article from one person's domain to another's. It does not change the article being given. So too, as the soul is "given" to man in this world, it does not undergo any fundamental change; it retains its essential G-dly nature (Maamarei Admur HaRayatz). xv*

Pure — The term thr, "pure," also means "shiny," as in the verse:30*lthr)." Similarly, the Aramaic translation of noon istyhr , i.e., the time when the sun shines most brightly. Thus the description of the soul as "pure" indicates that its G-dly nature shines forth (Likkutei Torah).xvi*
Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… hännoten läshsë́chəvi vinoh
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Hanotein Lesechvi Bina
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
hännoten läshsë́chəvi vinohləhävəchin bein yom uvein láiəloh:
Who grants the rooster the understanding to distinguish between day and night.
baruch

The Morning Blessings — Our Sages ordained that the Morning Blessings be recited in appreciation for the renewal of the natural order and its functioning — from which the created beings derive benefit — each day. Each day, we should bless the Holy One, blessed be He, for receiving these benefits again33*Shulchan Aruch).xxv*

A similar process transpires within our individual souls. Each day, the soul is returned with renewed energy, with each of its powers rejuvenated (Toras Shmuel).xxvi*

Each of the Morning Blessings thanks G-d for a particular benefit that man receives: sight, the ability to walk upright, etc. There is a difference of opinion among the halachic authorities as to whether one is required to recite a particular blessing if he does not personally experience the corresponding benefit. For example, the blessing "Who provides me with all my needs," was ordained as an expression of thanks for wearing shoes.34*35*36*

There is a spiritual parallel to this halachic ruling. It is possible that a person may not feel spiritual renewal in one — or several — of the dimensions associated with these blessings. Nevertheless, he is required to acknowledge that the process of renewal is ongoing. He need but sensitize himself and heighten his awareness of the Divine energy G-d is radiating to the world and he will eventually feel this Divine energy (Toras Menachem).xxvii*
Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… poqéäch ïvərim
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Pokeach Ivrim
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
poqéäch ïvərim:
Who opens the eyes of the blind.
poqéäch ïvərim:

…Who opens the eyes of the blind — This is a request that G-d remove our blindness to the spiritual and that He open our eyes to see the G-dliness invested in the world (Toras Chayim).xxxii*

For the fundamental difference between holiness and kelipah is the ability to see G-dly truth with the eye of our mind and thus recognize the true nature of every situation (Meah Shearim).xxxiii*
Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… mätir äsurim
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Matir Asurim
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
mätir äsurim:
Who releases the bound.
mätir äsurim:

…Who releases the bound — This is a request that we not be bound by the material orientation of the body. Indeed, assurim, translated as "bound," can also mean "imprisoned." Each morning, the soul is granted renewed spiritual energy to step beyond the prevailing spiritual darkness. In response, one should rejoice with the happiness a detainee would feel upon his release from prison (Toras Chayim; Pokeach Ivrim).xxxiv*

Our limbs are analogies for our emotions. A person is described as bound when his limbs, i.e., the expression of his spiritual emotions — his love and fear of G-d — are restricted. "Releasing the bound" implies the ability to give free rein to those feelings (Meah Shearim).xxxv*

Adam, "man," is derived from the phrase:41*Adamah L'Elyon, "I resemble the One Above." Thus all of man's actions: his limbs being released, his clothing himself, and his taking steps, reflect what transpires in the spiritual realms Above and, consequently, draw down G-dly influence into this material world. Hence, these actions are acknowledged in our blessings (Likkutei Torah; Toras Shmuel).xxxvi*
Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… zoqef kəfufim
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Zokef Kefufim
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
zoqef kəfufim:
Who straightens those who are stooped.
zoqef kəfufim:

…Who straightens the bowed — With this phrase, we request that we function like a man who walks erect, with eyes that can focus upward and recognize his Creator, in contrast to an animal that walks bent over with eyes focusing downward, never looking heavenward (Toras Chayim).xxxvii*

A man's erect posture reflects the proper hierarchy within his soul powers. Man's highest potential is his mind (his head), then his emotions (his trunk), and then his power of action (his legs). We should structure our conduct according to this hierarchy (Meah Shearim).xxxviii*
Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… mäləbish ärümmim
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Malbish Arumim
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
mäləbish ärümmim:
Who clothes the naked.
mäləbish ärümmim:

…Who clothes the naked — Clothes are an analogy for mitzvos, the manner in which man establishes his connection with G-dliness (Meah Shearim).xxxix*
Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… hännoten leeiaef ḱoäch
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Hanoten Layaef Koach
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
hännoten leeiaef ḱoäch:
Who grants strength to the weary.
hännoten leeiaef ḱoäch:

…Who gives strength to the weary — A weary person feels his strength sapped to such an extent that he is unable to function. So too, it is possible for a person to feel spiritually weary, incapable of expressing the energies of his G-dly soul. Every morning, G-d grants a person fresh energy, enabling him to realize his spiritual potential (Meah Shearim).xl*

Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… hämmechin mïtsəäđei ǥávër
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Hamechin Mitzadei Gaver
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
hämmechin mïtsəäđei ǥávër:
Who makes man’s footsteps stable.
hämmechin mïtsəäđei ǥávër:

…Who directs the steps of man — This blessing highlights how G-d influences man's will, causing him to desire to follow His will. As such, a person is aroused to seek out holiness and make it part of his life (Meah Shearim).xli*
Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… shëasah li kal tsorəki
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Sheasah Li Kol Tzarki
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
shëasah li kal tsorəki:
Who has provided me with my every need.
shëasah li kal tsorəki:

…Who provides me with all of my needs — Our Sages interpret42*Maamarei Admur HaEmtza'i).xlii*

In this vein,a connection can be seen between this and the following two blessings — girding our trunk and crowning our head — because they all deal with garments. Shoes are garments for the feet, a belt garbs the trunk, and a crown adorns the head. In spiritual terms, this refers to the encompassing powers43*of our deeds (feet), feelings (trunk), and thoughts (head). (Meah Shearim).xliii*

Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… shëllo asä́ni goi
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Shelo Osani Goy
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
shëllo asä́ni goi:
Who has not made me a gentile.
shëllo asä́ni goi:

…Who did not make me a gentile — This blessing expresses one's thanks at the opportunity to live a life of intimate connection to G-dliness, rather than that of an ordinary material existence (Ner Mitzvah).xlv*

R. Levi Yitzchak of Berditchevwas once seen dancing with joy while reciting the Morning Blessings. He explained that when he reached the blessing "Who did not make me a gentile," he contemplated what it means to have been born as a Jew and rejoiced at his good fortune (Toras Menachem).xlvi*

Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… hämmäävir shenah meeinai
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Hamaavir Sheina Meieinay
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
hämmäävir shenah meeinai utənumah meäfəäpai:
Who removes sleep from my eyes and slumber from my eyelids.
hämmäävir shenah meeinai

…Who removes sleep from my eyes — As mentioned above, sleep is one-sixtieth of death, and the darkness of night is a symbol for the forces of evil. By removing sleep from our eyes, G-d removes us from these influences and brings us into the realm of holiness, as the blessing continues: "Habituate us in [the study of] Your Torah and attach us to Your commandments" (Toras Chayim).xlvii*
Siddur: Morning Blessings - vihi ratson
vrcht hshchr - Vihi Ratzon
vihi ratson mïlləfanéicha Adonai ëlohéinu velohei ävotéinu,
May it be Your will, God, our Lord and God of our fathers,
shëtärəgilénu bətoratë́cha, vətäđəbiqénu bəmïtsəotéicha,
to habituate us in [the study of] Your Torah and make us cleave to Your commandments.
vəäl təviénu lo liđei chetə vəlo liđei äverah vəaon, vəlo liđei nïssaion
Do not bring us close to sin, transgression or iniquity, nor close to a challenge,
vəlo liđei vïzzaion, vəäl yïshəlot bánu yétsër hara,
nor close to disgrace. Let not the evil inclination master us.
vəhärəchiqénu meađam ra, umechaver ra,
Keep us far from a wicked person and a wicked friend.
vəđäbəqénu byétsër tov uvəmääsim tovim,
Make us cleave to the good inclination and to good deeds.
vəchof ët yïtsərénu ləhïshətäəbëđ lach,
Compel our [evil] inclination so that it will be subjugated to You.
utənénu heeiom uvəchal yom ləchen uləchë́sëđ ulərächämim bəeinéicha
Grant us today, and every day, grace, kindness and mercy, in Your eyes,
uvəeinei chal roéinu, vətïǥəməlénu chäsađim tovim.
and in the eyes of all who behold us, and bestow manifest kindness upon us.
baruch ätah Adonai, hägomel chäsađim tovim ləämmo yïsərael:
Blessed are You, God, Who bestows manifest kindness upon His people Yisrael.
vəäl təviénu lo liđei chetə vəlo liđei äverah vəaon, vəlo liđei nïssaion

Do not bring us close… to a challenge — Although it is through withstanding a challenge that a person can reach the highest spiritual levels, one should not bring such a challenge upon himself. Instead, he must wait for the challenge to come from Above, for that is a sign that G-d is in fact endeavoring to bring him to these lofty rungs of service (Toras Menachem; Sefer HaMaamarim Melukat).xlviii*

Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch … äl dïvərei torah
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Al Divrei Torah
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
äshër qïdəshánu bəmïtsəotaiv, vətsïvánu
Who has sanctified us with His commandments and Who has commanded us
äl dïvərei torah:
regarding the words of Torah.
baruch

The prophet Yirmeyahu asks,48*49*Beis HaMikdash and the subsequent exile.

Rashi explains50*51*

“For they did not regard the Torah as sufficiently important to recite a blessing over it. Therefore they would treat its blessings with disdain. Accordingly, even though they were very occupied with Torah study, their Torah study did not protect them.”

“Therefore every person should consider [the Torah] — G-d’s instrument of delight in which He takes delight each day52*

Chassidic thought takes this concept a step further, explaining that blessing refers to drawing down G-dliness.53*vrchv vtvrh, literally, "recited blessings in the Torah," not vrchv l htvrh, "recited blessings on the Torah." That choice of wording highlights that the blessings do not merely thank G-d for the Torah, they draw down essential G-dliness into the Torah.54*Sefer HaBahir, "David would bond the Torah with the Holy One, blessed be He." On one hand, the Torah is always one with G-d, as the Alter Rebbe writes in Tanya,55* "He and His wisdom are one." Nevertheless, that oneness is not necessarily revealed. When G-d's Essence is drawn into the Torah, its G-dly nature is reflected in every aspect of its teachings.

How is G-d's essential energy drawn down? Through bittul, i.e., through a person committing himself to G-d in a manner that transcends his individual self. For that reason, in chassidic thought, the concept of blessing the Torah is associated with the Divine service of prayer as a whole. For it is through prayer that a person goes beyond his self-concern.

When a person studies the Torah with such an approach, the Torah becomes an "elixir of life."56*To quote the Bach:57*"His soul becomes bonded with the holiness and the spirituality of the essence of the Torah, its very source" (Tanya; the Alter Rebbe's Shulchan Aruch; Likkutei Torah; Maamarei Admur HaZakein; Likkutei Sichos; Sefer Maamarim Melukat; Toras Menachem).xlix*

When a person approaches the Torah in this manner, he praises G-d as “the Giver of the Torah," using the present tense. For he realizes that at every moment, the Torah is being drawn down anew from its source and root.

In this vein, we can understand why the Sages associated the blessings of Torah study with the other morning blessings. For the morning blessings are also recited "[in appreciation] of [the renewal of] the natural order and its functioning from which the created beings derive benefit each day."58*59*Toras Menachem).l*

The blessings recited before Torah study differ from the blessings recited before the observance of other mitzvos. The blessings recited before other mitzvos are blessings of thanksgiving, acknowledging our appreciation for G-d's "sanctifying us with His commandments and commanding us." The blessings recited before Torah study have a more encompassing purpose: they praise and highlight the fundamental nature of the Torah itself, as the Alter Rebbe's words state in his description of these blessings: "Therefore every person should consider [the Torah] — G-d’s instrument of delight in which He takes delight each day — as important in his eyes so that he recites the blessings on it with a happiness that exceeds all other [types of] satisfaction in the world" (Likkutei Sichos).li*

Nor is it a result of our innate intellectual abilities or endeavors to reach spiritual refinement. Rather, it comes solely as a result of G-d's choice, a choice that is dependent on His initiative alone and not because of any quality possessed by those who were chosen (Toras Menachem).liii*

Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… äl mïtsəvät tsitsït
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Al Mitzvat Tzitzit
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
äshër qïdəshánu bəmïtsəotaiv,
Who has sanctified us with His commandments and commanded us
vətsïvánu äl mïtsəvät tsitsït:
concerning the mitzvah of tzitzis.
baruch ätah

At all times, a person should be conscious that "G-d is stand[ing] over him,"70*

One should contemplate this matter before studying the Torah or performing a mitzvah, for example, putting on his tallis or tefillin.71*He should also reflect how G-d's infinite light, which encompasses all worlds and pervades all worlds,72* tzitzis and the tefillin, and through putting them on, he draws this infinite light onto himself. This enables him to rise above himself and become subsumed in G-d’s light.

In addition to this general intent, he should contemplate the particular import of these mitzvos: With regard to tefillin, he should intend that the attributes of wisdom and understanding which are in his Divine soul be subsumed in the attributes of wisdom and understanding of G-d, i.e., he should use his wisdom and understanding for G-d alone. Similarly, that his attribute of Daas,which includes both Chessed (kindness) and Gevurah (might and sternness), i.e., love and fear, should be subsumed in G-d's higher knowledge, which contains Chessed and Gevurah. This is the implication of the Shulchan Aruch's statement that when putting on tefillin, one should have the intent to73*"make his heart and brain subservient to Him...."

When wrapping himself in a tallis, he should bear in mind what is written in the Zohar,74*tallis, he draws the yoke of G-d's Kingship over himself (Tanya).lviii*

The mitzvah of tzitzis involves not only the tzitzis, but also the tallis. Indeed, without a four-cornered tallis, there is no mitzvah to wear tzitzis. To explain, the 32 strands of tzitzis represent the 32 paths of Chochmah, wisdom, the mediums through which G-d's light permeates our consciousness. We must, however, realize that the 32 strands of the tzitzis are extensions of the tallis. In the analogue Above: the paths of wisdom originate in the all-encompassing, indefinable G-dly light, a reflection of G-d's infinite potential that transcends all limitation, a light that is too elevated to be internalized within our powers of intellect and emotion. By wrapping himself in a tallis, a person surrounds himself with G-dly light that transcends intellect. Afterwards, the 32 strands of the tzitzis reflect the beginning of the process of internalizing that light. This is indicated by the very name tzitzis which can also mean to "penetrate" (Imrei Binah;lix*Likkutei Sichos).

To develop this idea: The actual recitation of the prayers involves our internal powers of intellect and emotion. The tallis and the tefillin, by contrast, represent encompassing lights that are above our conscious control. They are put on before the prayer service to serve as protective influences. More particularly, the tallis and the tefillin represent the two encompassing soul levels of chayah and yechidah. Chayah is described as an encompassing light that is "close," i.e., sharing a connection with our internal powers. Similarly, the tefillin share a connection with the powers of intellect, i.e., they reflect the power of Chochmah as it exists before it enters into man's consciousness. The tallis, by contrast, represents the true concept of an encompassing light, one that is entirely above connection to the internal powers (Toras Shmuel).lx*

Our Sages describe prayer as a time of battle.75*tallis and the tefillin serve that purpose, guarding his heart and mind from the desires and foreign thoughts that the animal soul may arouse. This protective shield stems from the fact that the tallis and the tefillin represent encompassing G-dly lights above man's understanding. Therefore, they protect him even in situations where, were he to rely solely on his own power, he would stumble and sin (Imrei Binah; Maamarei Admur HaRayatz).lxi*

The tallis and tefillin that we wear are reflections of the sublime tallis and tefillin that are "worn" by G-d, as it were. Thus our Sages speak76*tefillin of the Master of the World" and relate how the Holy One, blessed be He, wraps Himself in a tallis.77*Indeed, this is alluded to in the wording of the blessing we recite before performing a mitzvah in which we describe the mitzvos as mitzvosav, "His mitzvos," i.e., the mitzvos that He Himself performs. As the Midrash states:78*mitzvos that He performs, He instructs Israel to perform.”

There is a twofold motif involved: Our observance of the mitzvos is dependent on His observance, for they are His mitzvos. Simultaneously, however, His observance is, as it were, dependent on ours. When we put on the tallis and the tefillin, we “motivate” Him to do so as well (Toras Chayim; Shaarei Orah; Maamarei Admur HaRashab).lxii*

vrcht hshchr - Barchi Nafshi

My soul, bless God. God, my Lord, You are sublimely exalted:
hođ vəhađar laváshəta:
You have donned glory and splendor.
́otëh or käshsäləmoh,

notëh shaméiïm keiəriah:
You spread the heavens like a curtain.82*
borəchi näfəshi ët Adonai

You are very great — There are two levels of Divine greatness:

a) Greatness that can be perceived by the created beings, as reflected in the verse:79*80*you will find His humility,” i.e., becoming great in the eyes of the created beings is a descent and an act of humility for Him.

b) His essential greatness, about which it is said:81*very great," the verse is pointing to this second, superior level of greatness.

[You enable] mortals [to] take refuge in the shade of Your wings — The word chnfych, translated as "Your wings," can also be understood as referring to a garment, as in the phrase:83*chnf vyv, "his father's garment." Because G-d's kindness is truly unlimited, it cannot be revealed directly and requires "shade" and "garments." This, however, applies only in the present age when the world is not fit for the revelation of His light. In the Era of Mashiach, by contrast, the world will be refined. Siddur: Morning Blessings - baruch… ləhańiäch təfïllin
vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Lehaniach Tefillin
baruchəätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
äshër qïdəshánu bəmïtsəotaiv,
Who has sanctified us with His commandments and commanded us
vətsïvánu ləhańichätəfïllin:
to put on tefillin.
vətsïvánu ləhańichätəfïllin:

When putting on tefillin, one should keep in mind that the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded us to write these four passages which speak of the Unity of the Divine Name and the exodus from Egypt, and to place them on the arm, opposite the heart; and on the head, over the brain.

Doing so recalls the miracles and wonders that He performed on our behalf and which reflect His Unity, demonstrating that He has the power and the sovereignty to do as He desires in the upper realms and in the lower realms. One should therefore subjugate his soul, which abides in his brain, to the Holy One, blessed be He, and the desires and thoughts of his heart to His service. Thus, by putting on tefillin, he will remember the Creator, blessed be He, and minimize his seeking of worldly pleasures (the Alter Rebbe's Shulchan Aruch).lxvi*

This intent is not merely an additional and secondary dimension of the observance of the mitzvah as is true with regard to the intent associated with the observance of other mitzvos, but rather an integral aspect of the actual performance of the mitzvah. When one's intent is lacking, there is a deficiency in his observance87*(Likkutei Sichos).

Through putting on tefillin, we cause G-d to put on tefillin as it were. Just as tefillin are worn on the head, G-d's putting on tefillin involves drawing His intellectual faculties down to the world. For our world is brought into being by G-d's emotional qualities, and through tefillin, we draw down His intellectual attributes, adding a higher light than inherently exists within the world88*Maamarei Admur HaRashab).lxvii*

Tefillin, like the word tefillah, comes from the root tofal, which can mean "join."89*tefillin on our heads and opposite our heartsinvolves joining our minds and our hearts and subjugating them both to the service of G-d. The straps extend from our heads to our legsand our arms to our hands. The implication is that the emotional and intellectual energy aroused should be drawn down to our hands and feet, the limbs associated with action, so that all of our conduct follows the Torah (Igros Kodesh of the Rebbe Rayatz; Maamarei Admur HaRayatz).lxviii*

Tying the tefillin straps is like leashing a dog — the yetzer hara. Once on a leash, he can be led wherever the master wants him to go (the Rebbe's Sichos Kodesh).lxix*

vrcht hshchr - Baruch… Al Mitzvat Tefillin
baruch ätah Adonai, ëlohéinu më́lëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,*
äshër qïdəshánu bəmïtsəotaiv,
Who has sanctified us with His commandments and commanded us
vətsïvánu äl mïtsəvät təfïllin:
concerning the mitzvah of tefillin.
Siddur: Morning Prayers - häreini məqäbel
tflh hshchr - Hareini Mekabel
häreini məqäbel alei mïtsəvät äseh shël vəahävəta ləreächa kamocha׃
“I hereby undertake to fulfill the positive commandment, ‘Love your fellow as yourself.’ “22*
häreini məqäbel alei mïtsəvät äseh shël vəahävəta ləreächa kamocha

It is proper to say before [the morning] prayer:25* “I hereby undertake to fulfill the positive commandment, ‘Love your fellow as yourself.’” – The AriZal26* teaches that mystically, the Jewish people comprise one single entity, the soul of Adam. For the soul of Adam represented the general, all-encompassing soul of mankind, embodying all the Jewish souls27* that would emerge in later eras. Each individual Jew thus constitutes a part of one particular “limb” or “organ”28* of Adam’s soul.29* Although this soul contains 248 distinct “limbs,” these parts are interrelated, each containing some aspects of all the others.

By way of analogy, the human body also consists of distinct limbs and organs: the head, feet, hands, nails, etc. Nevertheless, each part incorporates some of the vitality of the others. For example, the hand contains a certain dimension of the foot’s vitality. The same is true regarding all the other limbs and organs.

While the life-energy from the soul is vested within each organ individually, there is a general life-force that encompasses all the bodily organs equally, causing the body to function as a single organism. As a consequence, because of the intermingling of blood in the circulatory system, one limb of the body can be cured by medicating another.

A similar concept applies to the interrelation of the 248 dimensions of Adam’s soul. This interrelation comes as a result of the source of his soul’s vitality, the sefirah of Chochmah within the realm of Atzilus, where the Ein Sof, G-d’s infinity, rests. The soul of Adam — and thus of all Israel — is derived from G-d’s Chochmah30* and thus serves as the all-encompassing life-force that includes all of these different dimensions.

However, Adam’s primordial soul was divided into numerous root-souls, which in turn subdivided into manifold branches and sparks. Over the course of the generations, these individual sparks descend to this world and become enclothed in bodies, serving as their life-force. When clothed in bodies, the essential unity between these different souls is no longer felt. On this plane, the individual souls are analogous to bodily organs which have become severed one from the other. To continue the analogy, in such a state, the pain of the foot is no longer felt by the hand.

The separation between one Jew and another exists, however, only from the perspective of their bodies; their souls are never truly separated for they are all interconnected. On a soul level, therefore, all Jews are bound together like the diverse organs of one body.

We are therefore commanded to love every individual Jew, since each Jew includes within himself all the souls of Israel. Thus, since a person has something of his fellow within him, he should love his fellow as he does himself. Similarly, he is incorporated within his fellow, as mentioned above with reference to the interconnection of the body’s organs.

This is also the reason one must accept upon himself this mitzvah before prayer. Doing so enables the soul to ascend before G-d through the recitation of the Shema. This ascent is not possible unless the soul is complete and “healthy.”31* To cite a parallel: a sacrificial animal is not acceptable as an offering if one of its limbs is blemished.

The soul reaches a state of health when it willingly incorporates all the other souls within itself, just as one of the organs of the body is healthy when the veins that connect it with all the other organs are healthy. Being unified with all other souls, his soul is able to ascend into the general, all-encompassing light that is its source and root.

This unity is achieved when we demonstrate our love for our fellow Jew on a tangible level32* with a feeling of “what is mine is yours,”33* for his fellow is his own “bone and flesh.”34* (Derech Mitzvosecha).i*

Prayer35* involves requesting one’s needs – both material and spiritual – from G-d. Those requests are accepted more readily when we first generate satisfaction for Him. Now when a father has many sons, his greatest satisfaction is seeing all those sons joining together in unity. Similarly, G-d’s greatest satisfaction is seeing the unity among the Jewish people.36* Therefore, before we begin our morning prayers, we accept upon ourselves the mitzvah of loving every Jew (Sichos Admor HaRayatz).ii*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - mäh tovu ohaleicha
tflh hshchr - Ma Tovu Ohalecha
mäh tovu ohaleicha yääqov, mïshəkənoteicha yïsərael׃
How pleasing are your tents, O Jacob, your sanctuaries, O Israel.37*
vääni bərov chäsədəcha avo veitëcha
Thanks to Your abundant kindness, I will enter Your house;
ëshətächävëh ël heichäl qođəshəcha byïrəatëcha׃
I will prostrate myself toward Your holy Sanctuary in awe of You.38*
vääni təfïllati ləcha Adonai et ratson,
As for me, may my prayer to You, O G-d, be at a time of favor;
ëlohim bərav chäsədëcha, äneni bëëmët yïshəëcha׃
O God, in Your abundant kindness, respond to me with Your true deliverance.”39*
mäh tovu ohaleicha yääqov, mïshəkənoteicha yïsərael

How pleasing are your tents O Jacob, your sanctuaries, O Israel – Our Sages40* identify “your tents” with synagogues and houses of study, and “your sanctuaries” with the indwelling of the Divine presence, as manifest in the Beis HaMikdash.

A tent is a temporary dwelling, while the term “sanctuary” implies a permanent residence. The “tents” are associated with Jacob (Yaakov), the name which refers to Jews who involve themselves with the material realities of this world. For the Hebrew letters of the name Yaakov, yqv, can be divided as y qv, indicating how the Yud, the Divine presence, is drawn down into the eikev, the heel, the least sensitive limb of the body. Thus it refers to individuals on a lower spiritual level. The name Israel, (Yisrael, yshrl), on the other hand, is spelled with the same letters as the words (ly rsh) “a head for me,” thus referring to souls from a higher plane.

The Divine service of the Jews who are on the level of Yaakov involves interacting with the material realities of the world in a holy way – practicing proper business ethics, performing deeds of kindness, and showing love for their fellow man. Through such conduct, they draw G-dliness down to the lowest levels of material existence.

Yaakov is thus associated with tents, for souls on this level are unable to internalize the Divine light drawn down to them. Instead, like a tent, that light acts as an encompassing influence. In the Mishkan, the temporary Sanctuary that traveled with the Jewish people through the desert, the term “tent” (ohel) referred to the goatskin covering that protected the Sanctuary. Similarly, the encompassing light generated by the Divine service of the souls on the level of Yaakov creates a protective shield comparable to that goatskin covering.

The Divine service of the Jews on the level of Yisrael, by contrast, is focused on Torah study. Through it, G-dliness is drawn down in an overtly revealed manner. Hence, it is associated with “Your sanctuaries,” the Beis HaMikdash, the places where G-dliness was overtly revealed.

The connection between Torah study — the fundamental Divine service of these individuals — and the Sanctuary is further emphasized by our Sages’ statement:41* “From the destruction of the Beis HaMikdash onward, all the Holy One, blessed be He, has in this world is the four cubits of Torah law.” The G-dliness that was manifest in the Sanctuary and the Beis HaMikdash is also manifest in the study of Torah law.

Mishkan, mshchn, “Sanctuary,” relates to the root, shchn, meaning “dwell,” thus implying that the G-dly influence generated by Torah study is internalized. So too, through the intellectual approach of Yisrael, the person’s connection with G-dliness becomes part of his very self42* (Likkutei Torah;iii* Maamarei Admor HaRayatz).iv*

Yaakov and Yisrael can also be considered two phases on the ladder of Divine service.43* Yaakov reflects an initial stage, when one is primarily involved with the service of “turn[ing] away from evil.” These efforts draw down G-dly light, which serves as a protective influence for the Jewish people. This is comparable to a tent that protects whatever is within it from sun and rain.

Yisrael refers to a person on a higher level of service, one absorbed in the endeavors of Torah study and prayer. Such efforts bring about “Your sanctuaries,” enabling G-dliness to dwell in a revealed manner in the person’s heart and mind. The sequence of the phases, however, is important, for it is impossible to reach the level of Yisrael without first performing the Divine service of Yaakov (Maamarei Admor HaEmtza’i).v*

vəïm ruchi gəviati, Adonai li vəlo ira׃
And with my spirit, my body; God is with me, I shall not fear.46*
äđon olam äshër maläch, bətërëm kal yətsur nïvəra

Lord of the world, Who reigned before any being was created – This statement appears to contradict the principle that47* “There is no king without a nation.” That principle is seemingly a logical imperative, because the very definition of kingship involves dominion over free men who resemble the king48* yet are on a lower level49* and therefore accept him as ruler. Their acceptance of him is not a result of their understanding his greatness or of their love for him,50* but rather a submission to his authority. If this is so, how can there be kingship when nothing else exists?

In resolution, the principle that “There is no king without a nation” applies only on the earthly plane. Supernally, the concept of kingship exists before the subjects over whom G-d is King come into being.

G-d possesses the potential51* for the quality of kingship; it is a dimension of His essential Being.52* When this quality is expressed, created entities who exist in order to accept Him as king come into being. More concisely, an earthly king derives his authority from his subjects’ acceptance of him as king. G-d, by contrast, is a King in essence. As such, His kingship brings into existence beings who accept His sovereignty.

Based on the above, we can understand why our early sages 53* emphasized the importance of concentrating on the passage Adon Olam before prayer in general, and particularly on Rosh HaShanah.54* Prayer entails bonding with G-d. Concentrating on this passage motivates a person to bond himself to Him with an all-encompassing selflessness (bittul), accepting the yoke of His servitude in an absolute manner (Maamarei Admor HaZakein HaKetzarim; the series of maamarim entitled BeShaah SheHikidimu, 5672; Sefer HaMaamarim 5703).xi*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - ëloqéinu veloqei ävotéinu
tflh hshchr - Elokeinu Velokei Avoseinu
ëlohéinu velohei ävotéinu,
Our God and God of our fathers,
zochərénu bəzïkaron tov ləfanéicha,
remember us favorably before You,
ufoqəđénu bïfəqüdät yəshuah
and visit upon us deliverance and mercy,
vərächämim mïshshəmei shəmei që́đëm,
whose source is in the primeval and loftiest heavens.90*
uzəchar lánu Adonai ëlohéinu ähävät häqqäđəmonim
Remember for our sake, God our Lord, the love of the Patriarchs,
ävəraham yïtsəchaq vyïsərael ävađéicha,
Avraham, Yitzchak, and Yisrael, Your servants,
vəët häbərit vəët hächë́sëđ vəët häshshəvuoh
and the covenant, the kindness, and the oath91*
shënnïshəbä́əta ləävəraham av́inu bəhär hämmoriah,
that You swore to Avraham our father at Mount Moriah,
vəët haäqeđah shëaqäđ ët yïtsəchaq bəno äl gäbei hämmïzəbéäch, käkatuv bətoratë́cha:
and the Akeidah,92*93*
ëlohéinu velohei ävotéinu

Our G-d and G-d of our fathers – Rather than beginning this prayer with the words “Our G-d,” it might seem more fitting to first address G-d as "the G-d of our fathers," for chronologically, the Divine service of the Patriarchs preceded – and made possible – our Divine service. Additionally, by mentioning them first, we would be calling forth their merit.

Nevertheless, by first saying "our G-d," we emphasize how relevant our prayers are to us. As we see in practical experience, when something is personally relevant, an individual invests himself and calls forth inner spiritual energies to a far greater degree than he does when dealing with something abstract.

For example, we find that the Sages of the Talmud debate a number of deep, abstract arguments that a maid-servant accused of adultery (shifchah charufah) could use in her defense. How could the Talmudic Sages expect that a simple maid-servant would think of the abstract arguments that they put forth? Because she will be punished with lashes if she fails to come up with a convincing argument to exonerate herself. The threat of severe personal consequences prompts her to reveal latent intellectual powers within her and indeed, think sagaciously.

Similarly, when we perceive prayer as our personal responsibility – not something dependent on our ancestors – we invest ourselves to a far greater degree (the Rebbe's Sichos).lxx*

veiəhi ächär hädəvarim haéllëh

The Akeidah – The Alter Rebbe writes:94*

“It is proper to recite the passage of the Akeidah (the Binding of Yitzchak) every dayto recall the merit of the Patriarchs before the Holy One, blessed be He. This also serves to make one’s [evil] inclination submit to the service of G‑d, just as Yitzchak [was ready to] sacrifice himself (the Alter Rebbe's Shulchan Aruch)lxxi*

The fundamental merit of the Akeidah is not that Avraham was prepared to sacrifice his son. We see – unfortunately far too often in our history – manifold examples of people who gave their lives, and parents who sacrificed their children, for the sanctification of G-d's name. Instead, the uniqueness of Avraham's sacrifice was that he did so eagerly, with remarkable alacrity and a joyous willingness to carry out G-d's desire (Tanya).lxxii*

Alternatively, the uniqueness of the Akeidah was that this was the first time a Jew's life was called upon to be sacrificed for G-d. Breaking through – being first – is difficult in any dimension of Divine service. Certainly, this is true with regard to self-sacrifice. By making this utterly selfless commitment to sacrifice Yitzchak, Avraham made the self-sacrifice of his descendants possible in subsequent generations (Maamarei Admor HaRayatz).lxxiii*

The uniqueness of the self-sacrifice shown by Avraham can be understood through the resolution of a fundamental question. Why is the self-sacrifice of Avraham the focus of this event? It was Yitzchak who was prepared to actually sacrifice his life. In resolution, it can be explained that for righteous men like Avraham and Yitzchak, sacrificing one's life or the life of one's son is not considered a significant challenge. As stated in Tanya,95*the Patriarchs were entirely dedicated to G-d's will as a chariot is subordinate to the will of its driver.

What then was the challenge of the Akeidah? It was a challenge of faith. G-d had promised Avraham that Yitzchak would perpetuate his spiritual legacy.96*97*Nevertheless, without hesitating or questioning G-d's intent, Avraham submitted himself to G-d's will.98*

This represented the crowning element of Avraham's Divine service: At the outset, Avraham's connection to G-d was based on logic. He looked at the world and made the logical conclusion: There must be a G-d Who maintains its existence.99*Akeidah, he demonstrated a commitment that transcended reasonby following G-d’s will out of simple faith and trust (Toras Menachem).lxxiv*

In addition, Avraham's entire life was dedicated to publicizing the presence of G-d. He was in the process of transferring this mission to Yitzchak. Were he to sacrifice Yitzchak, there would be no one left to carry on this service in the world. Nevertheless, Avraham did not think of "what would become of his spiritual legacy" or the like. As soon as G-d gave the command, he set out to fulfill His will without the slightest hesitation (Likkutei Sichos).lxxv*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - rïbon kal haolamim
tflh hshchr - Ribon Kol Haolamim
rïbono shël olam, kəmo shëkaväsh ävəraham av́inu ët rächämaiv meäl bën yəchiđo lääsot rətsonəcha bəlevav shalem,

vyaǥ́ollu rächäméicha äl mïdotéicha.

vətïtənäheǥ ïmmánu Adonai ëlohéinu bəmïdät hächë́sëđ uvəmïdät harächämim, vətïkanes lánu lïfənim mïshshurät hädin,

whom I took out of the land of Egypt, before the eyes of the nations, to be their God; I am the Lord.”
vənëëmär: vəshav Adonai ëlohéicha ët shəvutəcha vərïchämë́cha,

vənëëmär: mi el kaḿocha nose aon vəover äl pë́shä, lïshəerit nächälato,
And it is said:124*Who, O God, is like You, Who is forbearing with iniquity, and forgives transgression for the remnant of His heritage?
lo hëchëziq laäđ äpo, ki chafets chë́sëđ hu:

yashuv yərächäménu, yïchəbosh äonotéinu,

vənëëmär: vähäviotim ël här qođəshi, vəsïmmächətim bəveit təfïllati,
“I will bring them to My holy mountain and have them rejoice in My House of prayer.
oloteihëm vəzïvəcheihëm ləratson äl mïzəbəchi, ki veiti beit təfïllah yïqqare ləchal haämmim:
Their burnt offerings and sacrifices will be favorably accepted on My altar, for My House will be called a house of prayer for all nations.”
ken yïchəbəshu rächäméicha ët kääsəcha mealéinu

Just as Avraham our father suppressed his mercy for his only son in order to do Your will wholeheartedly, so too, may Your mercies suppress Your wrath toward us — On all the levels of the Spiritual Cosmos there exist two vectors of spiritual influence: the right vector that is associated with kindness and generosity, and the left vector that is associated with judgment and retribution. Each prevails over the other at various times. There is, however, a higher level, a degree of Divine will known as r’aiva dechol raivin,“the will of wills,” that isnotconfined by the ordinarychannels of expression. On this level, there is only kindness with no possibility for stern judgment.103*Toras Chayim).lxxx*

umođëh äl haëmët, vəđover ëmët bïləvavo, vyäshəkem vyomär:
He should acknowledge the truth and speak truth in his heart. Let him arise early and say:
Siddur: Morning Prayers - rïbon kal haolamim
tflh hshchr - Ribon Kol Haolamim
rïbon kal haolamim, lo äl tsïđəqotéinu änä́chənu mäpilim tächänunéinu ləfanéicha, ki äl rächäméicha haräbim.
Master of all worlds, we are not presenting our supplications to You because we rely on our own righteousness, but because of Your abundant mercies.
mah ánu, mëh cheeiéinu, mëh chäsədénu, mäh tsïđəqénu, mäh kochénu, mäh gəvuraténu.
Of what worth are we? Of what worth are our lives, our kindness, our righteousness, our strength, and our might?
mäh nomär ləfanéicha Adonai ëlohéinu velohei ävotéinu,
What can we say before You, God, our Lord, and God of our fathers?
hälo kal hägïborim kəéiïn ləfanéicha,
Are not all mighty men as nothing before You?
vəänəshei häshshem kəlo haiu, vächächomim kïvəli mäda, unəvonim kïvəli häsəkel,
Are not the men of renown as if they had never been, and the wise men as if bereft of knowledge, and the men of understanding as if without intellect?
ki rov määseihëm t́ohu, vimei cheeieihëm hë́vël ləfanéicha,
For most of their deeds are empty, and the days of their lives are worthless before You.
umotär haađam mïn häbəhemah áiïn, ki häkol hávël:
The superiority of man over animal is naught, for everything is worthless —
ləväđ hännəshamah hättəhorah shëhi ätiđah lïten din vəchëshəbon lïfənei chïsse chəvođë́cha,
except for the pure soul that will ultimately give an account and a reckoning before the throne of Your glory.
vəchal hägoiïm kəéiïn nëǥədë́cha, shënnëëmär:
All the nations are as nothing before You, as it is written:
hen goiïm kəmär mïdəli uchəshä́chäq mozənéiïm nëchəshávu, hen iim kädäq yïttol:
“After all, nations are considered like a drop from a bucket, like mere dust on the scales; indeed, He can blow islands away like dust.”
rïbon kal haolamim

We are not presenting our supplications to You because of our own righteousness, but because of Your abundant mercies — Since we are attempting to draw down G-d's infinite mercies, we cannot rely on "our righteousness" or any other "arousal from below,” for all our merits are limited and cannot evoke these lofty levels of Divine light. Instead, we ask that G-d, on His own initiative, reveal “abundant mercies” that transcend all limitation (Maamarei Admur HaRashab).xcii*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - äval änä́chənu ämməcha
tflh hshchr - Aval Anachnu Amecha
äval änä́chənu ämməcha bənei vəritë́cha, bənei ävəraham ohävəcha, shënnïshəbä́əta lo bəhär hämmoriah;
But we are Your nation, the people of Your covenant: the descendants of Avraham, who loved You, to whom You swore on Mount Moriah;
zë́rä yïtsəchaq yəchiđo, shënnëëqäđ äl gäbei hämmïzəbéäch;
the offspring of Yitzchak, his only son who was bound on the altar;
äđät yääqov bïnəcha bəchorë́cha, shëmmeähävotəcha shëahä́vəta oto, umïshsïməchotəcha shëshsomä́chəta bo, qaráta ët shəmo yïsərael vishürun:
and the congregation of Yaakov, Your son, Your firstborn, whom You named Yisrael and Yeshurun, out of Your love for him and Your delight in him.
äđät yääqov bïnəcha bəchorë́cha, shëmmeähävotəcha shëahä́vəta oto, umïshsïməchotəcha shëshsomä́chəta bo

Whom You named Yisrael and Yeshurun, out of Your love for him and Your delight in him — The three names — Yaakov, Yisrael, and Yeshurun — represent three planes of Divine service.

To explain the difference between the paths of Yaakov and Yisrael: The name Yaakov indicates a connection to deception.129*Through cleverness, Yaakov was able to snatch Yitzchak’s blessings from Esav. Yisrael, by contrast, reflects a higher rung. For Yisrael, there is no need to secure blessings through craftiness. Instead, they are granted him “as befitting a ruler, in a revealed manner.”

Similarly, Yaakov reflects the way a Jew should approach material activities. There is a certain amount of deception involved. He wears “Esav’s clothes,” i.e., he eats, drinks, and deals in business, but he engages in these activities “for the sake of Heaven.”130*He carries out all his material activities with a sense of inner purpose: to elevate the sparks of G‑dliness contained in the material entities.

The Divine service of Yisrael involves a different approach. The blessings for prosperity granted him by Yitzchak are conferred upon him “as befitting a ruler, in a revealed manner.” He does not have to conceal the G‑dly goal of his material involvement. For material concerns do not create a conflict for him. For him, the material does not conceal its G‑dly source. This concept is alluded to by the name Yisrael, which was granted to Yaakov because, “You strove with angels131*and men and prevailed”132*(Likkutei Sichos).xcvi*

Both Yaakov and Yisrael, however, relate to levels of G-dliness that exist within the limited framework of the Spiritual Cosmos. Yeshurun, by contrast, refers to an encompassing light that transcends that framework entirely. Yeshurun (yshvrvn) thus relates to the term shyr, a term that also has the meaning of “a circular collar,”133*because it relates to the level of G-dly light that is sovev kol almin (“encompassing all the worlds”). Just as a circle has no beginning or end, so too, the name Yeshurun reflects a level on which the Jewish people are united in a manner where no one is higher or greater than his fellow134*Likkutei Torah; Maamarei Admur HaZakein).xcvii*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - ləfichach änä́chənu cheeiavim ləhođot ləcha
tflh hshchr - Lefichach Anachnu Chayavim Lehodot Lecha
ləfichach änä́chənu cheeiavim ləhođot ləcha, uləshäbechächa uləfaërəcha uləvarech uləqädesh vəlïten shë́väch vəhođaiah lïshəmë́cha:
Therefore, we are obligated to thankfully acknowledge, praise and glorify You, and to bless, sanctify, and give praise and thankful acknowledgment to Your name.
äshəréinu, mäh tov chëləqénu, umäh naim goralénu, umäh yafah yərüshshoténu;
We are fortunate! How good is our portion! How pleasant is our lot! And how beautiful is our inheritance!
äshəréinu, shëánu mäshəkimim umäärivim ë́rëv vav́oqër vəomərim pääméiïm bəchal yom:
Fortunate are we that, upon rising in the morning and again in the evening, we declare twice every day, evening and morning:135*
äshəréinu, mäh tov chëləqénu, umäh naim goralénu, umäh yafah yərüshshoténu;

How good is our portion! How pleasant is our lot! And how beautiful is our inheritance! — Making these exclamations can be compared to a child who boasts how great his father is, even though he does not appreciate who his father really is and how he is great. Similarly, we boast of our unique merit in reciting the Shema, even though — at this point in prayer — we do not fully comprehend the greatness of the Shema. For this reason, this portion of prayer is called Kerias Shema Ketanah, "the small Kerias Shema," because we are reciting the Shema while still on a low level.

This phrase can also be interpreted as follows:

"How good is our portion!" — that we labor in Divine service with our hearts.

"How pleasant is our lot!" — that we labor in Divine service with our minds.

"And how beautiful is our inheritance!" — to be able to appreciate and sense G-dliness in all beings and to fulfill the Divine intent in making a dwelling for G-d on this earthly plane (Maamarei Admur HaRayatz).xcviii*

Siddur: Morning Prayers - qəriät səmä qətanah
tflh hshchr - Kriat Shema Ketana
shəmä yïsərael, Adonai ëlohéinu, Adonai | ëchađ:
Hear, O Yisrael, God is our Lord, God is one.*
