tflh hshchr - Baruch Sheim Kevod
baruch shem kəvođ mäləchuto ləolam vaëđ:
Blessed be the name of His glorious kingdom forever and ever.136*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - vəahävəta et h׳
tflh hshchr - Veohavta Et Hashem
vəahävəta et Adonai ëlohéicha, bəchal | ləvovəcha, uvəchal näfəshəcha, uvəchal məođë́cha:
You shall loveGod your Lord with all your heart, with all your soul, and with all your might.
vəhaiu hädəvarim haéllëh äshër anochi mətsäuəcha heeiom, äl | ləvavë́cha:
These words that I command you today shall be on your heart.
vəshïnnänətam ləvanéicha vəđïbärəta bam, bəshïvətəcha bəveitë́cha, uvəlëchətəcha vädë́rëch, uvəshochəbəcha, uvəqumë́cha:
You shall teach them diligently to your children and speak of them when you sit at home, when you walk on the way, when you lie down and when you rise.
uqəshärətam ləot äl yađë́cha, vəhaiu lətotafot bein einéicha:
You shall bind them as a sign on your arm and as an ornament between your eyes.
uchətävətam äl məzüzot beitë́cha, uvïshəaréicha:
And you shall write them on the doorposts of your homes and your gates.137*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - ätah hu
tflh hshchr - Atah Hu
ätah hu äđ shëllo nïvəra haolam, ätah hu mïshshënnïvəra haolam,
You are the One Who existed before the world was created; You are the One Who has existed since the world was created.
ätah hu baolam häzzëh, vəätah hu laolam häba.
You are the One Who exists in this world, and You are the One Who will exist in the World to Come.
qädesh ët shïməcha baolamë́cha äl äm mäqədishei shəmë́cha,
Sanctify Your name in Your world upon the people who make Your name holy.
uvishuotəcha mäləkénu tarum vətäǥəb́iäh qärənénu, vəhoshiénu bəqarov ləmä́än shəmë́cha.
Through Your salvation, our King, raise and uplift our banner, and deliver us soon for the sake of Your name.
baruch häməqädesh shəmo baräbim:
Blessed is He Who sanctifies His name among people at large.
ätah hu äđ shëllo nïvəra haolam

You are He Who existed before the world was created — The concept that G-d's existence precedes Creation — and indeed, all other existence — relates to the concept that He is mechuyav hametzius. R. Yosef Albo (in his Sefer HaIkkarim) defines that term as meaning: “His existence must be; i.e., His existence stems from His very Self and is not the result of any other cause preceding it.”

Implied is that all other beings are created; brought into existence from utter nothingness. In other words, the underlying truth of every created entity is non-being. Since there was a time when it did not exist, now when it does exist, its fundamental state is non-being. Although it does in fact exist, its existence is totally arbitrary; it exists only because G‑d desires that it be.

G‑d exists without any motivating rationale. He just is. And He always was, and He always will be. The very “definition” of G‑d implies that He was not brought into being at any time or by any other preceding cause. Instead, He exists independently, being the truth of all existence (Derech Mitzvosecha;the series of maamarim entitled BeShaah SheHikidimu, 5672).xcix*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - ätah hu h׳
tflh hshchr - Atah Hu Hashem
ätah hu Adonai haëlohim bäshshoméiïm uvaárëts, uvïshəmei häshshoméiïm haëlyonim.
You indeed are God our Lord,141*
ëmët ätah hu rïshon, vəätah hu ächäron, umïbäləađéicha ein ëlohim.
Truly, You are the first and You are the last; apart from You, there is no God.
qäbets nəfutsot qovéicha meärəbä känəfot haárëts,
Gather the dispersed who put their hope in You from the four corners of the earth.
yäḱiru vyeđəu kal baei olam, ki ätah hu haëlohim ləvädəcha ləchol mämələchot haárëts.
Let all the inhabitants of the earth recognize and know that You alone are the Lord over all the kingdoms of the world.
ätah aśita ët häshshoméiïm vəët haárëts, ët heiam vəët kal äshër bam,
You made the heaven, the earth, the sea, and all that they contain.
umi bəchal määseh yađéicha baëlyonim uvätächətonim, sheeiomär ləcha mäh tääsëh, umäh tïfəal.
Who among all the works of Your hands, in the spiritual realms or in the physical realms can tell You what You should do, or what You should bring into being?
av́inu shëbäshshoméiïm, chei vəqeeiam,
Our Father in heaven, Who lives eternally,
äseh ïmmánu tsəđaqah vachë́sëđ bäävur shïməcha hägađol hägïbor vəhännora shënnïqəra aléinu,
deal charitably and kindly with us for the sake of Your great, mighty, and awesome name that is proclaimed upon us.
vəqeeiëm lánu Adonai ëlohéinu ët hädavar shëhïvətächətánu äl yəđei tsəfänyah chozach kaamur:
Fulfill for us, God our Lord, the promise You made through Tzephaniah, Your seer, as it is written,146*
baet hähi avi ëtəchëm, uvaet qäbətsi ëtəchëm,
“ ‘At that time, I will bring you back and at that time, I will gather you,
ki ëten ëtəchëm ləshem vəlïtəhïllah bəchol ämmei haárëts, bəshuvi ët shəvuteichëm ləeineichëm, amär Adonai:
for I will make you renowned and glorified among all the nations of the earth, when I return your captivity before your eyes.’ Thus has God declared.”
ëmët ätah hu rïshon, vəätah hu ächäron

Aside from You, there is no G-d — The name used for G-d in this phrase is Elokim, the name of G-d that is the source for the limitation and concealment of the revelation of the name Havayah, the infinite dimension of G-dliness.

"Aside from You, there is no Elokim" can be understood as implying that the name Elokim is not "aside from You," but rather an expression of You. Although it conceals G-dliness to the extent that our material world perceives itself as an independent entity (a yesh), that is only a superficial perception. By deepening our contemplation of the name Elokim, we can realize that its inner purpose is to bring the revelation of G-dliness to lower levels and thus appreciate that the limitations it produces are merely superficial and the world is fundamentally G-dly (the series of maamarim entitled BeShaah SheHikidimu, 5672).cii*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - trumät hädë́shën
tflh hshchr - Trumat Hadeshen
veiəđäber Adonai ël moshëh lemor: tsäv ët ähäron vəët banaiv lemor, zot torät haolah,
God spoke to Moshe, saying: Command Aaron and his sons, saying: This is the law of the burnt-offering.
hïv haolah äl moqəđah äl hämmïzəbéäch kal hälléiəlah äđ häb́oqër vəesh hämmïzəbéäch t́uqäđ bo:
It is the burnt-offering that remains on the pyre on the altar throughout the night until the morning, and the fire of the altar shall be kept burning on it.
vəlaväsh häkohen mïdo väđ umïchənəsei väđ yïləbäsh äl bəsaro,
The kohen shall put on his linen tunic and shall wear linen breeches on his flesh.
vəherim ët hädë́shën äshër tochäl haesh ët haolah äl hämmïzəbéäch, vəsamo étsël hämmïzəbéäch:
He shall lift up [a pan-full of] the ashes that were produced when the fire consumed the burnt-offering on the altar and place them next to the altar.
ufashät ët bəǥađaiv vəlaväsh bəǥađim ächerim, vəhotsi ët hädë́shën ël mïchuts lämmächänëh ël maqom tahor:
Then he shall remove his garments, put on other garments, and take out [other] ashes beyond the camp to a pure place.
vəhaesh äl hämmïzəbéäch t́uqäđ bo lo tïchəbëh
The fire on the altar shall be kept burning on it; it must not be extinguished.
uvïer aléiha häkohen etsim bäb́oqër bäb́oqër,
The kohen shall burn wood upon it, morning after morning.
vəaräch aléiha haolah vəhïqətir aléiha chëləvei häshshəlomim:
He shall arrange the burnt-offering upon it and burn the fat of the peace-offerings upon it.
esh tamiđ tuqäđ äl hämmïzəbéäch lo tïchəbëh:
A constant fire shall be kept burning on the altar; it must not be extinguished.”156*
vəlaväsh häkohen mïdo väđ

The priest should put on his linen raiment — Because the Divine service of removing the ash from the altar (terumas hadeshen) is an important service, the Torah emphasizes that it must be performed while wearing garments of an elevated nature, garments made from pure linen147*Toras Shmuel).civ*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - yəhi ratson
tflh hshchr - Yehi Ratzon
yəhi ratson mïlləfanéicha Adonai ëlohéinu velohei ävotéinu,
May it be Your will, God our Lord, and God of our fathers,
shëtərächem aléinu vətïməchol lánu äl kal chättotéinu, utəchäpër lánu äl kal äonotéinu, vətïməchol vətïsəläch lánu äl kal pəshaéinu,
that You have mercy upon us and forgive us for all our sins, grant us atonement for all our iniquities, and forgive and pardon us for all our transgressions.
vəsheeiïbanëh beit hämmïqədash bïməherah vyaméinu,vənäqəriv ləfanéicha qorəbän hätamiđ sheeiəchäper bääđénu,
May the Beis HaMikdash be built speedily in our days and [then] we will offer before You the daily offering that will atone for us,
kəmo shëkatä́vəta aléinu bətoratë́cha äl yəđei moshëh ävədë́cha mïpi chəvođë́cha kaamur:
as You prescribed for us in Your Torah, through Moshe Your servant as You dictated in Your glory, as it is said:170*
shëtərächem aléinu vətïməchol lánu äl kal chättotéinu

May it be Your will, G-d… that You have mercy upon us and forgive us for all our sins — Bringing the daily sacrifice involved sprinkling its blood on the altar and offering its fats on the altar’s pyre. Blood serves as an analogy for vitality, warmth, and energy, while fat serves as an analogy for satisfaction.157*

When a person makes a firm resolution that his “blood and fat,” his energy and satisfaction, will be directed to the altar, i.e., to holy matters alone, G‑d forgives his previ­ous trespasses and grants him His blessings, satisfying his — and his family’s — needs in material and spiritual mat­ters (Likkutei Sichos).

My sacrifice — Korbani, the term translated as "My sacrifice," shares a common root with the verb karev meaning to "draw near." Indeed, the function of the sacrifices was to bring one's spiritual faculties and sensibilities closer to G-d.

This concept can be explained through an analysis of the verse that introduces the Torah's description of the sacrifices:158*

The possibility and responsibility for man's connection with G-d lies within himself. No man should say: "How can I approach G-d?" He may realize to what degree he has tainted his soul through improper conduct and recognize the prodigious distance he has thereby imposed between himself and G-d. But still the Torah assures him: "Your nearness to G-d is ‘from you’; it is dependent entirely on yourself." It is within the reach of every Jew to say, "When will my deeds approach the deeds of my forefathers, Avraham, Yitzchak and Yaakov?" There are no true obstacles preventing him from elevating himself and attaining closeness to G-d. If he exerts himself, nothing will prevent him from bonding with Him (Basi LeGani, 5710).

In an ultimate sense, there are three eras in which sacrifices were — or are to be — offered: a) those offered by Adam in the Garden of Eden; b) those offered by mankind after the sin of the Tree of Knowledge, the quintessence of those being the sacrifices offered in the Beis HaMikdash; and c) those that will be offered by the Jewish people after the coming of Mashiach.

The sacrifices offered by man after the sin of the Tree of Knowledge were primarily for the purpose of atonement. Thus our Sages state159*kelipah that became attached to its material substance through Adam's sin. After that sin, Adam and his descendants were charged with the service of refinement,160*

Nevertheless, the purpose of the sacrifices extends beyond atonement, as evidenced by the sacrifices offered by Adam in the Garden of Eden before the sin.161* Adam’s sacrifices drew down a new dimension of G-dly energy.162*Zohar states:163*Ein Sof."164*165*

c) Nevertheless, even Adam’s sacrifices — offerings that had no association with sin — did not represent the apex of man's Divine service, since these sacrifices were offered prior to the Giving of the Torah. As our Sages state,166*reichos,"unsubstantial,"167*did not permeate the world's material substance in a consummate manner.168*mitzvos performed after the Giving of the Torah) and, moreover, the sacrifices will be offered in a pure world where there is no need for atonement, because "I will cause the spirit of impurity to depart from the world."169*Toras Menachem).cxi*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - qorəbän tamiđ
tflh hshchr - Karban Tamid
veiəđäber Adonai ël moshëh lemor: tsäv ët bənei yïsərael vəamärəta älehëm,
God spoke to Moshe, saying, Command the Children of Yisrael and tell them:
ët qorəbani lächəmi ləïshshei, réiäch nichochi tïshəməru ləhäqəriv li bəmoäđo:
Take heed to offer My sacrifice to Me at its appointed time — My food for My fires, My satisfying fragrance.
vəamärəta lahëm, zëh haïshshëh äshër täqəŕivu leiya, kəvasim bənei shanah təmimïm, shənéiïm leeiom, olah tamiđ:
Tell them: This is the fire-offering that you shall bring for God — two unblemished yearling male lambs a day, as a daily burnt-offering.
ët häkë́vës ëchađ tääsëh väb́oqër, vəet häkë́vës häshsheni tääsëh bein haärəbáiïm:
You shall make an offering of one lamb in the morning and an offering of a second lamb in the afternoon,
vääsirit haeifah śolët ləmïnəchah, bəlulah bəshë́mën katit rəviït hähin:
[together with] a tenth of an ephah of superior flour as a meal offering, mixed with a fourth of a hin of oil from crushed [olives].
olät tamiđ, haäsüyah bəhär sinei ləréiäch nich́oäch ïshshëh leiya:
This is a daily burnt-offering, [which you shall bring] as it was brought at Mount Sinai, for a satisfying fragrance, a fire-offering to God.
vənïsəko rəviït hähin läkë́vës haëchađ, bäqq́ođësh hässech në́sëch shechar leiya:
And for its wine libation, you shall pour a quarter of a hin for each lamb on the holy [altar] as a libation of strong wine to God.
vəet häkë́vës häshsheni tääsëh bein haärəbáiïm, kəmïnəchät häb́oqër uchənïsəko tääsëh,
And you shall offer the second lamb in the afternoon, with the same meal-offering and wine libation as in the morning,
ïshsheh réiäch nich́oäch leiya:
to be a fire-offering of satisfying fragrance to God.
ët qorəbani

My food — Food nourishes the body and provides it with energy, maintaining the connection between the body and the soul. Similarly, the sacrifices maintain the connection between the world and the G-dly vitality that sustains it (Shaarei Teshuvah; Toras Shmuel).cxii*

Aaron's sons, the priests, shall cast its blood on the altar — Blood is an analogy for the warmth, excitement, and energy within a person's soul, as implied by the verse:179*Sefer HaMaamarim Kuntreisim).cxix*

Siddur: Morning Prayers - qət́orët tamiđ
tflh hshchr - Ketoret Tamid
veeíomër Adonai ël moshëh, qäch ləcha sämmim, nataf, ushəchélët, vəchëləbənah, sämmim, uləvonah zäkah, bäđ bəväđ yïhyëh:
God said to Moshe: Take for yourself fragrant spices: balm, onycha, and galbanum — fragrant spices and pure frankincense. Each one should be weighed individually.
vəaśita otah qət́orët, ŕoqäch määseh roqéäch, məmüllach tahor q́ođësh:

Siddur: Morning Prayers - pïttum häqqət́orët keitsäđ
tflh hshchr - Petum Haketoret Keitzad
tanu räbanan, pïttum häqqət́orët keitsäđ:
Our Sages taught:183*
shəlosh meot vəshïshshim ushəmonoh monim haiu voh. shəlosh meot vəshïshshim vächämïshshoh kəmïnyän yəmot hächämmah, manëh ləchal yom pəräs bəshächärit ufəräs bein haärəbáiïm,
It contained 368 maneh — 365 for each of the days of the year, a maneh for each day, half to be offered in the morning and half toward evening.
ushəloshah manim yəterim, shëmmehëm mächənis kohen gađol məlo chofənaiv byom häkïpürim,
Of the remaining three maneh, the High Priest would bring two cupped handfuls into [the Holy of Holies] on Yom Kippur.
umächäziran ləmächətë́shët bəë́rëv yom häkïpürim, vəshochäqan yafah yafah kəđei shëtəhe đäqqah mïn hädäqqah.
These [three maneh] had been returned to the mortar on the day before Yom Kippur and were ground very thoroughly so that they would be exceedingly fine.
vəächäđ asar sämməmanim haiu vah. vəéllu hen:
[The incense-offering] comprised eleven kinds of fragrant spices:
1)hätstsari 2) vəhätstsïṕorën 3) hächëləbənah 4) vəhälləvonah mïshəqäl shïvəim shïvəim manëh, 5) mor
1) balm; 2) onycha; 3) galbanum; 4) frankincense — each component weighing seventy maneh; 5) musk;
6) uqətsiah 7) shïb́olët nerəd 8) vəchärəkom mïshəqäl shïshshoh asor shïshshoh asor monëh, 9) häqqoshət shəneim asar, 10) qïllufah shəloshah, 11) qïnnamon tïshəah.
6) cassia; 7) spikenard; 8) saffron — each component weighing sixteen maneh; 9) costus, twelve [maneh]; 10) aromatic bark, three [maneh]; and 11) cinnamon, nine [maneh].
borit kärəshinah tïshəah qäbin, yein qäfərisin səin təlata vəqäbin təlata,
[The following were also included:] Carshina lye, nine kabin; and wine from Cyprus, three se’ah and three kabin.
vəïm ein lo yein qäfərisin mevi chämär chïuäryan ätiq. më́läch səđomit ŕovä, määlëh ashan kal shëhu.
If there was no wine from Cyprus, they would use aged white wine. [Also included were] a quarter [of a kav] of salt from Sodom, and a minute amount of a smoke-raising herb.
räbi natan häbävəli omer: äf kïpät heeiärəden kal shëhi,
Rabbi Nassan the Babylonian says: A minute amount of Jordanian amber [was also added].
vəïm natän bah dəväsh pəsalah, vəïm chïssär ëchađ mïkal sämməmanéiha cheeiav mitah:
If honey was added, [the offering] was invalidated, and if one omitted any of its spices, he was liable to the death penalty [at the hands of Heaven].
Siddur: Morning Prayers - räban shïməon bën gäməliel
tflh hshchr - Raban Shimon Ben Gamliel
räban shïməon bën gäməliel omer: hätstsari eino ëlla səraf hännotef meätsei häqqətaf,
Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Balm is simply the sap that drips from the balsam tree.*
borit kärəshinah shëshshofin boh ët hätstsïṕorën, kəđei shëtəhe naah;
Carshina lye [was used] to rub on the onycha to improve its appearance.
yein qäfərisin shëshshorin bo ët hätstsïṕorën kəđei shëtəhe äzzah.

vähälo mei räǥəléiïm yafin lah, ëlla shëein mächənisin mei räǥəléiïm bämmïqədash mïpənei häkavođ:
Although the water of Raglayim could have served that purpose, the water of Raglayim was not brought into the Beis HaMikdash out of respect.
Siddur: Morning Prayers - tänya räbi natan
tflh hshchr - Tanya Rabi Natan
tänya räbi natan omer: kəshëhu shocheq omer:
It is taught that Rabbi Nassan said: As [a priest] would grind the incense, [another] would say:
hađeq heitev, heitev hađeq, mïpənei shëhäqqol yafëh läbəsamim.
“Grind thoroughly; thoroughly grind,” for the sound is beneficial for the spices.
pïttəmah lächätsain kəsherah, lïshəlish vəlïrəv́iä, lo shamä́ənu.
If one mixed the compound in half quantities, it was fit for use. If only a third or a quarter [of the prescribed compound] was mixed, we have not heard [whether or not it would be fit for use].
amär räbi yəhuđah, zëh häkəlal: ïm kəmïdatah kəsherah lächätsain.
Rabbi Yehudah said: The general rule is that if it was mixed in its proper proportions, it is fit for use even though it was compounded in half-quantities [or even in lesser quantities].184*
vəïm chïssär ëchađ mïkal sämməmanéiha cheeiav mitah:
[A person who] left out one [of the spices] was liable to the death penalty [at the hands of Heaven].

Siddur: Morning Prayers - mïnəchät yəhuđah
tflh hshchr - Minchat Yehuda
vəorəvah leiya mïnəchät yəhuđah virushaláiïm, kimei olam uchəshanim qäđəmoniot:
Then the offering of Judah and Jerusalem will be pleasing to God, as in the days of yore and as in bygone years.193*
vəorəvah leiya mïnəchät yəhuđah virushaláiïm, kimei olam uchəshanim qäđəmoniot:

Then the offering of Yehudah and Jerusalem will be pleasing to God — The sacrifices draw down G-d's pleasure (rvvt), His inner satisfaction that transcends the ordinary structure of Divine revelation. This is evoked by the sacrifices because they transform rv, "evening," and darkness into light (Or HaTorah).cxx*

The term translated as "offering," minchah, can also mean "gift."189*

These offerings represented such a gift. For refining and elevating the flesh and blood of a physical animal that exists in a state of apparent separation from G-d is an entirely new development that calls forth G-d's inner satisfaction and pleasure (Toras Chayim).cxxi*

Minchah also shares a connection to the term menuchah meaning "rest." In an ultimate sense, this refers to "the Era of the Redemption," the era that is "all Shabbos and rest for life-everlasting," i.e., an era of consummate revelation from Above in which man will no longer have to call forth revelation through his Divine service (Maamarei Admur HaEmtza'i).cxxii*

As in the days of yore and as in bygone years — "As in the days of yore" refers to the sacrifices offered by Noach after the Flood; "as in bygone years" to the sacrifices offered by the Jewish people at the time of the Giving of the Torah. The Midrash states190*191*

What is the difference between these two types of sacrifices? The sacrifices offered by Noach drew down G-dliness into the external dimensions of existence. Therefore, they called forth G-d's covenant that "Seed time and harvest, cold and heat, summer and winter, and day and night shall not cease."192*

In the Ultimate Future, the sacrifices offered by the Jewish people will arouse the positive qualities associated with both these types of offerings. They will call forth the highest levels of Divine pleasure (as did the sacrifices offered at Sinai) and that pleasure will permeate the lowest dimensions of worldly existence (as resulted from Noach's sacrifices). By combining these two seemingly opposite thrusts, the sacrifices will serve as fundamental elements ofG-d’s dwelling place, established by man in this lowly world (Or HaTorah, Toras Menachem).cxxiii*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - äbeeiei hävah məsäder
tflh hshchr - Abbaye Hava Mesader
äbeeiei hävah məsäder séđër hämmäärachah mïshshəma đïǥəmora, vəällïba đəäba shaul,
Abbaye would recount the [sequence of offerings, beginning with] the arrangement [of wood on the outer altar], based on scholarly tradition, according to the teaching of Abba Shaul.
määrachah ǥəđolah qođë́mët ləmäärachah shəniah shël qət́orët,
The large arrangement [of wood on the altar] preceded the second arrangement [of wood, from which coals were taken] for the incense-offering.
umäärachah shəniah shël qət́orët qođë́mët ləsïdur shənei ǥïzərei etsim,
The second arrangement [of wood] for the incense-offering preceded the placement of the two logs.
vəsïdur shənei ǥïzərei etsim q́ođëm ləđïshshun mïzəbéäch häpənimi,
The placement of the two logs preceded the clearing of the ashes from the inner altar.
vəđïshshun mïzəbéäch häpənimi q́ođëm ləhättavät chamesh nerot,
The clearing of the ashes from the inner altar preceded the cleaning of the five lamps [of the Menorah].
vəhättavät chamesh nerot qođë́mët ləđäm hätamiđ,
The cleaning of the five lamps preceded [the dashing of] the blood of the daily offering.
vəđäm hätamiđ q́ođëm ləhättavät shətei nerot,
[The dashing of] the blood of the daily offering preceded the cleaning of the [remaining] two lamps [of the Menorah].
vəhättavät shətei nerot qođë́mët lïqət́orët,
The cleaning of the two lamps preceded the incense-offering.
uqət́orët qođë́mët ləevarim,
The incense-offering preceded [the offering of] the limbs on the altar.
vəevarim ləmïnəchah, umïnəchah lächävïtin,
[The offering of] the limbs preceded the meal-offering. The meal-offering preceded the fried chavitin.
vächävïtin lïnəsachin, unəsachin ləmusafin,
The chavitin preceded the wine libations. The wine libations preceded the additional [Mussaf] offering.
umusafin ləvazichin, uvazichin qođəmin lətamiđ shël bein haärəbáiïm.
The additional offering preceded the [two] bowls [of frankincense]. The bowls [of frankincense] preceded the afternoon daily offering.
shënnëëmär: vəaräch aléiha haolah vəhïqətir aléiha chëləvei häshshəlomim,
This [sequence] is indicated by the verse,202*kohen] shall arrange the burnt-offering upon it, and upon it he shall burn the fat of the peace-offerings.”
aléiha häshəlem kal häqqorəbanot küllam:
[This can be understood to mean] “upon it” — i.e., after it, [that is, after the morning daily offering], you shall complete [the offering of] all the sacrifices.203*
vəđäm hätamiđ q́ođëm ləhättavät shətei nerot

The cleaning of the five cups [of the Menorah]194* sacrifice precedes the cleaning of the [remaining] two cups [of the Menorah] —The kindling of the seven-branched Menorah in the Sanctuary has its parallel in our Divine service: the illumination of one's seven emotional qualities (the wick and the lamps) with the light of Chochmah (the oil and the flame). Before the kindling of the lamps of the Menorah is completed, the blood of the daily sacrifice must be offered. For offering that blood represents the transformation of the animal soul — that its vitality and energy be directed to G-dliness — as indicated by the interpretation195*196*197*

Nevertheless, before that blood is offered, five of the lamps of the Menorah are prepared.198*Chochmah to the emotions. Afterwards, there can be an expression of love in the heart which enables the light of Chochmah to shine in its full power, extending even unto the lower levels of the emotions (Shaarei Orah).cxxiv*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - onna bəch́oäch
tflh hshchr - Ana Bechoach
onna, bəch́oäch gəđüllät yəminəcha, tätir tsərurah. (v"ǥ yt"ts)
We entreat You, with the great power of Your right hand, release the bound.
qäbel rïnnät ämməcha, sägəvénu, tähärénu, nora. (qr" sht"n)
Accept the supplication of Your people; fortify us, purify us, O Awesome One.
na ǥïbor, dorəshei yïchuđəcha, kəvavät shomərem. (nǥ"đ ych"sh)
Please, O Mighty One, guard those who seek Your oneness, as one guards the apple of the eye.
borəchem, tähärem, rächämei tsïđəqotəcha tamiđ goməlem. (vt"r tst"ǥ)
Bless them, purify them; bestow upon them always Your merciful righteousness.
chäsin qađosh, bərov tuvəcha nähel äđatë́cha. (chq"v tn")
Mighty and Holy One, in Your abundant goodness, guide Your congregation.
yachiđ, geëh, ləämməcha pəneh, zochərei qəđüshshotë́cha. (yǥ"l fz"q)
Unique and Exalted One, turn to Your people, who recall Your holiness.
shävəaténu qäbel, ushəmä tsääqaténu, yođéä täälumot. (shq"v tsy"t)
Accept our entreaty; hear our cry, Knower of hidden things.
baruch shem kəvođ mäləchuto ləolam vaëđ:
Blessed be the name of His glorious kingdom forever and ever.213*
onna, bəch́oäch gəđüllät yəminəcha

Please, with the strength of the greatness of Your right hand — G-d's right hand is associated with the Torah,204*205*yetzer hara, as the verse continues: "Your right hand, O G-d, shatters the enemy."

From the perspective of G-d's transcendence, there is the possibility for negative forces to exist. Because of His exalted nature, it is as if He does not notice them, nor do they create a conflict for Him, as it is written: "Darkness is the same as light."206*207*

It is thus through "the strength of the greatness of Your right hand," the power generated by a Jew’s Torah study, that the power of kelipah can be broken and those "bound" by the forces of kelipah can be extricated and "released" (Likkutei Torah).cxxvii*

When combined, the first letter of each of the words of the first line of the prayer n vchch are numerically equivalent to 506, the numerical equivalent of the word tvl, meaning "worm." Similarly, the first letter of each of the words of the last line of this prayer ("Accept our entreaty") are numerically equivalent to 906, the numerical equivalent of the word tvlt, the feminine form of tvl.

The prophet208* Just as a worm's power is in its mouth, so too, it is through the Jews' Torah study ("the strength of Your right hand") and prayer ("Accept our entreaty") that their power becomes manifest.

Continuing the analogy, just as a lowly worm can gnaw away at a tall cedar with its mouth until it fells it, so too, utilizing the powers of Torah and prayer emanating from their mouths, Jews can overcome enemies that outwardly look far more formidable than they (Likkutei Torah).cxxviii*

There are 42 words in the prayer Ana BeKoach. The number 42 is kabbalisticallysignificant,209*210*Sefirah of Malchus.211*Eretz Yisrael. For that reason, the prayer Ana BeKoach is recited in the prayer service at the beginning of those phases of prayer that reflect a transition to a mode of ascent. For example, it is recited in the Kabbalas Shabbos prayer because Shabbos represents the ascent on Shabbos of the spiritual vitality enclothed in the lower worlds during the six weekdays. Similarly, it is included in the Kerias Shema recited before retiring, for at night, the soul ascends to its source in the spiritual realms. And it is recited before the Morning and Afternoon Prayers because it is through these prayers212*Gevurah (might) which is associated with the analogy of fire and reflects this spiritual motif (Likkutei Torah; Maamarei Admur HaZakein; Or HaTorah; Maamarei Admur HaRashab).cxxix*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - rïbon haolamim
tflh hshchr - Ribon Haolamim
rïbon haolamim, ätah tsïuitánu ləhäqəriv qorəbän hätamiđ bəmoäđo, uləhäqətir häqqət́orët bïzəmännah,
Master of the worlds, You commanded us to offer the daily sacrifice at its appointed time and to offer the incense at its designated time,
vəlïhyot häkohänim bäävođatam, uləviïm bəđuchanam, vyïsərael bəmäämađam,
with the kohanim performing their service, the Levites [singing] on their platform, and the Yisraelites attending [the sacrifices].
vəätah bääonotéinu, charäv beit hämmïqədash uvüttäl hätamiđ vəhäqqət́orët,
But now, because of our sins, the Beis HaMikdash was destroyed and the daily offering and the incense-offering were disrupted.
vəein lánu lo chohen bäävođato, vəlo levi bəđuchano, vəlo yïsərael bəmäämađo:
We have neither a kohen performing his service, nor a Levite on his platform, nor a Yisraelite attending.
lachen yəhi ratson mïlləfanéicha Adonai ëlohéinu velohei ävotéinu,sheeiəhe śiäch sïfətotéinu chashuv uməqübal ləfanéicha,
Therefore, may it be Your will, God, our Lord and God of our fathers, that the utterance of our lips be considered and accepted by You
kəïllu hïqərä́vənu qorəbän hätamiđ bəmoäđo vəamä́đənu äl määmađo, vəhïqətä́rənu häqqətórët bïzəmännah, kəmah shënnëëmär:
as if we had offered the daily sacrifice at its appointed time, stood in attendance for it, and offered the incense at its designated time, as it is written:217*
unəshälləmah farim səfatéinu:
“We will compensate for [the sacrifice of] bulls by [the prayers of] our lips.”
vənëëmär: zot hätorah laolah lämmïnəchah vəlächättat vəlaasham vəlämmïlluim uləzë́väch häshshəlomim:
And it is said,224*
vəlïhyot häkohänim bäävođatam, uləviïm bəđuchanam, vyïsərael bəmäämađam

The priests to perform their service, the Levites to [chant] on their platform, and the Israelites to attend [the sacrifices] —The Zohar speaks of the time of prayer as “a time of battle.”214*

The right vector is identified with the service of love, the left vector with the service of fear and awe, and the middle vector with the service of mercy. Opposite these vectors of the G-dly soul are the attributes of the animal soul with its physical desires (the corruption of Divine love), timidity and petty fears (the corruption of Divine fear and awe), and idle boasting (the corruption of the Divine attribute of mercy). These opposing forces battle each other. For example, when the love of G-d in the G-dly soul is aroused, the pursuit of material desires is subdued; when one's awe of G-d is aroused, all the petty fearsstemming from the animal soul are erased.

The Kohanim are identified with the right vector, love that stems from the realization of one’s closeness to and appreciation of G-d. This love draws G-dliness even closer and causes it to descend to this material plane. Levites, by contrast, are identified with fear and awe stemming from the left vector. The awareness of the distance from G-d stemming from this awe arouses a thirst and desire to bond with Him. The Divine service of the Kohanim and the Levites coalesce, bringing about an integration of the tendencies of ratzo,215*yearning for G-dliness,and shov,216*bringing G-dliness down to the material plane.

The integration of the two services performed by the Kohanim and the Levites enables the possibility of a bond with G-d. That bond, however, is primarily manifest in the "the Israelites in their attendance at the sacrifices." For the Israelites represent the middle vector, identified with mercy, the vector in which G-d's essential dimensions are manifest (the Tzemach Tzedek's Biurei Zohar; Maamarei Admur HaRashab).cxxx*
Siddur: Morning Prayers - eizëhu məqoman
tflh hshchr - Eizehu Mekoman

I1) In234*Beis HaMikdash Courtyard].

In what locations was the sacrificial [service performed]? — Our Sages established the practice of reciting225*Mishnayos beginning Eizehu Mekoman226*andthe beraisa beginning Rabbi Yishmael227*Mishnah and Talmud every day.

Additionally, the mishnah beginning Eizehu Mekoman was ordained to be recited after the passages describing the daily sacrifices and incense offering, for through the study of all these passages,228*229*Shulchan Aruch).cxxxiv*

Reciting these passages before prayer makes one conscious of the destruction of the Beis HaMikdash and our inability to bring sacrificial offerings at the present time. This will arouse feelings of bitterness and contrition, prompting him to request with heartfelt sincerity that the Beis HaMikdash be rebuilt230*Kuntreisim).cxxxv*

Another reason why this chapter [of Mishnayos] is recited is that it does not include any differences of opinion between the Sages,231*Shulchan Aruch).cxxxvi*

[The meat from these sacrifices] could be eaten within the entire city [of Jerusalem], by any person, prepared in any manner, during the day [the sacrifice was offered] and on the following night, and during the [next] day.
hämmuram mehëm keeiotse vahëm, ëlla, shëhämmuram nëëchal läkohänim lïnəsheihëm vəlïvəneihëm uləävəđeihëm:
Similar rules apply to the portions taken from them, except that they could be eaten [solely] by the kohanim, their wives, their children, and their servants.
z

The peace offerings… [The meat from these sacrifices]may be eaten within the entire city [of Jerusalem], by any person — The meat of the peace offerings was not only eaten by Kohanim, but by ordinary Israelites. The sacrifices brought the revelation of G-dliness into all the physical substance of the offerings brought. For this reason, the offerings were generally eaten by people on a higher spiritual level — the Kohanim — in a holy place — the Beis HaMikdash. The peace offering, by contrast, extended the influence of the sacrifices, drawing down the revealed spirituality associated with them into the realities of everyday life (the Rebbe’s Igros Kodesh).cxliv*

There is a level of Torah study that is referred to as an acquisition, as our Sages commented:260*261*

The level of acquisition reflects an understanding of the Torah that the Jews achieve on the basis of their own efforts. The level of the Torah that is a gift, by contrast, reflects a level that they could not attain on their own and must be given to them.

yïtəgädäl vyïtəqädäsh shəmeh räba. (mn)

May His great name be magnified — The intent of the recitation of the Kaddeishim in the prayer service can be best appreciated by contemplating their spiritual parallels to the different stages of the prayer service. In that context, Yaakov's vision of the ladder265*266*Atzilus, Beriah, Yetzirah, and Asiyah. Yaakov dreamt of angels ascending and descending the ladder. Similarly, through the letters of prayer, angels that will ascend upward are brought into being, reflecting the elevation of our material plane of existence. Afterwards, the angels descend, drawing down G-dly influence to this world.

The first of the four rungs of the ladder of prayerparallels the preliminary prayers recited until Baruch SheAmar. This reflects the ascent into the world of Asiyah in the spiritual realms.267*Yetzirah, parallels the Pesukei DeZimra prayers. The third, the ascent into the world of Beriah, parallels the recitation of the Shema and its blessings. And the fourth, the ascent into the world of Atzilus, parallels the Shemoneh Esreh prayers.

Afterwards, the light is drawn downward through the recitation of Tachanun, the hymn Ashrei,the passage U’va LeTziyon, and the concluding portions of the Morning Service. At the transitional phases268*amud, "a pillar," connecting the higher world and the world below it. In our prayers, this function is facilitated by the recitation of Kaddish, whose recitation aids the upward ascent during the initial stages of the prayer service as well as the descent during the concluding stages.

The first of the Kaddeishim of the prayer service is Kaddish DeRabbanan that precedes Hodu. In it, blessings are also requested for the Jewish people as a whole and particularly for the Sages, following the motif that ahavas Yisrael is a preparatory step for prayer.269*By making these requests, the individuals praying rise not only above their individual identities, but even above their identity as a minyan (a collective), and pray for the Jewish people as a whole.

The recitation of Kaddish also has an effect on the souls of the departed, providing them with the potential to ascend to higher spiritual levels. This, in turn, has a reciprocal effect as it motivates them to arouse Divine mercy on behalf of their descendants (Igros Kodesh of the Rebbe Rayatz).clviii*

The Scriptural source for the first phrase of Kaddish is Yechezkel 38:23: “And I will be magnified and sanctified... before the eyes of many nations,” which refers to the war between Gog and Magog. The Midrash270*states that G-d's name becomes magnified in the world when He executes judgment against the wicked (Or HaTorah).clix*

Behold the power of a Jew — for Kaddish is recited by all Jews, and its resultant effect is achieved by them all. Every Jew causes G-d's "great name" to be magnified and sanctified in the entire Spiritual Cosmos. For the recitation of Kaddish is not only a prayer, it is a description of what transpires in the spiritual realms (Sefer HaSichos 5748).

hođu leiya

“Thankfully acknowledge G-d…” – Just as every day, immediately upon awakening, we express thanks to G-d with the recitation of Modeh Ani, similarly, our daily prayers begin with Hodu.

The verbs modeh and hodu share a common root whose literal meaning is “grateful acknowledgment.” Nevertheless, hodaah, the noun that shares that root, has two meanings: a) the giving of thanks, and b) the acknowledgment of another’s position. One appreciates and accepts the truth of the other’s position even though one does not comprehend it entirely because it is above one’s own level of understanding and, as a result, cannot be altogether internalized.

For example, the expression83* “The Sages acknowledged Rabbi Meir’s [position]” implies that originally, they differed with him and afterwards, they acknowledged the validity of his approach. Now, Rabbi Meir’s understanding surpassed that of the other Sages, as the Talmud states:84* “The Sages were not able to fully comprehend the depth of [Rabbi Meir’s] reasoning.” Nevertheless, although they were not capable of understanding Rabbi Meir’s perspective in all its depth, they conceded to him and acknowledged that he was correct.

Similarly, with regard to our relationship with G-d, hodaah reflects the willingness to go beyond one’s own limited perspective, to bend oneself to His will – acknowledging it even though we don’t understand it and even if he has not sufficiently internalized this commitment for it to become his own natural desire. As we renew our bond with G-d each day – upon awakening and as we begin our prayers – we emphasize our willingness to extend ourselves in such a manner (Likkutei Torah).xv*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - mïzəmor shir
fsvqy đzmrh - Mizmor Shir
mïzəmor shir chänükät häbeiït ləđavïđ׃
A psalm, a song for the dedication of the House, by David.
äromïməcha Adonai ki đïllitani, vəlo sïmmächəta oiəvei li׃
I exalt you, O Lord, for You have raised me up, You did not enable my enemies to rejoice over me.
Adonai ëlohai, shïuäəti eleicha vätïrəpaeni׃
God, my Lord, I cried out to You and You healed me.
Adonai hëëlita mïn shəol näfəshi, chiitani miorəđi vor׃
God, You lifted my soul up from the grave; You granted me life, [saving me] from descending to the pit.
zämməru leiya chäsiđaiv, vəhođu ləzechër qođəsho׃
His pious ones, make music for God, and give thanks, recalling His holy [name].
ki rëǥä bəäpo, cheeiim bïrətsono, baërëv yalin bëchi vəläboqër rïnnah׃
For His anger endures for only a moment; when He is appeased, life is granted. In the evening, one retires weeping; in the morning, he rejoices.
vääni amärəti vəshäləvi, bäl ëmmot ləolam׃
During the time of my tranquility, I said, “I will never falter.”
Adonai bïrətsonəcha hëëmäđətah ləhärəri oz, hïsətärəta faneicha, haiiti nïvəhal׃
God, when You desired, You made my [strength] stand sturdily like a mountain; when You hid Your face, I was terrified.
eleicha Adonai ëqəra, vəël Adonai ëtəchännan׃
To You, God, I call out, and I plead to the Lord.
mäh bëtsä bəđami bərïđəti ël shächät, häyođəcha afar häyägiđ ämïtëcha׃
What is to be gained by [shedding] my blood, in my going down to the grave? Will dust praise You and relate Your truth?
shəmä Adonai vəchonneni, Adonai hëyeh ozer li׃
Hear me, God, and be gracious unto me; God, be a Helper for me.
hafächəta mïsəpəđi ləmachol li, pïtächəta säqqi vätəäzzəreni sïməchah׃
You have transformed my mourning into a dance for me; You have loosened my sackcloth and girded me with happiness,
ləmään yəzämmërəcha chavođ vəlo yïdom, Adonai ëlohei, ləolam ođëëcha׃
so that my soul will play music to You and not fall silent. God my Lord, I will thankfully acknowledge You forever.77*
mïzəmor shir chänükät häbeiït ləđavïđ

“A psalm, a song…” – The two terms, mzmvr and shyr, appear to be redundant. In truth, however, each has a distinct meaning. mzmvr, mizmor, a musical composition, refers to a melody played with musical instruments, while shyr, shir, refers to a song sung by a person vocally.109*

In spiritual terms, mizmor refers to the song of the angels, because they have their source in the external dimensions of existence, the keilim, the vessels that contain and communicate Divine light. As such, their bittul, their self-nullification, is never totally complete; they always retain a certain dimension of personal existence, a sense of self. Therefore, their bittul is expressed in music produced on an instrument – sounds produced by an external entity – paralleling the way in which their sense of self becomes nullified as it becomes absorbed in a higher light.

Shir, by contrast, refers to the song of the souls in Gan Eden. This is an expression of genuine bittul, where there is no sense of self. For there are no trappings of personal existence whatsoever that conflict with a soul’s spiritual expression in that realm.

This psalm was intended to be played and sung at the dedication of the Temple. Therefore, it describes both means of expression, for both were included in the Temple service. There were Levites who played musical instruments and others who sang.

When a psalm begins with the words mizmor shir, the intent is that the two are combined. The mizmor is elevated and subsumed in the higher and more consummate bittul of the shir, i.e., the instrumental music is secondary to the vocals and the music’s purpose is to serve the song. (In other psalms, however,110* these opening words are sometimes transposed and read shir mizmor, indicating how the shir descends and lowers itself to the mizmor, i.e., the vocals become secondary to the music of the instruments.)

Shir also implies a repetitive melody, corresponding to the level of sovev kol almin, which is identified with a circular form, without beginning or end. Mizmor, by contrast, has the connotation of cutting, i.e., dividing a melody into distinct movements, thus alluding to the light of memale kol almin, which brings into being entities that are distinct; each on its own rung (Likkutei Torah).xxvi*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - h׳ mëlëch
fsvqy đzmrh - Hashem Melech
Adonai mëlëch, Adonai malach, Adonai yïməloch ləolam vaëđ (v״f):
The following verses should be recited while standing: God is King; God has been King; God will be King forever.78* This phrase should be repeated.
vəhaiah Adonai ləmëlëch äl kal haarëts, beeiom hähu yïhyëh Adonai ëchađ ushəmo ëchađ׃
And God will be King over all the earth; on that day God will be one, and His name one.79* One may be seated.
Adonai mëlëch, Adonai malach, Adonai yïməloch ləolam vaëđ

“G-d is King; G-d has been King; G-d will be King forever.” The fact that this collection of phrases116* mentions the past, present, and future tenses indicates that it is applicable only within the context of the Sefirah of Malchus. Since Malchus brings into being the limited worlds of Beriah, Yetzirah, and Asiyah – and ultimately, our material realm – it also recognizes and relates to the constraints of time and space that characterize them. The G-dly light above Malchus, by contrast, transcends these dimensions entirely and therefore has no connection to time and space. Ultimately, however, not only does Malchus bring into being our created reality with all its limitations, it also infuses the worlds with G-d’s infinity. For that reason, when referring to G-d, the verse uses His name Havayah, the name used to refer to G-d as He is above the constraints of Malchus; as He is in His transcendence. By referring to His Kingship in the past, present, and future, it implies that the transcendence of Havayah is being drawn down into the structured framework of our existence (Tanya, Shaar HaYichud VehaEmunah, ch. 7; Sefer Maamarim Melukat, Vol. 1).xxxii*

The three mentions of G-d’s name Havayah in this phrase refer to three different patterns of the revelation of G-dliness: memale kol almin, the G-dly light that fills the world and enclothes itself with it; sovev kol almin, the G-dly light that surrounds the worlds and transcends all worlds equally; and a third level which is above both memale and sovev, and indeed, cannot be described in terms of relating to the worlds at all. This level will be revealed in the Ultimate Future and will continue forever. This is the intent of the future tense in this third part of the phrase (Or HaTorah, Siddur).xxxiii*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - hoshienu
fsvqy đzmrh - Hoshienu
hoshienu Adonai ëloheinu vəqäbətsenu mïn hägoiïm, ləhođot ləshem qođəshëcha, ləhïshətäbeäch bïtəhïllatëcha׃
Deliver us, God our Lord, gather us together from among the nations, so that we may thankfully acknowledge Your holy name and glory in Your praise.
baruch Adonai ëlohei yïsərael mïn haolam vəäđ haolam, vəamär kal haam amen, häləluyah׃
Blessed is God, the Lord of Israel, from this world until the World to Come – and all the people said: “Amen; praise God.”80*
kol hännəshamah təhällel yah häləluyah׃
Let all souls praise God; Praise God!”81*
baruch Adonai ëlohei yïsərael mïn haolam vəäđ haolam

“Blessed is G-d, the L-rd of Israel, from this world until the World to Come.” This phrase is also interpreted as “Blessed is G-d… from one end of the world to the other.” In a spiritual context, the verse refers to blessing G-d not only from one end of the physical earth to the other, but from the highest levels of the Spiritual Cosmos to the other.

“Blessing” refers to the process of drawing down G-dliness. “From one end of the world” refers to the hidden worlds. “To the other [end of the world]” refers to the revealed worlds.

To explain: The term “hidden worlds” refers to realms where G-dliness shines so powerfully that it permeates those realms. This causes the identity of the entities in them to be entirely subsumed in G-dliness to the extent that their identities are completely nullified and they do not feel their own selves at all.

The term “revealed worlds,” by contrast, refers to realms where G-dliness has been sufficiently contracted and hidden to enable the entities in those worlds to feel their own identity. The request in this verse is that the level of G-dly awareness that pervades the hidden worlds be drawn down until it pervades the revealed worlds as well and is consciously felt by the entities within them (Or HaTorah, Bamidbar).xxxiv*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - lämənätstseäch
fsvqy đzmrh - Lamnatzeach
lämənätstseäch bïnəǥinot mïzəmor shir׃
To the lead musician: a musical composition and a song to be played [in the Temple].
ëlohim yəchonnenu vivorəchenu, yaer panaiv ïtanu sëlah׃
May G-d be gracious unto us and bless us, and shine His face upon us forever,
lađäät baarëts därəkëcha, bəchal goiïm yəshuatëcha׃
so that Your ways will be made known upon earth and Your salvation among all nations.
yođucha ämmim ëlohim, yođucha ämmim küllam׃
The nations will thankfully acknowledge You, O Lord; all the nations will thankfully acknowledge You.
yïsəməchu virännənu ləümmim, ki tïshəpot ämmim mishor, uləümmim baarëts tänəchem sëlah׃
The nations will rejoice and sing joyously, for You will judge nations justly and You will guide nations on earth forever.
yođucha ämmim ëlohim, yođucha ämmim küllam׃
The nations will thankfully acknowledge You, O Lord; all the nations will thankfully acknowledge You.
ërëts notənah yəvulah, yəvorəchenu ëlohim ëloheinu׃
The land will have yielded its produce; God, our God, will bless us.
yəvorəchenu ëlohim, vyirəu oto kal äfəsei arëts׃
God will bless us, and all [the peoples] from the corners of the earth will fear Him.82*
ëlohim yəchonnenu vivorəchenu, yaer panaiv ïtanu sëlah

“A musical composition, a song…. G-d will be gracious unto us and will bless us; He will cause His countenance to shine upon us forever.” As R. Moshe Alshich states, this psalm refers to the era of Mashiach, when two different thrusts will be manifest. There will be abundant blessings for the Jewish people – “G-d will be gracious unto us and will bless us” – and, as the psalm continues (v. 5), “He will judge the nations [justly],” causing His name to be sanctified in the world at large.

As explained above on the verse Mizmor Shir Chanukas HaBayis, mizmor refers to the song of the angels, while shir refers to the song of the souls. The judgment of the nations of the world – who receive their sustenance via the intermediary of the angels – reflects the mizmor dimension of the psalm,117* while the blessings given to the Jewish people reflect the shir dimension.

Mizmor points to our refinement of the material dimension of the world. When this is accomplished, it will bring about an elevation in the G-dly influence conveyed to the Jewish people (shir); hence, the order mizmor shir. On the other hand, the graciousness and blessing conveyed to the Jewish people is mentioned before the judgment of the nations because the ultimate intent of Creation is for G-d’s presence to be manifest within the Jewish people (Yahel Or; Sefer HaMamaamarim Melukat, Vol. 3, p. 232).”xxxv*

The name for G-d used here, Elokim, is identified with the Divine attribute of judgment, while “be[ing] gracious” reflects G-d’s attribute of kindness. The term fnyv in the above verse, translated as “His countenance,” can also be understood as “His inner dimension,” since a person’s inner feelings are reflected on his face. The inner and essential core of G-d’s judgment is kindness and blessing. Therefore, in an ultimate sense, it is appropriate to speak of Elokim being gracious and serving as a source of blessing.

More particularly, ychnnv, translated as “be gracious,” shares the same root as the term chnvn, which is one of the Thirteen Attributes of Mercy, which reflect transcendent Divine potentials. Nevertheless, even though G-d’s name Elokim brings about the contraction and the veiling of His influence, it is specifically this name that reveals His mercies more powerfully. To cite an analogy: the sun’s warmth is felt more powerfully here on earth than in outer space, although the earth is more distant from the sun than is the space that separates them. Precisely because the earth blocks the sun’s rays and prevents them from traveling further enables the earth’s atmosphere to absorb the sun’s rays and benefit from them (Yahel Or).xxxvi*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - ləshem yïchuđ
fsvqy đzmrh - Lesheim Yichud
ləshem yïchuđ quđəsha bərich hu ushəchinəteh lyächäđa shem y״h vv״h byïchuđa shəlim bəshem kal yïsərael׃
For the sake of the union of the Holy One, blessed be He, and his Shechinah, to unite the letters yud-kei118* with vav-kei in perfect oneness, in the name of all Israel.
ləshem yïchuđ quđəsha bərich hu ushəchinəteh

For the sake of the union of the Holy One, blessed be He and His Shechinah – In Jewish thought, the term “holy” is interpreted as meaning “separate”; “removed.” Thus the term “the Holy One” refers to G-d in His transcendence – He Who in His loftiness exists entirely above our limited framework of existence.

The term Shechinah, by contrast, refers to a level of G-dliness that descends to relate to the worlds and causes His light to rest within our finite realm. The entire purpose of man’s existence is to bring about a union between these two dimensions of G-dliness: that G-d’s infinite light, which exists above the Spiritual Cosmos and beyond time, be revealed within the Spiritual Cosmos and even on this material plane.

The term Shechinah also refers to the source of the souls of the Jewish people, for it is the Jewish people who draw down G-dliness into this world through their Divine service. Thus the union of the Shechinah and the Holy One, blessed be He, reflects how G-d in His transcendence becomes manifest in this world through the Jews’ involvement in the Torah and its mitzvos.

At present, G-d’s unity is not evident in this world, i.e., it is not at all apparent how the world is one with Him. It is only in the era of Mashiach when “all flesh will see that the mouth of G-d has spoken,”119* that His unity will be manifest. By saying “For the sake of the union…” before our prayers, we emphasize that unifying the upper and lower realms of G-d’s expression is the central intent and purpose of our prayers.

As mentioned above, this intent should motivate all aspects of our Divine service, not only our prayers. For this reason, according to kabbalistic texts,120* it is proper to say, “For the sake of the unity…” before the observance of every mitzvah. Indeed, in many Siddurim, the statement of this mystical intention is included before the observance of certain mitzvos and before certain prayers. The Alter Rebbe does not include this statement prior to other mitzvos and prayers, yet he does institute its recitation before Baruch SheAmar. As the Rebbe Rashab explains,121* we say “for the sake of the unity…” at the beginning of our morning prayers, and that fulfills the obligation for all the mitzvos and prayers of the entire day.

This practice, however, raises a question: As is often explained, the Alter Rebbe did not include mystic intentions in his Siddur because he desired his Siddur to be relevant to every person, be he a sage or ordinary individual. Thus the inclusion of this statement here implies that he felt that this intent is relevant to every person. Why then did he not institute its recitation before other mitzvos?

In resolution, however, it can be explained that during prayer, every person – each according to his level – has the ability to focus on the intent implied by “For the sake of the unity….” True, for one’s intent to be genuine, he would have to love G-d with an all-encompassing love that motivates him to devote himself to G-d’s purpose without thinking about his own desires, not even his desire to cling to G-d.122*

Nevertheless, even if, on a conscious level, it is more feigned than true, a person should habituate himself to having this intent in mind, because on a deeper, subconscious level, it truly is genuine. It reflects the inner, essential desire of every Jew.

Making this statement at this point in the prayer service produces an ongoing effect on one’s performance of the Torah and its mitzvos for the remainder of the day, aligning those activities with this fundamental intent.

This relates to a concept of greater scope. As the Rebbe Rayatz explains,123* when a person recites his prayers with the general intent to fulfill the mystic purposes explained by the Sages of the Kabbalah, it is considered as if he in fact consciously had these intents. He may not intellectually appreciate what is being achieved, but through his prayers, he brings about the effect of these mystic intents (Tanya,xl* Likkutei Torah;xli* Likkutei Sichos, Vol. 39, pp. 44-47).
Siddur: Verses of Praise - baruch shëamär
fsvqy đzmrh - Baruch Sheamar
baruch shëamär vəhaiah haolam, baruch hu,
Blessed be He Who spoke, and the world came into being; blessed be He.
baruch omer vəosëh,
Blessed be He Who speaks, and acts [accordingly].
baruch gozer uməqeeiem,
Blessed be He Who decrees, and fulfills.
baruch osëh vəreshit,
Blessed be He Who creates the universe.
baruch mərächem äl haarëts,
Blessed be He Who has compassion on the land.
baruch mərächem äl häbəriot,
Blessed be He Who has compassion on the created beings.
baruch məshällem sachar tov lireaiv,
Blessed be He Who grants a generous reward to those who fear Him.
baruch chei laäđ vəqeeiam lanëtsäch,
Blessed be He Who lives forever and exists for all time.
baruch pođëh umätstsil, baruch shəmo.
Blessed be He Who redeems and saves. Blessed be His name.
baruch ätah Adonai ëloheinu mëlëch haolam,
Blessed are You, God our Lord, King of the universe,
hael, av harächäman, häməhüllal bəfëh ämmo,
the benevolent God and merciful Father, Who is praised by the mouth of His people,
məshübach uməfoar bïləshon chäsiđaiv väävađaiv,
and exalted and glorified by the tongue of His pious ones and by His servants,
uvəshirei đavïđ ävədëcha.
and by the songs of David, Your servant.
nəhällëləcha Adonai ëloheinu, bïshəvachot uvïzəmïrot,
We shall extol You, God our Lord, with praises and music;
nəǥädëləcha unəshäbechächa unəfaërəcha, vənäməlichəcha vənäzəkir shïməcha mäləkenu ëloheinu.
we shall magnify, exalt and glorify You; we shall affirm Your sovereignty and recall Your name, our King, our God.
yachiđ, chei haolamim
You are unique, granting life to the worlds,
mëlëch. məshübach uməfoar äđei äđ shəmo hägađol.
the King. Praised and glorified forever is His great name.
baruch ätah Adonai, mëlëch məhüllal bätïshəbachot׃
Blessed are You, God, the King Who is extolled with praises.
baruch shëamär vəhaiah haolam

Blessed be He Who spoke – This blessing introduces the section of the prayer service known as Pesukei D’Zimra (“Verses of Praise”). Our Sages instituted the recitation of these verses so that our praise of G-d would generate additional light in the higher spiritual realms, following the motif that an arousal from below generates an arousal from Above. For example, praising His kindness and generosity arouses these attributes Above and calls forth their expression. The G-dly light thus generated then enables the Jewish people to bond with G-d on a deeper and more encompassing level, following the motif that an arousal from Above generates an arousal from below.

Nevertheless, the very basis of this dynamic is somewhat difficult to understand. On this earthly plane, one person will be motivated to bring out his hidden potentials through the praises recited by another. Those praises are effective because the two are more or less on the same level and therefore the praise is meaningful and stimulating. But how can praises uttered by man, a limited, created being, be significant to – and therefore arouse the kindness and mercy of – G-d, the unlimited Creator?

In resolution, it can be explained that the power to generate such an arousal is also granted from Above, from a sublime level of G-dly light. This is the purpose of the blessing Baruch SheAmar – to draw down vibrant supernal energies to inspire the Jewish people and endow their praise of G-d with the power to generate an arousal from Above. Since the Jews begin their prayers on a low spiritual rung, an extremely high light must be drawn down to inspire them (Peirush HaMilos).xlii*

<divider />

Blessed be He Who spoke and the world came into being – Speech is used as an analogy to describe the process of creation. Now there is a difference between speech and a person’s intellectual and emotional attributes. His intellect and emotions reflect who he is, revealing to us something about his character, his inner self. His ability to speak, by contrast, defines how he communicates with others and is thus an external dimension of his being. It does not tell us about his character.

Similar concepts apply with regard to the analogue. Thus when a person realizes that Creation comes into being124* from G-d’s speech, i.e., an external aspect of His Being, and G-d Himself is far exalted above that, he will be overcome by awe and fear. He will appreciate the smallness not only of his own being but of the entire realm in which he exists. Moreover, the awe and reverence he feels will itself engender greater humility, for he will realize that the awe he is experiencing is on a very low level: He is not fearing G-d Himself, for he has no perception of Who G-d is. His fear stems only from his experience of the created worlds – what G-d brought into being – which, as mentioned, relates only to His external dimension (Toras Shmuel).xliii*

The expression “Blessed is He Who spoke and the world came into being” can be contrasted with the phrase that immediately follows: “Blessed be He Who speaks and does.” It is explained that the two phrases reflect two different levels of creation. “Blessed is He Who ‘spoke’…” refers to the creation of the world on the level of thought.

To explain: Our Sages state that the first word of the Torah, Bereishis, “In the beginning,” is also considered one of the utterances of creation. Through that utterance, on the first day of existence, all existence came into being on the first day. Nevertheless, on that day, creation was still in a state of potentia.125*

Targum Yerushalmi renders Bereishis as “In wisdom.” Just as the lightning flash of wisdom contains all the concepts that will subsequently be revealed, so too, the utterance of Bereishis included all existence. This is termed creation on the level of thought. Later, when “He spoke and made,” He uttered the remaining nine individual utterances of creation, “Let there be…,” bringing every created being into existence with its own specific characteristics (Likkutei Torah; Toras Shmuel).xliv*

In the Siddur of the Ari zal, it is explained that the prayer Baruch Sheamar reflects how influence is drawn down from the highest levels of the Spiritual Cosmos until it reaches a level that relates directly to our material world. Each phrase relates to a different spiritual rung. For example, the phrase “Blessed be He Who spoke…” refers to the inner dimension of Kesser; “Blessed be He,” to the external dimensions of Arich Anpin; “Blessed be He,” to the hidden dimensions of Chochmah, etc. The purpose of drawing down this influence is to motivate the Jewish people to elevate themselves and the world through their praise of G-d in the Pesukei D’Zimra prayers (Peirush HaMilos).xlv*

Pri Etz Chayim126* states that the words shmr vhyh hvlm serve as an acronym for the term shvh meaning equal. Implied is that a fundamental equality permeates the different worlds and all their particular elements. As they all exist on the primordial level of Adam Kadmon, there is no hierarchy between one level and another; they are all equal.127* They are included in one glance, as it were (Toras Menachem).xlvi*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - mïzəmor lətođah
fsvqy đzmrh - Mizmor Letoda
mïzəmor lətođah, hariu leiya kal haarëts׃
A psalm of thanksgiving: Let the entire earth call out to God in jubilation.
ïvəđu ët Adonai bəsïməchah, bou ləfanaiv bïrənanah׃
Serve God with happiness, come before Him with joyous song.
dəu ki Adonai hu ëlohim, hu asanu, vəlo änächənu, ämmo, vətson märəito׃
Know that God is the Lord. He made us, and we are His, His nation, the sheep that He pastures.
bou shəaraiv bətođah, chätserotaiv bïtəhïllah, hođu lo borəchu shəmo׃
Enter His gates with thanksgiving, His courtyards with praise. Give thanks to Him, bless His name.
ki tov Adonai, ləolam chäsədo, vəäđ dor vađor ëmunato׃
For God is good; His kindness is everlasting, and His faithfulness endures from generation to generation.137*
mïzəmor lətođah

A psalm of thanksgiving – tvđh, thanksgiving, shares the root of the word hvđh, “acknowledgment”; one accepts a truth that he does not totally comprehend.154* To apply these concepts in our relationship with G-d: There are levels of G-dliness – for example, the G-dliness that pervades the natural order – whose existence can be comprehended intellectually. With regard to these levels, there is no need to acknowledge G-d’s presence; it can be recognized by our minds.

There are, however, aspects of G-dliness that transcend nature. These, man cannot comprehend but can merely acknowledge. In the times of the Beis HaMikdash, a thanksgiving offering, whose sacrifice was accompanied by the recitation of this psalm, was brought when a person was saved through Divine providence beyond what is usually revealed in the natural order. This would raise his awareness and motivate him to acknowledge that there are higher dimensions of existence than those manifest in nature (Peirush HaMilos).lxii*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - yəhi chəvođ
fsvqy đzmrh - Yehi Chevod

mïmmïzəräch shëmësh äđ məvoo, məhüllal shem Adonai׃

Adonai hefir ätsät goiïm, heni mächəshəvot ämmim׃
God foils the designs of nations; He thwarts the thoughts of peoples.145*
räbot mächäshavot bəlëv ish, väätsät Adonai hi taqum׃
There are many thoughts in the heart of man, but the counsel of God will prevail.146*
ätsät Adonai ləolam täämođ, mächəshəvot lïbo ləđor vađor׃
The counsel of God will endure forever; the thoughts of His heart from generation to generation.147*
ki hu amär veeiëhi, hu tsïvah veeiäämođ׃
For He spoke, and [the world] came into being; He commanded, and it endured.148*
ki vachär Adonai bətsion, ïvah ləmoshav lo׃
For God has chosen Zion; He desired it for His dwelling place.149*
ki yääqov bachär lo yah, yïsərael lïsəǥüllato׃
For God has chosen Jacob as His own, Israel as His cherished one.150*
ki, lo yïttosh Adonai ämmo, vənächälato lo yääzov׃
For God will never abandon His nation; He will not forsake His heritage.151*
vəhu rächum yəchäper aon vəlo yäshəchit, vəhïrəbah ləhashiv äpo, vəlo yair kal chämato׃
And He is compassionate, forgiving of sin, and will not destroy. Many times He withdraws His anger and does not fully arouse His wrath.152*
Adonai hoshiah, hämmëlëch yäänenu vyom qorəenu׃
God, deliver us. May the King answer us on the day we call.153*
yəhi chəvođ Adonai ləolam

May the glory of G-d endure forever – This phrase can also be interpreted: “May the glory of G-d be extended into the world.”164* When the Torah describes the manifestation of G-d’s presence in the Sanctuary, it states:165* “And the glory of G-d filled the Sanctuary.” Similarly, this verse is a request, asking that His glory permeate the world entirely so that the world itself will reveal how it is G-d’s dwelling. At present, G-dliness is revealed through a process of contraction and concealment. The request of this verse is that His glory be revealed as is, without any such veils (Or HaTorah).lxxiii*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - äshərei
fsvqy đzmrh - Ashrei
äshərei yoshəvei veitëcha, ođ yəhäləlucha sëlah׃
Fortunate are those who dwell in Your house; they will yet praise You forever.181*
äshərei haam shëkachah lo, äshərei haam sheiya ëlohaiv׃
Fortunate is the nation whose lot is this; fortunate is the people whose God is the Lord.182*
təhïllah ləđavïđ, äromïməcha ëlohei hämmëlëch, väävorəchah shïməcha ləolam vaëđ׃
A psalm of praise by David: I will exalt You, my God, the King, and I will bless Your name forever and ever.
bəchal yom ävorəchëëcha, väähäləlah shïməcha ləolam vaëđ׃
Every day I will bless You, and I will praise Your name forever and ever.
gađol Adonai uməhüllal məođ, vəlïǥəđüllato ein cheqër׃
Great is God and exceedingly extolled, and His greatness is beyond comprehension.
dor ləđor yəshäbäch määseicha, uǥəvuroteicha yägiđu׃
One generation will praise Your works to another and tell of Your mighty deeds.
häđär kəvođ hođëcha, vəđïvərei nïfələoteicha asichah׃

vëëzuz norəoteicha yomeru, uǥəđüllotəcha äsäpərënnah׃

zëchër räv tuvəcha yäbiu, vətsïđəqotəcha yərännenu׃
They will articulate the remembrance of Your abundant goodness, and sing of Your righteousness.
chännun vərächum Adonai, ërëch äpeiïm uǥəđal chasëđ׃

tov Adonai läkol, vərächämaiv äl kal määsaiv׃

yođucha Adonai kal määseicha, vächäsiđeicha yəvorəchuchah׃

kəvođ mäləchutəcha yomeru, uǥəvurotəcha yəđäberu׃

ləhođiä lïvənei haađam gəvurotaiv, uchəvođ häđär mäləchuto׃

mäləchutəcha mäləchut kal olamim, umëməshälətəcha bəchal dor vađor׃
Your sovereignty is a sovereignty over all worlds, and Your dominion [endures] for all generations.
somech Adonai ləchal hännofəlim, vəzoqef ləchal häkəfufim׃
God supports all those who are fallen, and straightens all those who are bent.
einei chol eleicha yəsäberu, vəätah noten lahëm ët ochəlam bəïto׃
The eyes of all look expectantly to You, and You give them their food at its due time.
poteäch ët yađëcha, umäsəbiä ləchal chei ratson׃
The following verse should be recited with concentration. If this was lacking, the verse should be repeated. You open Your hand and satiate the desire of every living being.
tsädiq Adonai bəchal dərachaiv, vəchasiđ bəchal määsaiv׃
God is righteous in all His ways and generous in all His deeds.
qarov Adonai ləchal qorəaiv, ləchol äshër yïqəraühu vëëmët׃
God is close to all who call upon Him, to all who call upon Him truthfully.
rətson yəreaiv yääsëh, vəët shävəatam yïshəmä vyoshiem׃
He fulfills the will of those who fear Him; He hears their outcry and delivers them.
shomer Adonai ët kal ohävaiv, vəet kal horəshaim yäshəmiđ׃
God protects all those who love Him, but He will destroy all the wicked.
təhïllät Adonai yəđäbër pi, vivarech kal basar shem qođəsho ləolam vaëđ׃
May my mouth utter God’s praise, and may all flesh bless His holy name forever.183*
väänächənu nəvarech yah, meätah vəäđ olam, häləluyah׃
And we will bless God from now until eternity; Praise God!184*
äshərei yoshəvei veitëcha

Fortunate are those who dwell in Your house; they will yet praise You forever. Fortunate is the nation whose lot is this; fortunate is the people whose G-d is the L-rd. – This is one of those instances where translation falls short. It is hard to find an appropriate term for the word Ashrei. The term is associated with the quality of taanug, pleasure and delight,185* indicating how the Jews’ relationship with G-d is a source of overwhelming satisfaction, as it is written:186* “Then you will delight (tisanag) in G-d” (Yahel Or).lxxxvii*

On this basis, we can understand why the Men of the Great Assembly ordained that the two verses that begin with Ashrei be recited at this place in the prayer service. The fundamental prayer in Pesukei D’Zimra is the psalm beginning immediately after these two verses, Tehillah L’David. This psalm is structured according to the alef- beis187* and appended to it is a verse concluding with the word Halleluyah, which can be divided as hll yh, implying that light is drawn down188* from the letters yh of G-d’s name Havayah. From these two aspects of the prayer’s structure, it could be inferred that only a limited dimension of G-dly light is being drawn down, one that conforms to the limited patterns that govern the alef-beis and these two letters of G-d’s name Havayah.189*

Nevertheless, reciting the two prefatory verses that begin with the word Ashrei clarifies that we are dealing with a loftier rung of G-dliness that surpasses these structured patterns. Ashrei is associated with the quality of pleasure that, in turn, is identified with the Sefirah of Kesser, an unlimited dimension of G-dliness. As an indication that an unlimited dimension is being tapped, the praise continues “forever,” without any limitation (Peirush HaMilos).lxxxviii*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - häləluya־h, häləli näfəshi
fsvqy đzmrh - Hallelukah, Halleli Nafshi
häləluyah, häləli näfəshi ët Adonai׃
Praise God! My soul, praise God.
ähäləlah Adonai bəcheeiai, äzämmərah lelohei bəođi׃
I will praise God during my life, I will make music to my Lord while I exist.
äl tïvətəchu vïnəđivim, bəvën ađam shëein lo təshuah׃
Do not trust in generous nobles, in a mortal who cannot bring deliverance.
tetse rucho yashüv ləäđəmato, beeiom hähu ovəđu ëshətonotaiv׃
When his spirit departs, he will return to his earth; on that day all his designs perish.
äshərei shëel yääqov bəëzəro, sïvəro äl Adonai ëlohaiv׃
Fortunate is he whose help is the God of Jacob, whose hope focuses on God, his Lord.
osëh shameiïm vaarëts, ët heeiam vəët kal äshër bam, häshshomer ëmët ləolam׃
He makes the heaven and the earth, the sea and everything it contains; He keeps the truth of His [promise to created beings] forever.
osëh mïshəpat lääshuqim, noten lëchëm lorəevim, Adonai mätir äsurim׃
He executes judgment on behalf of the oppressed; He gives bread to the hungry; God releases the bound.
Adonai poqeäch ïvərim, Adonai zoqef kəfufim, Adonai ohev tsädiqim׃
God opens the eyes of the blind; God straightens the bent; God loves the righteous.
Adonai shomer ët gerim, yatom vəäləmanah yəođeđ, vəđërëch rəshaim yəäuet׃
God protects the strangers; He strengthens the orphan and the widow; He twists the path of the wicked.
yïməloch Adonai ləolam, ëloheiïch tsion, ləđor vađor, häləluyah׃
God will reign forever – your Lord, O Zion – from generation to generation. Praise God!
ähäləlah Adonai bəcheeiai, äzämmərah lelohei bəođi

I will praise G-d during my life; I will make music to my Lord while I exist – Our translation follows the gloss of Metzudos, et al. The Alter Rebbe, however, extends the meaning of the verse, interpreting both chyy and vđy as nouns. chyy, “my life,” he explains, refers to the soul, for the soul is essentially alive. vđ, the root of the term vvđy, translated as “while I exist,” implies something secondary, as in our Sages’ expression:229* “Once there is a [Scriptural] verse that reveals the meaning of a term, is it necessary to cite the practice in Yehudah, even as a secondary corroboration (od)? I.e., does the evidence of a Biblical verse need to be propped up by the addition of a mere custom in Yehudah?! In this context, the term refers to the body which is secondary to the soul.

Praise is usually spoken verbally. Music, by contrast, is mostly played with an instrument. Therefore the soul – a spiritual entity with no form – praises. The body, a material entity, by contrast, makes music. Similarly, the soul relates to the G-d’s name Havayah, the source for His light, while the body relates to the name Elokim, the source of the keilim, which are the source for the world’s material substance (Tanya, Shaar HaYichud; maamar Gedolim Maaseh Tzaddikim, 5685).cxxix*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - häləluya־h, ki tov
fsvqy đzmrh - Hallelukah, Ki Tov

Praise God! It is good to make music for our God, for praise [to His name] is pleasant and attractive.
boneh yərushaleiïm Adonai, nïđəchei yïsərael yəchännes׃
God is the Builder of Jerusalem; He will gather the dispersed of Israel.
harofe lïshəvurei lev, uməchäbesh ləätstsəvotam׃

gađol äđoneinu vəräv koäch, lïtəvunato ein mïsəpar׃

məođeđ änavim Adonai, mäshəpil rəshaim äđei arëts׃
God raises the spirits of the humble; He humbles the wicked down to the ground.
ënu leiya bətođah, zämməru leloheinu vəchïnnor׃
Call out to God in thanks, with a harp make music to our Lord –
häməchässëh shameiïm bəavim, hämmechin laarëts matar, hämmätsəmiäch harim chatsir׃
Who covers the heavens with clouds, Who prepares rain for the earth, Who causes grass to grow on the mountains,
noten lïvəhemah lächəmah, lïvənei orev äshër yïqərau׃

lo vïǥəvurät hässus yëchəpats, lo vəshoqei haish yïrətsëh׃

ki chïzzäq bərichei shəaraiïch, beräch baneiïch bəqïrəbech׃
For He has strengthened the bolts of your gates, and blessed your children in your midst.
häshsam gəvulech sholom, chelëv chïttim yäsəbiech׃
He has granted peace to your borders, and satiated you with the cream of the wheat.
häshsholeäch ïməroto orëts, äđ məheroh yoruts dəvoro׃
He sends His decrees earthward; His word runs swiftly.
hännoten shëlëǥ kätstsamër, kəfor kaefër yəfäzzer׃
He gives snow like fleece; He scatters frost like ashes.
mäshəlich qärəcho chəfïtim, lïfənei qarato mi yäämođ׃
He casts His ice like crumbs; who can withstand His cold?
yïshəläch dəvaro vyäməsem, yäshshev rucho yïzzəlu maiïm׃
He sends forth His word and it melts them; He causes His wind to blow and water flows.
mägiđ dəvaraiv lyääqov, chüqqaiv umïshəpataiv lyïsərael׃
He relates His word to Jacob, His statutes and judgments to Israel.
lo asah chen ləchal goi, umïshəpatim bäl yəđaum, häləluyah׃
He did not do this for other nations, nor do they know [these] judgments. Praise God!
häləluyah, ki tov

To make music to G-d – It is necessary to understand what is meant by this phrase, “To make music to G-d.” And why is the name Elokim specifically used to refer to G-d in this context?

On the earthly plane, music is both an expression of happiness and a means to evoke happiness. For example, happy people often express their joy in music. Conversely, at weddings and the like, music is played to generate joy. Similarly, in the spiritual analogue, the heavenly music created by the songs of the angels and souls is an expression of their happiness, and it arouses happiness on G-d’s part as well, as it were.

This happiness is associated with G-d’s name Elokim, which is identified with Binah. Binah refers to developed understanding: comprehending a concept in all of its length, depth, and breadth. Only when a person understands a concept in this manner — taking it beyond the abstractions of Chochmah and fully comprehending it with the power of Binah — will he feel happiness in its contemplation.

On this basis, we can understand the interactive relationship between the happiness and songs of the angels and souls, and the happiness they arouse within G-d, as it were. The happiness of the angels and souls results from their comprehension of G-d that stems from the quality of Binah. Their songs evoke happiness Above, i.e., for G-d’s name Elokim, as it were. This in turn energizes the Sefirah of Binah and thus makes it possible for the angels and souls to reach an even deeper and more comprehensive understanding of G-d (Siddur Im Dach).cxxxix*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - häləluya־h, häləlu
fsvqy đzmrh - Hallelukah, Hallelu
häləluyah, häləlu ët Adonai mïn häshshomeiïm, häləluhu bämməromim׃
Praise God! Praise God from the heavens; praise Him in the lofty heights.
häləluhu chal mäləachaiv, häləluhu kal tsəvaaiv׃
Praise Him, all His angels; praise Him, all His hosts.
häləluhu shëmësh vyareäch, häləluhu kal kochəvei or׃
Praise Him, sun and moon; praise Him, all the stars that shine.
häləluhu shəmei häshshomaiïm, vəhämmeiïm äshër meäl häshshomaiïm׃
Praise Him, the loftiest of the heavens, and the waters that are above the heavens.
yəhäləlu ët shem Adonai, ki hu tsïvah vənïvərau׃
Let them praise the name of God, because He commanded, and they were created.
veeiäämiđem laäđ ləolam, chaq natän vəlo yäävor׃
He established them forever, for all time; He laid down a statute, and it shall not be contravened.
häləlu ët Adonai mïn haarëts, tänninim vəchal təhomot׃
Praise God from the earth, the sea-serpents and all [the creatures of] the watery depths.
esh uvarađ shëlëǥ vəqitor, ruäch səarah osah đəvaro׃
Fire and hail, snow and steam, the stormy wind that carries out His command;
hëharim vəchal gəvaot, ets pəri vəchal ärazim׃
