mountains and all the hills, fruit trees and all cedars;
hächeeiah vəchal bəhemah, rëmës vətsïpor kanaf׃
wild beasts and all domesticated animals, crawling creatures and winged fowl;
mäləchei ërëts vəchal ləümmim, sarim vəchal shofətei arëts׃
the kings of the earth and all nations; nobles and all the judges of the land;
bächurim vəǥäm bətulot, zəqenim ïm nəarim׃
young men and maidens, elders with youth; –
yəhäləlu ët shem Adonai, ki nïsəgav shəmo ləvädo, hođo äl ërëts vəshamaiïm׃
let them all praise the name of God, for His name is exalted alone. His glory is upon the earth and heaven.
veeiarëm qërën ləämmo, təhïllah ləchal chäsiđaiv, lïvənei yïsərael äm qərovo, häləluyah׃
He raised a standard for His nation, [generating] praise for all His pious ones – for the Children of Israel, the people close to Him. Praise God!
häləluyah

Praise G-d from the heavens – As explained previously, hallel, praise, refers to the shining forth of G-d’s infinite light.

“The heavens” refer to G-d’s emotional attributes which combine Chessed (“kindness”) and Gevurah (“might”). This is alluded to by the Hebrew term for heavens, shmym, which our Sages understand as a composite of the terms sh (fire) and mym (water), which are analogies for these two emotional qualities. Praising G-d causes light to shine forth from His limitless Essence. For that light to be drawn down into this limited world, it must flow through the filter of the heavens: G-d’s emotional qualities.

For that to happen, the emotional qualities must themselves become batel to G-d’s Essence, for their bittul enables them to become fit vessels to receive His light, in keeping with the saying of our Sages,247* “an empty vessel is able to contain….” Their bittul is necessary, because G-d is utterly above these emotional qualities and it is only through their bittul that they become fit receptacles for His light. Moreover, it is their bittul that evokes the flow of Divine light to them (Siddur Im Dach).clv*

This psalm raises a fundamental question: When speaking of praising G-d, it uses the name Havayah, which, as frequently explained, refers to the infinite G-dly light that transcends the Spiritual Cosmos.

Who is it that will be praising Havayah? As the psalm continues: “Wild beasts and all domesticated animals,” and all the created beings of this material world. Their existence derives from the name Elokim (-lhym), which is numerically equivalent to nature (htv). How is it possible for created beings – whose existence is defined by the limited framework of nature – to praise Havayah, Who is entirely above that framework?

The resolution is dependent on the verse:248* “And you shall know today and take it to heart that Havayah is Elokim.” True, in order to bring about our world, the name Elokim functions as a shield, limiting the expression of the name Havayah. Nevertheless, the ultimate intent of the name Elokim is to bring the revelation of the name Havayah to a lower level, enabling even the created beings that derive from the name Elokim to become conscious of G-d’s infinity and praise Him (Toras Chayim; Toras Menachem).clvi*

Our Sages249* consider this psalm as the fundamental prayer of Pesukei D’Zimra. Among the explanations for this distinction is that it includes a collective expression of the entire creation’s praise of G-d. All existence – spiritual and material – joins in praising Him.

As the AriZal explains, the psalm begins by describing the downward flow of Divine energy: “Praise G-d from the heavens” refers to the world of Atzilus,250* “Praise Him in the lofty heights” refers to the world of Beriah;251* “Praise Him, all His angels,” to the world of Yetzirah;252* and “Praise Him, all His hosts,” to the world of Asiyah.253*

After mentioning the process of drawing down G-d’s light into the worlds, the psalm alludes to a process of elevation, in which each realm becomes included in the realm above it. “Praise Him, sun and moon” reflects how Asiyah is included in Yetzirah.254* “Praise Him, all the stars that shine” indicates Yetzirah being included in Beriah. “Praise Him, the loftiest of heavens,” Beriah being included in Atzilus, and “the waters that are above the heavens,” Atzilus being included in the very source of G-d’s light.

Afterwards, the psalm proceeds to describe how this praise is echoed by the four elements: the element of “Fire”; “hail, snow, and steam,” the element of Water; “the stormy wind that carries out His command,” the element of Wind; and “mountains and all the hills,” the element of Earth.

This motif continues, embracing all four types of existence, for “mountains and all the hills,” refers to inanimate existence (domeim), “fruit trees, and all cedars,” to the plant kingdom (tzomei’ach), “wild beasts, and all cattle; crawling creatures, and winged fowl,” to the animal kingdom (chai), and “kings of the earth, and all peoples…” to humans (medaber). The psalm concludes with the exclamation that although the praise of G-d reverberates through all existence, nevertheless, “He championed the cause of His nation… the children of Israel, the people close to Him,” for their service of Him is of an entirely different level (Toras Shmuel).clvii*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - häləluya־h, shiru
fsvqy đzmrh - Hallelukah, Shiru
häləluyah, shiru leiya shir chađash, təhïllato bïqəhäl chäsiđim׃
Halleluyah! Sing a new song to God; His praise [will be related] in the congregation of the pious.
yïsəmäch yïsərael bəosaiv, bənei tsion yaǥilu vəmäləkam׃
Let Israel rejoice in its Maker; let the children of Zion delight in their King.
yəhäləlu shəmo vəmachol, bətof vəchïnnor yəzämməru lo׃
Let them praise His name with the flute; let them play music to Him with the drum and the harp.
ki rotsëh Adonai bəämmo, yəfaer änavim bishuah׃
For God favors His people; He adorns the humble with salvation.
yäələzu chäsiđim bəchavođ, yərännənu äl mïshəkəvotam׃
The pious will celebrate with [this] honor; they will sing joyously on their beds.
roməmot el bïǥəronam, vəchërëv pifiot byađam׃
The exaltation of God is in their throats and a double-edged sword is in their hand –
lääsot nəqamah vägoiïm, tochechot bäləümmim׃
to bring vengeance upon the nations, to inflict punishment upon the peoples,
lëəsor mäləcheihëm bəzïqqim, vənïchəbəđeihëm bəchävəlei värəzël׃
to bind their kings in chains, and their honored ones in iron fetters,
lääsot bahëm mïshəpat katuv, hađar hu ləchal chäsiđaiv, häləluyah׃
to execute the prescribed judgment against them – [thus bringing] glory to all His pious ones. Halleluyah!
häləluyah

Sing a new song (shir chadash) to G-d – Our Sages260* distinguish between shyr, the masculine form of the word “song,” and shyrh, the feminine form. In general, the concept of song represents a process of ascent, enabling the singer to rise above his individual limitations.261* This is the intent of the Scriptural verses that describe the angels as “singing.” Obviously, the song of the angels is not singing as we know it. Instead, just as on the physical plane song uplifts a person’s spirits and enables him to rise above his ordinary mindset, so too, the song of the angels reflects – and enables – their ascent to higher spiritual levels.

According to Kabbalah, the ascent of the angels and thus their “song” is brought about by the Sefirah of Malchus. Malchus descends from the oneness of the realm of Atzilus and enclothes itself in the lower realms of Beriah, Yetzirah, and Asiyah, where separation exists, to enable these lower realms to ascend. Moreover, the ascent of the angels also elevates the realm of material existence that derives from them.

Now, within the Sefiros of Atzilus, Malchus functions as a recipient, a vessel for the influence granted by the higher Sefiros. Therefore it is associated with the feminine dimension. Accordingly, the ascent, i.e., the song, prompted by Malchus is referred to as shyrh, using the feminine form of the word. That very term reflects the connection of song to Malchus, for shyrh can be divided as shyr h, the song of the letter h. And, as is well known, the lower h of G-d’s Divine name y-h-v-h is identified with the Sefirah of Malchus.

The association of song with the cycle of ascent and descent described above applies in the present era. In the Ultimate Future, by contrast, the entire task of refining the world’s material substance will have been completed, for then “the spirit of impurity will be swallowed up forever.”262* Hence, the ascents will be of a different nature entirely. This is the implication of the term shir chadash, “a new song.” The song will be “new,” resulting from a new degree of light that will not have been revealed until that time. And it will be male in nature, i.e., an expression of G-d’s potential to convey influence.

Although this potential will not be fully revealed until the Ultimate Future, a foretaste of this level is revealed to us in microcosm on Shabbos. Therefore in the Kabbalas Shabbos prayers we say, “Sing a new song to G-d” (Siddur Im Dach; Toras Menachem).clxv*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - häləluya־h, häləlu e־l bəqođəsho
fsvqy đzmrh - Hallelukah, Hallelu Keil Bekadsho
häləluyah, häləlu el bəqođəsho, häləluhu bïrəqiä üzzo׃
Praise God! Praise God in His holy place; praise Him in the firmament where His power [is manifest].
häləluhu bïǥəvurotaiv, häləluhu kərov güđəlo׃
Praise Him by [relating] His mighty acts; praise Him according to His abundant greatness.
häləluhu bəteqä shofar, häləluhu bənevël vəchïnnor׃
Praise Him by sounding the shofar; praise Him with a nevel and a harp.
häləluhu bətof umachol, häləluhu bəmïnnim vəüǥav׃
Praise Him with a drum and a flute; Praise Him with an organ and a pipe.
häləluhu bətsïlətsəlei shamä, häləluhu bətsïlətsəlei təruah׃
Praise Him with resounding cymbals, praise Him with resounding trumpets.
kol hännəshamah təhällel yah häləluyah׃
Let every soul praise God; Praise God!
kol hännəshamah təhällel yah häləluyah׃
Let every soul praise God; Praise God!
häləluyah, häləlu el bəqođəsho, häləluhu bïrəqiä üzzo

Praise G-d in His holiness; Praise Him in the firmament where His power [is manifest]. Praise Him by [relating] His mighty acts – “His holiness” refers to a dimension of G-dliness that is “lofty and holy,”274* above any connection to the influence revealed within the lower realms. This dimension is described as “a consuming fire.”275*

“The firmament where His power [is manifest]” refers to the many veils that hide and conceal the revelation of G-dliness, one concealment after another. This clause points to the first step in drawing down G-dly influence toward the material world: that the influence be enclothed in veils which are necessary for it to enter the realm of limited existence.

“His mighty acts” refer to the contractions276* that take place after G-d’s infinite light is concealed and enclothed in several types of garments and levels. This enables the light and vitality to be drawn down in a reduced manner, so that it can provide vitality for all the worlds, the higher and the lower realms277* (Likkutei Torah).clxxix*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - baruch h׳ ləolam
fsvqy đzmrh - Baruch Hashem Leolam
baruch Adonai ləolam, amen vəamen׃
Blessed is God forever; Amen and Amen.
baruch Adonai mïtstsion shochen yərushalaiïm, häləluyah׃
Blessed is God from Zion, Who dwells in Jerusalem, Praise God!
baruch Adonai ëlohim ëlohei yïsərael, oseh nïfəlaot ləvädo׃
Blessed is God, the Lord, the Lord of Israel, Who alone performs wonders.
uvaruch shem kəvođo ləolam, vyïmmale chəvođo ët kal haarëts, amen vəamen׃
Blessed is His glorious name forever; may His glory fill the entire earth; Amen and Amen.
veiəvarëch daviđ ët Adonai ləeinei kal häqqahal, veeiomër daviđ, baruch ätah Adonai ëlohei yïsərael avinu, meolam vəäđ olam׃
And David blessed God in the presence of the entire assembly, and David said: “Blessed are You, God, the Lord of our father Israel, from this world until the World to Come.
ləcha Adonai hägəđüllah, vəhägəvurah, vəhätïfəërët, vəhännetsäch, vəhähođ, ki chol bäshshomeiïm uvaorëts, ləcha Adonai hämmäməlachah vəhämmïtənäshse ləchol lərosh׃
The greatness, the might, the splendor, the victory, and the glory [that I have been granted] are all Yours, for everything in heaven and on earth [is Yours]. Kingship and the rule of all leaders [derives from] You.
vəhaoshër vəhäkavođ mïlləfaneicha, vəätah moshel bäkol, uvyođəcha, koäch uǥəvurah, uvyođəcha, ləǥädel uləchäzzeq läkol׃
Wealth and honor come from You, and You rule over all; in Your hand are strength and might; and it is in Your hand to grant anyone greatness and strength.
vəätah ëloheinu, mođim änächənu lach, uməhäləlim ləshem tïfəärətëcha׃
And now, our God, we thankfully acknowledge You and praise Your splendid name.
vivorəchu shem kəvođëcha, uməromäm äl kal bərachah utəhïllah׃
Let [Israel] bless Your glorious name, for You are exalted above all blessing and praise.
ätah hu Adonai ləvädëcha, ätah asita ët häshshomeiïm, shəmei häshshomeiïm, vəchol tsəvaam, haorëts vəchol äshër oleiha, heiämmim vəchal äshër bahëm, vəätah məcheeiëh ët küllam, utsəva häshshomeiïm ləcha mïshətächävim׃
You alone are God; You made the heavens and the highest celestial heights and all their hosts, the earth and everything that is upon it, the seas and everything within them. You grant life to them all, and the heavenly legions bow down before You.
ätah hu Adonai haëlohim, äshër bachärəta bəävəram, vəhotseto meur käsədim, vəsäməta shəmo ävəraham׃
You are God the Lord Who chose Avram, and brought him out from Ur of the Chaldees, and named him Abraham.
umatsata ët ləvavo nëëman ləfaneicha
And You found his heart faithful before You –
baruch Adonai ëlohim ëlohei yïsərael

…Who alone performs wonders –Often G-d performs wonders, but it is He alone Who perceives their wondrous nature. The person to whom the miracle occurred, by contrast, does not recognize that anything miraculous transpired. In particular, this pattern of Divine conduct prevails in the era of exile when G-d’s providence is not overtly apparent, despite the fact that He controls every dimension of existence.

Perhaps the area where this motif is most evident is in the challenges related to earning a livelihood. G-d controls every aspect of a person’s income. At the same time, the workings of His hand are not evident, and it appears that our livelihoods are dependent on the chance occurrences of the natural order (Kesser Shem Tov; Torah Or; Toras Menachem).clxxxviii*

G-d’s self-concealment that prevents man from perceiving His wonders is a sign of His ultimate greatness. To cite a parallel: it is a uniquely wise man who can explain an idea even to a person of little understanding, coding the concept in terms which the simple person can understand. Because he grasps the essence of the idea, he can clothe it in an endless variety of forms and levels. Similarly, this verse praises G-d for enclothing His light within myriad levels of existence, even those in which He will not be recognized at all (Siddur Im Dach).clxxxix*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - vəcharot ïmmo häbərit
fsvqy đzmrh - Vecharot Imo Habrit
vəcharot ïmmo häbərit, latet ët ërëts häkənääni hächïti haëmori vəhäpərïzzi vəheiəvusi vəhägïrəgashi latet ləzärəo, vätaqëm ët dəvareicha ki tsädiq atah׃
– to establish the covenant with him to give him the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizites, the Jebusites and the Girgashites, to give it to his descendants, and You upheld Your word, for You are righteous.
väterë ët ani ävoteinu bəmïtsəraiïm, vəët zääqatam shamäəta äl yäm suf׃
And You saw the oppression of our ancestors in Egypt, and You heard their outcry at the Sea of Reeds.
vätïten otot umofətim bəfärəoh uvəchal ävađaiv uvəchal äm ärətso, ki yađäəta ki heziđu äleihëm, vätääs ləcha shem kəheeiom häzzëh׃
And You performed signs and wonders against Pharaoh and all his servants and all the people of his land, for You knew that they had acted wickedly toward [our forefathers]. [In doing so,] You brought Yourself renown [that continues] until the present day.
vəheeiam baqäəta lïfəneihëm veeiäävəru vətoch heeiam beeiäbashah, vəët rođəfeihëm hïshəlächəta vïmətsolot, kəmo ëvën bəmeiïm äzzim׃
You split the sea before them, and they passed through the sea on dry land, and You thrust their pursuers into the depths like a stone in fierce waters.
vəcharot ïmmo häbərit

…to establish the covenant with him – In G-d’s covenant with Avraham, Bris Bein HaBesarim, He commanded Avraham to cut several animals in half and place the halves opposite each other. Avraham and a heavenly fire (representative of G-d’s Presence) then passed between the halves.

What is the implication of passing between the halves? That the two parties who passed between them share a common identity. They are not separate entities, but two parts of a single whole. In that vein, the Maggid of Mezritch would interpret the term bechatzotzros266* as beis chatza’ei tzuros (two half-forms) – that alone, both the Jews and G-d are merely halves, as it were, and only through their joining together do they attain fulfillment (Or HaTorah).cxciv*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - veeioshä h׳
fsvqy đzmrh - Vayosha Hashem
veeioshä Adonai beeiom hähu ët yïsərael miäđ mïtsəraiïm, veeiärə yïsərael ët mïtsəreiïm met äl səfät heeiam׃
And God delivered Israel from the hand of the Egyptians on that day, and Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the shore of the sea.
veeiärə yïsərael ët heeiađ hägəđolah äshër asah Adonai bəmïtsəreiïm, veeiirəu haam ët Adonai, veeiääminu beiya uvəmoshëh ävədo׃
Israel saw the mighty hand that God had wielded against the Egyptians, and the people feared God, and they believed in God and in Moses, His servant.
veeioshä Adonai beeiom hähu ët yïsərael miäđ mïtsəraiïm

And then Israel saw…. The people feared… and they believed – Fear and sight employ the same root letters. Seeing the revelation of G-dliness caused the people to respond in fear, just like seeing a great man evokes fear and shame on the part of a person of lesser stature. From this awareness, the people proceeded to a higher level, emunah, faith. For faith reflects a connection to a level of G-dliness that cannot be seen or even comprehended intellectually. Rather, it relates to G-d in His utter transcendence (Or HaTorah).ccxiv*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - az yashir moshëh
fsvqy đzmrh - Az Yashir Moshe
az yashir moshëh uvənei yïsərael ët häshshiroh häzzot leiya veeioməru lemor, ashirah leiya ki ǥaoh gaah, sus vərochəvo ramah veeiam׃
Then Moses and the Children of Israel sang this song to God. They declared responsively: I will sing to God for He is exceedingly exalted; He has cast the horse and its rider into the sea.
ozzi vəzïmərat yah veiəhi li lishuah, zëh eli vəänəvehu, ëlohei avi vääroməmënəhu׃
The might and the vengeance of God became my salvation. This is my God, and I will make a dwelling for Him, the God of my father and I will exalt Him.
Adonai ish mïləchamah, Adonai shəmo׃
God is a Master of war; God is His name.
märəkəvot pärəoh vəcheilo yarah veeiam, umïvəchär shalïshaiv tübəu vyäm suf׃
He cast Pharaoh’s chariots and forces into the sea; his chosen officers were drowned in the Sea of Reeds.
təhomot yəchäsyümu, yorəđu vïmətsolot kəmo avën׃
The watery depths covered them; they fell to the depths like a stone.
yəminəcha Adonai nëədari bäkoäch, yəminəcha Adonai tïrəäts oiev׃
Your right hand, O God, is glorified with power; Your right hand, O God, shatters the enemy.
uvərov gəonəcha tähäros qameicha, təshälläch chäronəcha yochəlemo käqqäsh׃
In Your abundant grandeur, You destroy those who rise against You; You send forth Your rage; it consumes them like straw.
uvəruäch äpeicha nëërəmu meiïm, nïtstsəvu chəmo neđ nozəlim, qofəu təhomot bəlëv yam׃
By the breath of Your nostrils the waters piled up; the flowing waters stood upright like a wall; the deep waters congealed in the heart of the sea.
amär oiev, ërədof äshsiǥ ächälleq shalal, tïməlaemo näfəshi, ariq chärəbi, torishemo yađi׃
The enemy said: “I will pursue; I will overtake; I will divide the booty; my desire will be fulfilled with them; I will unsheathe my sword; my hand will obliterate them.”
nashäfəta vəruchächa kïssamo yam, tsalälu käofërët bəmeiïm ädirim׃
You blew with Your wind and the sea covered them; they sank like lead in the mighty waters.
mi chamochah baelïm Adonai, mi kamochah nëədar bäqqođësh, nora təhïllot, oseh fëlë׃
Who is like You among the mighty, O God! Who is like You, glorified in holiness, awesome in praise, working wonders!
natita yəminəcha, tïvəlaemo arëts׃
You stretched out Your right hand, the earth swallowed them.
nachita vəchäsədəcha äm zu gaoləta, nehäləta vəozzəcha ël nəveh qođəshëcha׃
In Your kindness, You led this people whom You redeemed; You guided them with Your strength to Your holy dwelling.
shoməu ämmim yïrəgazun, chil achäz yoshəvei pəlashët׃
The nations heard and were agitated; a shudder gripped the inhabitants of Philistia.
az nïvəhälu ällufei ëđom, eilei moav yochäzemo raäđ, namoǥu kol yoshəvei chənaän׃
The lords of Edom were terrified; the mighty men of Mo’av were gripped by trembling; all the inhabitants of Canaan melted away.
tïpol äleihëm eimatah vafächäđ, bïǥəđol zəroächa yïdəmu kaavën, äđ yäävor ämməcha Adonai, äđ yäävor äm zu qanita׃
May dread and fear fall upon them; By the greatness of Your arm they fell silent, like a stone – until Your nation crosses, O God; until this nation You acquired crosses over.
təvïemo vətïttaemo bəhär nächälotəcha, machon ləshïvətəcha paäləta Adonai, mïqqəđash, äđonai, konənu yađeicha׃
You will bring them and plant them on the mountain of Your inheritance, the place that You, O God, established for Your dwelling, the Sanctuary that Your hands, O God, made.
Adonai yïməloch ləolam vaëđ׃
God will reign forever and ever.
Adonai yïməloch ləolam vaëđ׃
God will reign forever and ever.
Adonai mäləchuteh qaem ləaläm uləoləmei oləmeeia׃
The kingdom of God endures forever and ever.
ki va sus pärəoh bərïchəbo uvəfarashaiv beeiam veeiashëv Adonai älehëm ët mei heeiam, uvənei yïsərael holəchu veeiäbashah bətoch heeiam׃
When Pharaoh’s horses with his chariots and riders entered the sea, God turned the waters of the sea back upon them, while the Children of Israel walked on dry land in the midst of the sea.
ki leiya hämməluchah umoshel bägoiïm׃
For sovereignty is God’s; He rules over the nations.
vəalu moshiim bəhär tsion lïshəpot ët här esav, vəhaiətah leiya hämməluchah׃
And deliverers will ascend to Mount Zion to judge the mountain of Esau, and sovereignty will be God’s.
vəhaiah Adonai ləmëlëch äl kal haarëts, beeiom hähu yïhyëh Adonai ëchađ ushəmo ëchađ׃
And God will be King over the entire earth; on that day, God will be one and His name, one.
az yashir moshëh uvənei yïsərael

Then Moses and the Children of Israel sang – Moses reflects Daas Elyon, the sublime Daas,311* i.e., viewing existence from G-d’s perspective, as it were. In truth, this potential exists within every Jew. In Moses’ instance, it governed his consciousness. The people at large, by contrast, were not on that level and this level of awareness remained in their subconscious. Nevertheless, after passing through the sea – i.e., being exposed to the transcendent dimensions of G-dliness – their external dimensions fused with their inner dimensions and they were able to sing together with Moses; i.e., they were elevated to this higher level – the level of his mindset (Or HaTorah).ccxv*

The question may be raised:312* Why is Moses’ song of praise recited after David’s313* in the order of the prayers in the Siddur? Seemingly, Moses’ deserves precedence, since Moses’ song is found in the Torah while David’s is from the Book of Tehillim. In resolution, it can be explained that David’s praises relate fundamentally to the greatness of G-d manifest in Creation, while Moses’ refer to the special relationship established between G-d and the Jewish people. First, we praise the external dimensions of G-d’s bond with Creation. We then proceed to highlight the inner bond G-d established with the Jewish people through the Exodus and the Giving of the Torah (Or HaTorah).ccxvi*
Siddur: Verses of Praise - yïshətäbäch
fsvqy đzmrh - Yishtabach
yïshətäbäch shïməcha laäđ mäləkenu, hael, hämmëlëch hägađol vəhäqqađosh bäshshomeiïm uvaorëts.
May Your name be praised forever our King, the Almighty, the great and holy King in heaven and on earth.
ki ləcha naëh Adonai ëloheinu velohei ävoteinu ləolam vaëđ׃
For to You, O God, our Lord and Lord of our forefathers, it is fitting [that we offer] forever,
shir ushəvachah, hällel vəzïmərah, oz umëməshalah, nëtsäch, gəđüllah uǥəvurah, təhïllah vətïfəërët, qəđüshshoh umäləchut׃
song and acclaim, praise, and music, strength and dominion, timelessness, greatness, might, adulation, splendor, holiness and kingship,
bərachot vəhođaot ləshïməcha hägađol vəhäqqađosh, umeolam äđ olam ätah el.
blessing and thanksgiving to Your great and holy name. From this world unto the World to Come, You are the Almighty.
baruch ätah Adonai, el mëlëch gađol uməhüllal bätïshəbachot, el hähođaot, äđon hännïfəlaot, bore kal hännəshamot, rïbon kal hämmääsim, häbocher bəshirei zïmərah, mëlëch yachiđ chei haolamim׃
Blessed are You, God, Almighty and great King, exalted with praise, the God [to Whom] thanksgiving [is due], the Master of wonders, the Creator of all the souls, the Master of all deeds, Who takes pleasure in songs of praise, the Unique King, Who gives Life to the worlds.
yïshətäbäch shïməcha laäđ mäləkenu

May Your name be praised forever our King… – This passage is the conclusion and thus the summation of the Pesukei D’Zimra prayers. By using the terms “Your name” and “our King,” it highlights the realization that our vitality and our very existence stems only from the dimension of His light projected forth to others. For a person needs a name only in order to be able to relate to others; as he exists for himself, he has no need for a name.

Similarly, a true Jewish king must be on a loftier level than his subjects, and ruling over them represents a descent for him. In that vein, Scripture describes323* Shaul, Israel’s first king, as “from his shoulders upwards, taller than any of the people.” Chassidic thought explains that this is not merely a description of his physical stature. Spiritually, as well, he was on a higher plane than the general populace.

Thus, saying that Creation derives from G-d’s kingship implies that it is removed from His Essence, because how He exists for Himself transcends our frame of reference entirely.

Nevertheless, although G-d’s name and kingship are removed from His Essence, G-d’s name and His kingship are linked with the term “forever,” i.e., an aspect of eternity. For even His name and His kingship are unbounded, for they are the radiance of His infinite light.

In this manner, Malchus serves as an intermediary, enabling G-d’s infinite dimension to be drawn down into limited existence (Torah Or; Toras Chayim).ccxxx*

shvch, the root of the term Yishtabach, translated as “be praised,” also means “improve.” With this prayer, we are asking that G-d’s name be “improved,” i.e., that His infinite dimension be infused into His name or, alternatively, that His name be elevated and subsumed within G-d’s essential light.

To explain: “His name” is an analogy used to refer to Malchus of Atzilus, the source of the light and energy with which He maintains our existence. Since Malchus is the medium through which our world is maintained, it possesses a certain aspect of limitation itself. When Malchus is brought into contact with G-d’s infinite light — through either the infusion of His infinite dimension into His name, or Malchus being subsumed into G-d’s essential light — it endows our world with an aspect of eternity, enabling it to continue “forever” (Torah Or; Likkutei Torah; Toras Chayim).ccxxxi*
Siddur: Blessings Of The Shema - yotser or
vrchvt shm - Yotzeir Or
baruch ätah Adonai, ëloheinu mëlëch haolam, yotser or uvore choshëch, osëh shalom uvore ët häkol׃
Blessed are You God, our Lord, King of the universe, Who forms light and creates darkness, Who makes peace and creates all things,
baruch ätah Adonai

Blessed are You, G-d… – This portion of the prayer service is referred to as Birkas Kerias Shema, the blessings for the reading of the Shema.328* Although the content of these blessings does not directly relate to the Shema, our Rabbis termed them Birkas Kerias Shema, since these blessings prepare us for its recitation.

In the Shema, we state the command to “love G-d with all your heart, with all your soul, and with all your might,” to the point of sacrificing everything – even our very lives – for Him. Now, how can this be expected of mortal man, mere flesh and blood fraught with material concerns?

For this reason, we introduce the Shema with these two blessings. When taken to heart, the themes of these blessings – among them: G-d’s continuous renewal of creation, the angels’ sublime service, their bittul to Him, and the unique love relationship He shares with the Jewish people – will motivate a person to respond to G-d with an all-encompassing love (Tanya).ccxxxviii*
Siddur: Blessings Of The Shema - hämmeir laarëts
vrchvt shm - Hameir Laaretz
hämmeir laarëts vəlädarim aleiha bərächämim,
Who mercifully shines light to the earth and those who dwell upon it.
uvətuvo məchädesh bəchal yom tamiđ määseh vəreshit.
In His goodness, He renews the work of creation every day, continuously.
mah räbu määseicha Adonai, küllam bəchochəmah asita, moləah haarëts qïnyanëcha׃
How manifold are Your works O God! You have made them all with wisdom; the earth is filled with Your possessions.
hämmëlëch häməromam ləvädo meaz, häməshübach, vəhäməfoar, vəhämmïtənäshse mimot olam.
[You are] the King Who alone is exalted from the beginning of time, Who is praised, glorified, and upraised from the beginning of creation.
ëlohei olam, bərächämeicha haräbim rächem aleinu, äđon üzzenu, tsur mïsəgäbenu, maǥen yïshəenu, mïsəgav bääđenu.
God of the universe, in Your abundant mercies, have mercy upon us, [for You are] the Master of our strength, Rock of our refuge, Shield of our salvation, a Refuge for us.
el baruch, gəđol deah, hechin ufaäl zaharei chämmah,
The blessed God, great in understanding, prepared and brought about the rays of the sun.
tov yatsär kavođ lïshəmo, məorot natän səvivot üzzo,
The Generous One created glory for His name. He placed luminaries around His power.
pïnnot tsəvaaiv qəđoshim, roməmei shädei, tamiđ məsäpərim kəvođ el uqəđüshshoto.
The chieftains of His hosts are holy beings, who exalt the Omnipotent, continuously relating the glory of God and His holiness.
tïtəbarech Adonai ëloheinu bäshshomeiïm mïmmääl vəäl haarëts mïtachät, äl kal shëväch määseh yađeicha, vəäl məorei or sheeiatsärəta, yəfaärucha sëlah׃
Be blessed, God our Lord, in heaven above and on the earth below, for all of Your praiseworthy handiwork, and for the shining luminaries that You have formed. May they glorify You forever.
uvətuvo məchädesh bəchal yom tamiđ määseh vəreshit

In His goodness, He renews the work of creation every day – Since the creation is brought about yesh me’ayin, i.e., existence comes into being from absolute nothingness, it must continually be renewed. As explained at great length in Tanya, Shaar HaYichud VehaEmunah, since the fundamental state of created existence is non-being – i.e., were it not to have been created it never would have existed – its existence runs contrary to its natural state. Hence, the creative force that brings existence into being must be present within the creation at all times to constantly renew it. This continual renewal is diametrically opposed to the natural state of non-being. What then causes this renewal? G-d’s essential and boundless goodness (Toras Menachem).ccxliii*

Although the renewal is continuous, at every moment, we still mention it as taking place every day, because it is in the morning – with the shining of the sun and our awakening from sleep – that we become consciously aware of this process of renewal341* (Toras Shmuel).ccxliv*

The concept that creation must be continually renewed enables us to understand the connection between the main body of the blessing – which relates the angels’ praise of G-d – with its beginning, our praise of Him as Creator. In order for the creation to be renewed, there must be an arousal from below, an expression of bittul on the part of the created beings, which calls forth His creative energy. This bittul is achieved through the songs of praise recited by the angels in the spiritual realms and the Jewish people on this material plane (Toras Shmuel).ccxlv*

G-d’s “goodness” refers to the light brought into being on the first day of Creation, of which it is said:342* “And G-d saw the light and it was good.” Now, our Sages343* interpret that verse as implying that the goodness of this light was too powerful to be revealed in the world in its present gestalt and therefore G-d hid it away until the Ultimate Future. Nevertheless, even as the light is hidden from us, it is with its power that G-d renews creation. Implied is that each day the renewal of creation provides us with a glimmer of the Ultimate Future (Or HaTorah).

Our Rabbis ask: “Where did He hide away this light?” and respond “In the Torah.” One can extrapolate that through Torah study, one draws a deeper measure of light into the renewal of creation (Or HaTorah).ccxlvi*
Siddur: Blessings Of The Shema - tïtəbarech lanëtsäch
vrchvt shm - Titbareich Lanetzach
tïtəbarech lanëtsäch tsurenu mäləkenu vəǥoälenu bore qəđoshim, yïshətäbäch shïməcha laäđ
Be blessed for eternity, our Rock, our King and our Redeemer, the Creator of holy beings. May Your name be praised forever,
mäləkenu yotser məshorətim, vääshër məshorətaiv, küllam oməđim bərum olam,
our King, Who creates ministering angels, and Whose ministering angels all stand in the lofty heights of the universe
umäshəmiim byïrəah yächäđ bəqol, dïvərei ëlohim cheeiim umëlëch olam.
and loudly proclaim in awe together the words of the living God, the eternal King.
küllam ähuvim, küllam bərurim, küllam gïborim, küllam qəđoshim,
All of them are beloved, all are pure, all are mighty, all are holy.
vəchüllam osim bəeimah uvyïrəah rətson qonam.
All carry out the will of their Creator with dread and awe.
vəchüllam potəchim ët pihëm bïqəđüshshoh uvətoharoh, bəshiroh uvəzïməroh,
All of them open their mouths in holiness and purity, with song and music,
uməvorəchim uməshäbəchim, uməfaärim umääritsim,
and bless, praise, glorify, extol,
umäqədishim umäməlichim׃ ët shem hael,
sanctify and ascribe kingship to the name of the Almighty,
hämmëlëch hägađol, hägïbor vəhännora, qađosh hu.
the great, powerful and awesome King, Who is holy.
vəchüllam məqäbəlim äleihëm ol mäləchut shameiïm zëh mïzzëh,
They all accept upon themselves the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven, one from another
vənotənim bəähävah rəshut zëh lazëh,
and they all lovingly grant permission to each other
ləhäqədish lyotsəram bənächät ruäch, bəsafah vərurah uvïnəimah qəđoshah.
to sanctify their Maker with a gracious spirit, with refined speech and with a sacred melody;
küllam kəëchađ onim bəeimah vəomərim byïrəah׃
together they all exclaim with dread and declare in awe:
tïtəbarech lanëtsäch tsurenu mäləkenu vəǥoälenu

The Creator of holy beings; may Your name be praised forever – The term “holy beings” refers to the angels and the souls of the Jewish people as they exist in the spiritual realms. They relate only to “Your name,” which is a mere ray and a radiance of G-d’s Essence. They are, nevertheless, on a higher level than “Your handiwork,” which, as mentioned above, refers to the external357* dimensions of the worlds, the heavens and the earth and the other physical creations.

The difference between the two – the spiritual beings and the material ones – can be understood by way of analogy: Once man’s power of deed has been invested in a particular article or aspect of his handiwork, the power invested in the article no longer has any connection with the person who made it. It has become separate and distinct from him. Therefore, holding – even firmly clutching – the article in which the power of man’s deed had been invested does not draw down the essence of the person who fashioned it. In contrast, when a person is called by his name, his essence is drawn out. For though a name is but a ray and radiance, it affects the essence of the soul and remains connected and united with it.

Similarly, in the analogue, G-d’s “handiwork,” the external dimensions of the world, appear as if they no longer share any connection to Him. In contrast, the “holy beings,” the angels and the souls of the Jewish people,358* recognize G-d’s creative energy and therefore praise Him. Nevertheless, even as they praise Him, they are only relating to “His name,” which as above is but a ray of G-d’s Essence. G-d’s Essence is lofty and exalted, above their comprehension entirely (Torah Or; Toras Shmuel).cclxiv*

Like the other prayers, the blessing Yotzer Or was instituted by the Men of the Great Assembly after the Babylonian exile. After the destruction of the Temple, our ability to relate to G-dliness in a direct manner was greatly reduced. The revelation of G-dliness was contracted and diminished, and conveyed only through the medium of the angels.359* Accordingly, from this point in time onward, man could rouse himself to love and fear G-d only through first contemplating the love and fear of G-d possessed by the angels. For this reason, such an extensive description of their love and fear of G-d is included in this blessing (Toras Shmuel).cclxv*
Siddur: Blessings Of The Shema - qađosh | qađosh qađosh
vrchvt shm - Kadosh Kadosh Kadosh
qađosh | qađosh qađosh Adonai tsəvaot, məlo chal haarëts kəvođo׃
Holy, holy, holy is the God of hosts; the entire earth is filled with His glory.
qađosh | qađosh qađosh

Holy, holy, holy is G-d, Commander of legions – Kadosh, “holy,” is defined as “separate” and “apart.” With this statement, the angels proclaim their awareness that even as G-d creates and maintains the worlds, He remains apart from them. His relationship to them does not resemble the relationship of the soul to the body. The soul is affected by the body when it enlivens it. By contrast, even as G-d enclothes Himself in every aspect of creation and provides it with life, He Himself remains unchanged and unaffected.

As evidenced by their call, “Holy,…” the seraphim, the angels of the world of Beriah, perceive G-d’s separation and therefore feel a tremendous yearning to bond with Him. Indeed, this yearning is so powerful and permeates their consciousness so thoroughly that they are consumed with a fiery love for G-d. This is the literal meaning of the term seraphim, “those who are burned up,” i.e., consumed by their love for Him (Likkutei Torah; Toras Menachem).cclxxv*

While these angels stand in the heavens and contemplate G-dliness, they proclaim Kadosh, that G-d is holy, separate and removed from them. When, however, they are sent on a mission to fulfill G-d’s will, they are identified with Him to the point that they are referred to with His name.365*

This point is significant, not as an abstract analysis of the angels’ spiritual standing, but as a directive to be applied in our own Divine service. We are certainly even more removed than the angels in relation to G-d, but when we carry out His will, we too become bonded with Him; indeed, in a superior manner than the angels366* (Likkutei Torah).cclxxvi*
Siddur: Blessings Of The Shema - vəhaofännim vəcheeiot häqqođësh
vrchvt shm - Vehaofanim Vechayot Hakodesh
vəhaofännim vəcheeiot häqqođësh bərääsh gađol mïtənäshsəim ləümmät häshsərofim, ləümmatam məshäbəchim vəomərim׃
And the Ofanim and the holy Chayos rise up toward the Seraphim with a great clamor, and, in their manner, offer praise and declare:
vəhaofännim vəcheeiot häqqođësh bərääsh gađol mïtənäshsəim

And the ofanim and the holy chayos376* rise… with a great clamor – The clamor of the ofanim and the chayos comes from the fact that they know that there is a level of G-dliness that they cannot comprehend. The seraphim comprehend the G-dly energy that vitalizes creation and are therefore consumed with yearning to bond with Him. The chayos and the ofanim, by contrast, know that they derive from a G-dly source, but are unaware of the nature of that source. They are motivated to bond with Him, but because of this lack of awareness, their desire is impetuous and chaotic, an unbridled and unconstrained want. Therefore, it is expressed in a “clamor.”

More specifically, the “clamor” comes about because the existence of the chayos and the ofanim is much coarser and more materially oriented than that of the seraphim.377* As such, their efforts to rise above themselves and bond with G-d cause more “noise.” To illustrate with a material example: When refined and pure substances burn, they make little if any noise, but when coarse substances burn, they crackle loudly. Indeed, the coarser the substance, the greater the noise. Therefore it is the chayos and the ofanim who “clamor” in their desire for G-d378* (Likkutei Torah; Toras Shmuel, Toras Menachem).cclxxxv*

Why do the chayos and the ofanim clamor? It’s like anyone exposed to a new and exciting concept that he hears for the first time; he reacts with enthusiasm. Rather than remain calm and meditative, he is charged with vibrant inspiration. Similarly, when they are made conscious of the dimension of G-dliness that is “holy,” above relation to the creation, these angels cannot be stilled and clamor for the revelation of G-dliness. By contrast, the seraphim are continually aware of that dimension of G-dliness. As such, their reaction is not as excited.

To borrow an analogy from our Sages,379* the difference between them can be compared to the difference between the reaction of a villager who sees the king and that of an inhabitant of the king’s capital. The villager is overcome with fear and dread; shock and awe are real terms for him. The inhabitant of the capital is also overcome with awe upon seeing the king – from a certain standpoint even more so than the villager380* – but accustomed as he is to seeing the king, he shows no external signs of emotion. His excitement is all internal.

On a deeper level, it is not only that the chayos and the ofanim are exposed to a new conception of G-dliness that they had not known beforehand. Their excitement stems from the fact that this transcendent dimension of G-dliness revolutionizes their entire conception of their existence.

The seraphim, on the other hand, continually perceive G-d’s transcendence and appreciate how all existence is entirely insignificant to Him. Hence, that perception does not jolt their appreciation of reality entirely.

With the realization that G-d is bringing all existence into being from absolute nothingness, the chayos and ofanim, by contrast, come to a new awareness that revolutionizes their natural perspective. Their natural perception is that they – and all other elements of the Spiritual Cosmos – truly exist. Their new awareness thus runs in direct contradiction to their natural tendency. The inner turmoil and shake-up this brings about is what causes their noisy clamor. A person who had such a realization would cry out: “Gevald! What we see is not true!” So, too, the chayos and ofanim are driven by their new understanding to exclaim: “Blessed be the glory of G-d from its place!”(Likkutei Torah; the series of maamarim entitled BeShaah SheHikdimu, 5772; Maamarei Admor Rayatz; Likkutei Sichos).cclxxxvi*

As mentioned above, the seraphim’s desire to bond with G-d is dependent on their understanding. As such, it is not a complete state of bittul, for their existence is not eclipsed entirely; their bittul is commensurate with their understanding and circumscribed by its limits. The clamor of the ofanim to come close to G-d stems from their realization that there is a dimension of G-dliness that they do not understand at all and with which they wish to bond. This takes them beyond their individual existence.

Thus when speaking of the extent to which bittul, self-nullification, pervades their existence, the bittul of the seraphim is much greater, for their awareness of G-d permeates their entire being. Nevertheless, when speaking of the quality of the bittul, the degree to which it takes them beyond themselves, the bittul of the ofanim is superior, because it enables them to rise above their own existence entirely.

The superiority of the bittul of the seraphim is that it is more internalized. Nevertheless, that advantage leads to a shortcoming, because their bittul only draws down a level of G-d’s light which can be internalized, for as mentioned above, the seraphim only relate to the radiance of G-dly light that they can perceive and comprehend. And only the level of G-d’s light that has become contracted and limited can be perceived and comprehended.

The ofanim, by contrast, do not perceive G-dliness directly and thirst for a bond with Him. Their thirst is so powerful that it takes them beyond their own limits entirely. As such, it draws down the infinite dimensions of Divine light, those which transcend limitation (Toras Menachem).cclxxxvii*

rsh, “clamor,” shares the same letters as shr, “gateway.” The “noisy” bittul of the ofanim is the gateway through which they enter into a relationship with G-d (Toras Shmuel).cclxxxviii*

Siddur: Blessings Of The Shema - baruch kəvođ h׳
vrchvt shm - Baruch Kevod Hashem
baruch kəvođ Adonai mïmməqomo׃
Blessed be the glory of God from its place.
baruch kəvođ Adonai mïmməqomo

Blessed be the glory of G-d from its place – Kevod Havayah, “the glory of G-d,” refers to G-d’s attribute of Malchus,381* which is identified with the Divine light that is memale kol almin, i.e., the Divine light that fills the worlds and endows them with vitality. “From its place” means from its original source – i.e., from the sublime wisdom of Atzilus (Chochmah Ilaah),382* the source of all blessing. For it is within the Sefirah of Chochmah that G-d’s encompassing light, termed sovev kol almin, rests383* (Likkutei Torah).ccxci*

The seraphim384* are angels whose service centers on their comprehension of G-dliness. In contrast, the service of the ofanim – as previously explained – reflects a bittul that transcends comprehension. The seraphim’s comprehension of G-dliness leads to the conclusion that G-d is kadosh, “holy,” distant and removed from creation. By contrast, the service of bittul of the ofanim causes them to proclaim “Blessed be the glory of G-d….” By doing so, they draw G-dliness down385* to this material realm.

The ability of the ofanim to draw down a higher level of G-dliness than the seraphim reflects the fact that their source is rooted in a higher level of Divine light than that of the loftier angels. To explain: the unconstrained nature of their service and its transcendence of the bounds of logic indicate that they are rooted in a level of G-dliness that is likewise unbounded. The seraphim, by contrast, though lofty and refined, stem from a source in G-dliness that is by nature limited.386*

True, the ofanim are on a lower level than the seraphim. But their lower standing stems from their higher source. As is well known, an entity with a higher source will, ultimately, descend lower. To illustrate by analogy, when a stone wall is knocked down, its highest stones will fall the farthest away (Toras Menachem).ccxcii*

A further contrast between these two levels of angels: the seraphim’s desire is fundamentally self-oriented; they desire to be subsumed in G-d’s light. The ofanim’s yearning, by contrast, is outward oriented; they desire that G-d’s light be drawn down and revealed in the lower realms (the series of maamarim entitled BeShaah SheHikdimu, 5772).

This phrase vrvch chvvđ hvy׳ mmqvmv serves as an acronym for the Hebrew term vchym, “crying,”387* as in our Sages’ statement:388* “The lower waters cry (vchym), pleading, ‘We want to come before the King!’” Despite these angels’389* lack of comprehension of Who G-d is, their sincere yearning for Him draws forth a revelation from the Essential Source of light.

In truth, however, the description of the ofanim crying out over their distance from G-d pales in comparison to the similar outcry that the Jewish people, who, when they sense their distance from Him, call out in even greater yearning for G-dliness (Toras Menachem; Toras Shmuel; the series of maamarim entitled BeShaah SheHikdimu, 5772).ccxciii*

Indeed, in and of themselves, the angels would not have the power to draw G-d’s glory down to the lower realms of Beriah, Yetzirah, and Asiyah. When, however, the Jews praise and yearn for G-d and draw down His mercy, the impetus is generated for the downward flow of His light which is then facilitated by the angels’ request (Likkutei Torah; Toras Shmuel).ccxciv*

The expression “from its place” indicates that the chayos and the ofanim do not know where G-dliness is revealed. The seraphim say “The entire earth is filled with His glory;” i.e., as explained above,390* they perceive that the Divine presence is manifest among the Jewish people. The chayos and the ofanim, by contrast, are not aware of G-d’s place, where and how He is manifest (the Rebbe’s biurim of Tanya, as cited in Lessons In Tanya).ccxcv*
Siddur: Blessings Of The Shema - lae־l baruch
vrchvt shm - Lakeil Baruch
lael baruch nəimot yïtenu, lamëlëch el chei vəqeeiam, zəmïrot yomeru vətïshəbachot yäshəmiu,
They offer sweet melodies to the blessed God; to the Almighty King, Who is living and abiding, they recite songs and pronounce praise.
ki hu ləvädo marom vəqađosh, poel gəvurot, osëh chäđashot, bääl mïləchamot,
For He alone is exalted and holy, performing mighty deeds, bringing about new developments, the Master of wars;
zoreä tsəđaqot, mätsəmiäch yəshuot, bore rəfuot,
He sows righteousness, causes deliverance to sprout forth, and creates cures;
nora təhïllot, äđon hännïfəlaot, häməchädesh bətuvo bəchal yom tamiđ määseh vəreshit.
He is awesome in praise, the Master of wonders, Who in His goodness renews every day, continuously, the work of creation,
kaamur, ləoseh orim gəđolim, ki ləolam chäsədo׃
as it is said: “[Give thanks to] the One Who makes the great luminaries, for His kindness is everlasting.”
baruch ätah Adonai, yotser hämməorot׃
Blessed are You, God, Creator of the luminaries.
ki hu ləvädo marom vəqađosh

For He is alone, exalted and holy – chy, translated as “for,” can also be understood as meaning “because.” Why do the ofanim and the holy chayos clamor for the revelation of G-d’s glory? Because “He is alone, exalted and holy,” above their perception. Their understanding that His loftiness surpasses their comprehension is the motivating factor of their yearning to bond with Him (Tanya).ccxcvi*

Describing G-d as “alone” in His holiness implies that His holiness is not relative, i.e., He is not holy in comparison to others. Instead, G-d is intrinsically holy. His holiness is a reflection of His essential being (Toras Chayim).ccxcvii*

After referring to G-d’s essential holiness, the blessing mentions expressions of praise that describe the pattern through which G-d’s light is drawn down to the lower realms. “Exalted” refers to the level of Kesser that transcends all existence. The ten expressions of praise that follow correspond to the Ten Sefiros: “Holy” refers to Chochmah; “performing mighty deeds,” to Binah; etc. Thus the blessing indicates how the full range of His powers are drawn into our world (Toras Shmuel).ccxcviii*
Siddur: Blessings Of The Shema - ähävät olam
vrchvt shm - Ahavat Olam
ähävät olam ähävətanu Adonai ëloheinu,
You have loved us, God our Lord, with everlasting love.
chëməlah ǥəđolah viterah chamäləta aleinu.
You have bestowed upon us an abundant and exceeding measure of compassion.
avinu mäləkenu, bäävur shïməcha hägađol uväävur ävoteinu
Our Father, our King, for the sake of Your great name, and for the sake of our ancestors who trusted in You,
shëbotəchu vəcha vätəlämməđem chüqqei cheeiim lääsot rətsonəcha bəlevav shalem, ken təchonnenu utəlämməđenu.
whom You taught life-giving laws by which to fulfill Your will wholeheartedly, be likewise gracious to us and instruct us.
avinu av harächäman hämərächem rächëm na aleinu, vəten bəlïbenu binah
Our Father, merciful Father, Who shows mercy, have mercy upon us and implant understanding in our hearts
ləhavin uləhäsəkil, lïshəmoä lïləmođ uləlämmeđ lïshəmor vəlääsot, uləqeeiem ët kal dïvərei täləmuđ toratëcha bəähävah.
so that we may lovingly comprehend and perceive, listen, learn and teach, observe, perform and maintain all the words of the teachings of Your Torah.
vəhaer eineinu bətoratëcha, vəđäbeq lïbenu bəmïtsəoteicha, vyächeđ ləvavenu ləähävah ulyïrəah ët shəmëcha, vəlo nevosh vəlo nïkalem vəlo nïkashel ləolam vaëđ.
Enlighten our eyes with Your Torah, cause our hearts to cleave to Your commandments, and unify our hearts to love and fear Your name; and may we never be shamed or disgraced, or falter.
ki vəshem qođəshəcha hägađol vəhännora batochənu, naǥilah vənïsəməchah bishuatëcha.
For we have placed our trust in Your holy, great, and awesome name; may we celebrate and rejoice in Your salvation.
vərächämeicha Adonai ëloheinu vächäsađeicha haräbim äl yääzəvunu nëtsäch sëlah vaëđ.
May Your mercy, O God our Lord, and Your abundant kindness never forsake us.
mäher vəhave aleinu bərachah vəshalom məherah,
Hasten and speedily bring us blessing and peace.
vähävienu ləshalom meärəbä känəfot haarëts,
Bring us in peace from the four corners of the world.
ushəvor ol hägoiïm meäl tsävarenu, vətolichenu məherah qoməmiut ləärətsenu,
Break off the yoke of the nations from our necks and speedily lead us upright to our land.
ki el poel yəshuot atah, uvanu vachärəta mïkal äm vəlashon,
For You are God Who brings about acts of salvation and You have chosen us from all nations and tongues.
vəqerävətanu mäləkenu ləshïməcha hägađol bəähävah ləhođot ləcha ulyächëđəcha uləähävah ët shəmëcha׃
And You, our King, have lovingly brought us close to Your great name, so that we may thankfully acknowledge You, proclaim Your oneness, and love Your name.
baruch ätah Adonai, häbocher bəämmo yïsərael bəähävah׃
Blessed are You God, Who chooses His people Israel with love. No interruption should be made between this blessing and the recitation of the Shema that follows. According to Chabad custom, the sheliach tzibbur says the last words of this blessing in an undertone.
ähävät olam ähävətanu

You have loved us… with everlasting love – The preceding blessing, Yotzer Or,401* praises G-d for the creation of the luminaries and, in a larger sense, for bringing the entire creation into being. This blessing, Ahavas Olam, by contrast, praises Him for something far greater: the bond of love He established with us by giving us the Torah402* (Or HaTorah).cccvi* The connection between the themes of these two blessings – Creation and granting us His Torah – is emphasized by our Sages’ statement403* that the light G-d created on the first day of existence was subsequently hidden in the Torah (Or HaTorah).cccvii*

Yotzer Or places an emphasis on awe and fear of G-d, describing how the angels perceive their distance from G-d and how “they all exclaim with dread and declare in awe….” Even their love for G-d is a yearning that stems from the knowledge of their distance from Him and thus is associated with awe. Ahavas Olam, by contrast, emphasizes love, the sweetness and the satisfaction that stems from the bonds of closeness He has established with us (Likkutei Torah).cccviii*

Ahavas Olam, translated as “everlasting love,” can also be literally translated as “the love of the world.” In that context, the term can be understood to mean “love as great as the entire world,” i.e., that G-d’s love for us is like a father’s all-encompassing love for his son, for a son is his father’s “entire world” (Or HaTorah).cccix*

Alternatively, the expression “the love of the world” can be understood as implying that it is because of His great love for us that G-d contracted Himself and enclothed His light in the limitations that govern our world. Just as on the earthly plane love causes a person to make sacrifices on behalf of his beloved, so too, G-d’s love for the Jewish people causes Him to contract His great light and enclothe Himself in a framework of limitation. By doing so, He establishes a relationship with the Jewish people even as they exist on this earthly plane.404* As the blessing continues to state, “He chose us from all the nations of the world,” i.e., even as we exist in physical bodies, we are the objects of His love. Moreover, not only did He choose us from among all the nations, He also forsook all the holy heavenly hosts and instead, caused His presence to rest upon us, His people. Even as we exist on this physical plane, He identifies with us to the extent that He is called “our G-d” (Tanya).cccx*

Alternatively, the term “the love of the world” can be interpreted as implying that the love we have for G-d stems from “the world,” i.e., it results from meditating on G-d’s greatness as manifest in creation.

In a similar vein, “the love of the world” can be interpreted as the response from Above to man’s refinement of the latent sparks of G-dliness embedded in the world’s substance. G-d’s loving response is evoked by our spiritual activity within the world (Torah Or).cccxi*

In chassidic thought, Ahavas Olam is often contrasted with ahavah rabbah.405* As mentioned above, Ahavas Olam can be interpreted as “the love of the world.” It is thus considered to be on a lower level, an expression of love that is defined by the limitations of the world. By contrast, ahavah rabbah means “great love,” i.e., a love that is unbounded and unlimited in nature. Since G-d loves every Jew as a father loves a son – with a love that transcends all constraints and is as boundless and unlimited as He – every Jew radiates such love back to G-d in a manner unaffected by the world’s constraints. (Thus ahavah rabbah represents a higher level than Ahavas Olam.)

Nevertheless, we use the phrase Ahavas Olam – and not Ahavah Rabbah –for the interpretation of Ahavas Olam – and indeed, this is also the simple translation – as “with everlasting love implies that it too possesses an unbounded dimension. Indeed, “great love” indicates that the love surpasses the ordinary limitations of existence, but it is nevertheless bounded.406* Everlasting love, by contrast, is truly unbounded and unchanging, having no limitations whatsoever. The source for such love is G-d’s Essence, as that level alone is truly unbounded and above change. Since the soul of a Jew is “an actual part of G-d,”407* there exists in our hearts an essential love for Him that is also unbounded and unchanging (Likkutei Torah; Or HaTorah; Toras Menachem).cccxii*
Siddur: The Shema - shəmä
qryt shm - Shema
shəmä yïsərael, Adonai ëloheinu, Adonai | ëchađ׃
Hear, O Israel, God is our Lord, God is One.
shəmä yïsərael

Hear… One – The ayin of the word Shema and the dalet of the word echad are written as oversized letters, together forming the word đ, “witness.” G-d tells the Jewish people:420* “You are My witnesses,” i.e., it is the mission of the Jewish people to make G-d’s presence known in the world at large.

Our Sages421* relate that witnesses are not necessary regarding a matter that will inevitably be revealed. In spiritual terms, this can be understood as referring to the Divine light that is memale kol almin, i.e., the Divine energy that fills the world and imbues it with life. For it, like the presence of the soul in the body, can be appreciated through contemplation.422* G-d’s transcendent dimension, the light that is sovev kol almin,423* by contrast, is above intellectual grasp. To it, we relate through emunah, faith. The Jews’ mission is to bear witness to this dimension of G-dliness and make it known throughout the world (Or HaTorah).cccxxvi*

When the oversized letters ayin and dalet are read in the reverse order, the letters form the word đ, “know.” Belief and faith alone are insufficient. We must also “know” the dimension of the soul that testifies to G-d’s oneness.424* Then one shares a conscious bond with the essence of the soul (Kesser Shem Tov).cccxxvii*

is numerically equivalent to seventy and refers to the complete state of our seven emotional faculties.425* The oversized ayin indicates that these faculties are expressed as they exist in an exalted state; the emotions are raised to the level of intellect.426*

Seventy also refers to the seventy nations of the world. In a large sense, this number thus alludes to the sparks of G-dliness embedded in the material substance of the world that are under the dominion of these nations. These sparks are to be elevated through the Divine service of the Jewish people as they interact with the world at large (Likkutei Torah).cccxxviii*

Shema, translated as “Hear,” also has the connotation “gather,” as in the verse:427* “And Shaul gathered (vyshm) the nation [in preparation for battle].” In this instance, it implies fighting the natural tendencies that pull us outward and motivate us toward seeking varied forms of material satisfaction and pleasure. In this context, gathering means collecting the sparks of our souls that were dispersed through our pursuit of material pleasures and focusing them on G-d.

Alternatively, Shema has the connotation “of understanding deeply,”428* i.e., contemplating, feeling, and taking to heart G-d’s oneness and His bond with us (Likkutei Torah; Imrei Binah; Mitteler Rebbe, Kuntreisim).cccxxix*

Hear Israel – This charge also addresses the very source of the Jews’ souls, the dimension within the Jewish people that is above enclothement in the body. For the name Israel refers to the souls of the Jewish people as they “arose in G-d’s thought,”429* and, indeed, on so elevated a level of thought that it completely transcends conscious intellect (Maamarei Admor HaZakein; Toras Shmuel).cccxxx*
Siddur: The Shema - baruch shem kəvođ
qryt shm - Baruch Sheim Kevod
baruch shem kəvođ mäləchuto ləolam vaëđ׃
Blessed be the name of His glorious kingdom forever and ever.
baruch shem kəvođ mäləchuto ləolam vaëđ

Blessed be the name of His glorious kingdom forever and ever – This phrase is not found in the passage of Shema as it is written in the Torah.434* Nevertheless, when our Sages arranged the order of prayer in the era of the Second Beis HaMikdash, they ordained that this additional phrase be recited, inserting it between the contiguous Scriptural verses of Shema and VeAhavta.

What is the source for this phrase and why was it inserted? As the Talmud435* relates, before our Patriarch Yaakov passed away, he called his sons together. As he was about to address them, the Divine presence departed from him. Thereupon, he said, “Perhaps there are unworthy ones among them.”

His sons replied: “Hear, Israel, God is our Lord, God is one,” i.e., listen to us, Israel, our father, God is our Lord, God is one. Just as in your heart there is but one [G-d], so too in our hearts there is but one [G-d].”436*

Upon hearing this, Yaakov responded: “Blessed be the name of His glorious kingdom forever and ever.”

Our Sages pondered: “What should we do? Should we say [this phrase as part of the Shema prayer]? Moshe our teacher did not say it [in the paragraph of the Shema]. Should we not say it? But Yaakov did say it.” They therefore ordained that it be recited, but in a hushed tone.

And they continued with an analogy: It is similar to the daughter of a king who smelled the burnt food stuck to the pot and desired it. If she would publicly voice her desire, she would be shamed for desiring such a thing. If she would not voice her desire, she would feel pain, because her desire would not be satisfied. Therefore, she sent her servants who began bringing it to her secretly.”

All the particulars of this passage are significant. As explained at great length in Chassidus,437* there is a fundamental difference between the spiritual level of the Patriarchs and that of Yaakov’s sons. The Patriarchs were on the level of yichuda ilaah, “the sublime unity,” the level of oneness that permeates the sefiros in the realm of Atzilus. On that level, there is no sense of individual identity; the sefiros of Atzilus see themselves merely as extensions of G-d.

Yaakov’s sons, by contrast, are identified with the level of oneness that permeates the world of Beriah. On that rung, there is an awareness of self. Nevertheless, the angels and souls of that realm devote themselves to G-d with fiery love. Thus they too bond with G-d, but the oneness they achieve is described by the term yichuda tataah, “the lower unity.” In the individual sense, this refers to a level where a person has a personal identity but makes an all-encompassing commitment to G-d.

On this basis, we can appreciate the above narrative. Yaakov was looking at his sons and recognizing that their spiritual level did not approach his. He was concerned that like Avraham and Yitzchak before him, there were unworthy ones among his children.

His children responded that they were all clinging to the unity of G-d as Yaakov was, but their mission – and thus their level of unity – was different. Yaakov’s mission was to reveal the sublime unity, to demonstrate how even this material world is nothing more than an expression of G-d’s infinity (the theme of the first verse of the Shema). The mission of his sons, by contrast, was to show that even as the world allows for individual existence, i.e., a state where G-dliness is concealed and the limitations of material existence are apparent, it is still one with G-d.

This is implied by the expression Baruch Shem…, “Blessed be the name of His glorious kingdom….” That phrase parallels the verse Shema: Both contain six words and a total of 25 letters.438* Moreover, the letters of chđ, the last word of the Shema, are interchangeable with those of vđ, the last word of Baruch Shem.439*

Nevertheless, there is a fundamental difference between the two verses. While the Shema emphasizes absolute unity, Baruch Shem emphasizes the concept of kingship. Now, “there is no king without a nation”440* and the term “nation” implies subjects who have a sense of individual identity and feel themselves separate from the king. For a person cannot be king over his sons, his friends, or even officials who understand his greatness. Kingship implies the existence of subjects with an identity of their own who nevertheless subsume that identity in subservience to the king.

Similarly, in the spiritual analogue, Shema communicates the truth that there is no existence other than G-dliness. Baruch Shem involves the acceptance of G-d’s yoke even in a realm that appears to be separate from Him.

This is implied by the Talmud’s analogy of the king’s daughter who desired the food stuck to the pot. She is seeking the dregs; therefore, it is shameful, but nevertheless, she has a desire for them. Now that desire for lowly things is ultimately a reflection of G-d’s desire for a dwelling in the lower realms, that the world as it exists with its crass materiality and selfish desires, things that could seem shameful, will become a dwelling for Him.

Before the destruction of the First Beis HaMikdash, the Jews were on a level where they could appreciate yichuda ilaah. Therefore from echad, they would proceed directly to VeAhavta, “And you shall love G-d,” i.e., their love was a direct product of contemplating G-d’s oneness. After the destruction of the First Beis HaMikdash, the people’s spiritual level descended and the kabbalas ol of Baruch Shem, i.e., the acceptance of the yoke of G-d’s kingship by his subjects who possessed their own individual identities had to be emphasized (Tanya; Torah Or, Likkutei Torah; Imrei Binah; Likkutei Sichos; Toras Menachem; Sefer Maamarim Melukat).cccxxxvi*
Siddur: The Shema - vəahävəta et h׳
qryt shm - Veahavta Eit Hashem
vəahävəta et Adonai ëloheicha, bəchal | ləvovəcha, uvəchal näfəshəcha, uvəchal məođëcha׃
You shall love God your Lord with all your heart, with all your soul, and with all your might.
vəhaiu hädəvarim haellëh äshër anochi mətsäuəcha heeiom, äl | ləvavëcha׃
These words that I command you today shall be on your heart.
vəshïnnänətam ləvaneicha vəđïbärəta bam, bəshïvətəcha bəveitëcha, uvəlëchətəcha vädërëch, uvəshochəbəcha, uvəqumëcha׃
You shall teach them diligently to your children and speak of them when you sit at home, when you walk on the way, when you lie down and when you rise.
uqəshärətam ləot äl yađëcha, vəhaiu lətotafot bein eineicha׃
You shall bind them as a sign on your arm, and as ornaments between your eyes.
uchətävətam äl məzüzot beitëcha, uvïshəareicha׃
And you shall write them on the doorposts of your homes and your gates.
vəahävəta et Adonai ëloheicha

You shall love G-d your Lord – The term vhvt, VeAhavta, has two meanings. It is both a charge to love G-d and a promise that one will attain such love.

How does one fulfill the charge to love G-d? By meditating on His oneness so that love will be aroused in one’s heart. VeAhavta is thus dependent on the command Shema, “hear.” As explained above, Shema implies meditating on G-d’s oneness and taking it to heart. Thus the obligation incumbent upon us is contemplation; a command that every person can and must fulfill.

The promise of love refers to love that comes from Above. This love is a reflection of G-d’s love for the Jewish people which is utterly unlimited in nature. Since this love transcends all definition, man cannot be commanded to achieve it. Indeed, the attainment of such love is not dependent on man’s choice or efforts at all. Instead, it is granted by G-d on His initiative.

According to this interpretation as well, VeAhavta is dependent on Shema, for “hearing” also implies “receiving,” taking in what is being given. Although this degree of love cannot be achieved through man’s efforts, he must, however, transform himself into a vessel capable of taking in what is being given from Above (Torah Or).cccxxiii*

The command VeAhavta, “you shall love,” is dependent on Shema, the contemplation of G-d’s oneness. For it is impossible to command an emotion; either one loves or he does not love. There is no button to push that will make one love. Nevertheless, through meditation on concepts that will evoke love, one can cause such feelings to sprout forth in his heart (Sefer HaMaamarim 5699).cccxxiv*

“I personally heard the following from the Alter Rebbe: ‘I received [the following] from my master, the Maggid of Mezritch, who received it from the Baal Shem Tov, of blessed memory: The commandment “You shall love G-d” consists of immersing one’s thought and mind in matters that arouse love for G-d. [The feelings] that result from this [contemplation] do not constitute the primary aspect of the mitzvah.’”

(a note of the Rebbe, Derech Mitzvosecha, p. 420, quoting R. Eizik of Homel)
Siddur: The Shema - vəhaiah ïm shamoä
qryt shm - Vehaya Im Shamoa
vəhaiah ïm shamoä tïshəməu ël mïtsəotei äshër anochi mətsäuëh ëtəchëm heeiom,
And it shall come to pass that if you resolutely heed My commandments that I command you today,
ləähävah ët Adonai ëloheichëm uləovəđo, bəchal | ləvävəchëm uvəchal näfəshəchëm׃
to love God, your Lord, and to serve Him with all your heart and with all your soul,
vənatäti mətär ärətsəchëm bəïto yorëh umäləqosh,
I will grant the rain for your land at its proper time, the fall rain and the spring rain.
vəasäfəta đəǥanëcha vətiroshəcha vyïtsəharëcha׃
And you will gather your grain, your wine and your oil.
vənatäti esëv | bəsođəcha lïvəhëmətëcha, vəachäləta vəsavaəta׃
And I will provide grass in your fields for your cattle, and you shall eat and be satisfied.
hïshshoməru lochëm pën yïfətëh ləvävəchëm, vəsärətëm vääväđətëm ëlohim ächerim vəhïshətächävitëm lahëm׃
Beware lest your heart be tempted and you turn astray and worship other deities and bow down to them.
vəcharah | äf Adonai bachëm
For G-d’s fury will flare against you.
vəatsär ët häshshomeiïm vəlo yïhyëh motor vəhaäđomoh lo tïten ët yəvuloh,
He will seal the heavens and there will be no rain and the land will not yield its produce.
vääväđətëm | məherah meäl haarëts hättovah äshër Adonai noten lachëm׃
You will be banished swiftly from the good land that God is granting you.
vəsämətëm | ët dəvarei ellëh äl | ləvävəchëm vəäl näfəshəchëm, uqəshärətëm | otam ləot äl yëđəchëm vəhaiu lətotafot bein eineichëm׃
[And so,] place these words of Mine upon your hearts and upon your souls and bind them for a sign on your arm and as ornaments between your eyes.
vəlïmmäđətëm otam | ët bəneichëm ləđäber bam, bəshïvətəcha bəveitëcha uvəlëchətəcha vädërëch uvəshochəbəcha uvəqumëcha׃
Teach them to your children, to speak of them when you sit in your home, when you walk on the way, when you lie down and when you rise.
uchətävətam äl məzuzot beitëcha uvïshəareicha׃ ləmään yïrəbu yəmeichëm vimei vəneichëm
And you shall write them on the doorposts of your homes and your gates, so that your days and the days of your children will be prolonged
äl haäđamah äshër nïshəbä Adonai läävoteichëm latet lahëm, kimei häshshomeiïm äl haorëts׃
on the land that God swore to your ancestors to give them [for as long] as the heavens are above the earth.
ləähävah ët Adonai

To love G-d – This verse does not use the usual Hebrew form of the infinitive for “love,” lhv, but rather, the term lhvh which has the implication of generating love. For our fundamental thrust in these prayers is to generate love in the spiritual realms. Just as love draws two people together, the love generated by our service will then draw G-d and His love down into our material realm. Our efforts in this regard are necessary. Since G-d in His Essence is above all emotions, how can He be motivated to descend and clothe Himself in the emotion of love? Through an arousal of love for G-d on man’s part. Our arousal of love for G-d awakens a reciprocal love Above (Torah Or).cccliv*

Alternatively, the focus of lhvh is on the effects generated by our acts of love for G-d, i.e., our observance of G-d’s mitzvos. This – to borrow an expression of our Sages465* – “causes the name of G-d to become beloved,” i.e., one’s actions in the performance of mitzvos call forth a revelation of G-d’s love for us and this motivates others to love Him (Shaarei Teshuvah).ccclv*
Siddur: The Shema - veeiomër h׳
qryt shm - Vayomer Hashem
veeiomër Adonai ël moshëh lemor׃ däber ël bənei yïsərael vəamärəta älehëm vəasu lahëm tsitsït äl känəfei vïǥəđeihëm ləđorotam,
And God spoke to Moses, saying: “Speak to the Children of Israel and tell them to make tzitzis482* on the corners of their garments throughout their generations;
vənotənu äl tsitsït häkanaf | pətil təchelët׃
and they shall attach a cord of teicheles483* on the tzitzis on [every] corner.
vəhaiah lachëm lətsitsït, urəitëm | oto, uzəchärətëm | ët kal mïtsəot Adonai, vääsitëm | otam,
And they shall be tzitzis for you; you shall see it, and you will remember all of God’s mitzvos and perform them,
vəlo taturu ächärei ləvävəchëm vəächärei eineichëm äshër ätëm zonim ächäreihëm׃
and you will not wander after your hearts and after your eyes after which you stray –
ləmään tïzəkəru vääsitëm | ët kal mïtsəotai, vïhyitëm qəđoshim leloheichëm׃
so that you will remember and perform all My mitzvos and be holy to your God.
äni Adonai ëloheichëm äshër hotseti ëtəchëm | meërëts mïtsəreiïm lïhyot lachëm lelohim, äni Adonai ëloheichëm ëmët
I am God your Lord Who brought you out of the land of Egypt to be your God. I am God your Lord.” True…
veeiomër Adonai ël moshëh lemor

Speak to the children of Israel and tell them: Make tzitzis on the fringes of your garments – To explain the mystic dimension of a tallis and its tzitzis: the tallis is “[the garment] spread out by the King,”484* i.e., it represents an all-encompassing, indefinable Divine light. Wrapping ourselves in it alludes to the manner in which the mitzvos envelop us in G-dly light.

This all-encompassing light is alluded to by the term chnfy (translated as “fringes”)485* as evidenced by its use in the verses:486* “The children of men take refuge under the shadow of Your wings (chnfych)” and “G-d… under Whose wings (chnfyv) you have come to take refuge.”487*

The term tzitzis is also used to refer to hairs, as in the verse (Yechezkel 8:3): “And he took me by the hairs (vtsytsyt) of my head.” Hairs break through the surface of the body. Similarly, the tzitzis reflect how a revelation of the encompassing light represented by the tallis breaks through the limits of the Spiritual Cosmos and is conveyed into the limited realm of our internal powers of thought and feelings.488*

Similarly, the term tzitz means “to look”489* and also “to emerge.”490* Tzitzis thus also points to the ability to perceive the ray that emerges from this encompassing light.

It must be emphasized that the encompassing light that emerges into the realm of our internal powers is not a new – and more limited – light, but an extension of the simple, encompassing light alluded to by the tallis. This is intimated by the law491* requiring the tzitzis (representative of the light that projects into the realm of our limited powers) to be of the same type of fabric as the corner of the garment (the chnf, representative of the encompassing light).

In that vein, we can understand the requirement for 32 tzitzis strands, for 32 is representative of the 32 paths of Chochmah, wisdom. For Chochmah is the attribute that enables the encompassing light to break through and enter the realm of limitation.

This explains our Sages’ statement: tzitzis are equivalent to all the mitzvos.492* For the tzitzis contain parallels to both the Torah and the mitzvos: i.e., G-d’s will [as expressed in the mitzvos,] and the rationale [for them as expressed in the Torah,493* which are embodied] in the tallis and the tzitzis respectively.

Our Sages interpret494* the verse “Speak to the children of Israel… make tzitzis” as an exclusion, teaching that only Jews may make tzitzis. For the mystic service of drawing down G-d’s simple, encompassing light into the realm of limitation is solely the spiritual heritage of the Jewish people495* (Derech Mitzvosecha; Or HaTorah).ccclxix*
Siddur: The Shema - ëmët vyätstsiv
qryt shm - Emet Veyatziv
ëmët vyätstsiv, vyashar, vənëëman; vəahuv vəchaviv, vənëchəmađ vənaim,
genuine, established, enduring, upright, faithful, loved, cherished, desirable, pleasant,
vənora vəädir, umətüqqan uməqübal, vətov vyafëh, hädavar häzzëh aleinu ləolam vaëđ׃
awesome, mighty, correct, acceptable, good and beautiful is this statement for us forever.
ëmët, ëlohei olam mäləkenu, tsur yääqov maǥen yïshəenu,
It is true that the eternal God – our King, the Rock of Jacob, the Shield of our deliverance –
ləđor vađor hu qeeiam, ushəmo qeeiam, vəchïsəo nachon, umäləchuto vëëmunato laäđ qeeiëmët.
He endures from generation to generation, and His name endures; His throne is firmly established and His sovereignty and faith endure forever.
uđəvaraiv chaiim vəqeeiamim, nëëmanim vənëchëmađim laäđ uləoləmei olamim,
His words are alive and enduring, faithful and desirable forever and for all eternity,
äl ävoteinu vəaleinu, äl baneinu vəäl doroteinu, vəäl kal dorot zërä yïsərael ävađeicha.
for our fathers and for us, for our children and for our [future] generations, and for all the generations of the descendants of Israel, Your servants.
äl harïshonim vəäl haächäronim davar tov vəqeeiam bëëmët uvëëmunah, choq vəlo yäävor.
For the first and last [generations], it is a good and enduring matter in truth and in faithfulness, a law that will never be revoked.
