ëmët, shaätah hu Adonai ëloheinu velohei ävoteinu, mäləkenu mëlëch ävoteinu,
It is true that You are God, our Lord and the Lord of our ancestors, our King and the King of our fathers,
goälenu goel ävoteinu, tsurenu tsur yəshuatenu, pođenu umätstsilenu meolam hu shəmëcha,
our Redeemer and the Redeemer of our fathers, our Rock, the Rock of our deliverance, our Liberator and our Rescuer – this is Your name from the beginning of time.
vəein lanu ođ ëlohim zulotəcha sëlah׃
We have no other God aside from You, forever.
ëmët vyätstsiv

True, genuine – This blessing mentions the term Emes, true, eight times: four before the passage beginning Ezras avoseinu, “the Help of our fathers,” and four within that passage. The Zohar509*explains this division into two sets of four as reflecting the fact that each time the word Emes is mentioned, it alludes to one of the four letters of G-d’s name y-h-v-h, the name that is associated with G-d’s “attribute of truth.”510*

It is explained in Kabbalah that there are two dimensions of the name y-h-v-h, one which establishes the structure of the Spiritual Cosmos511* and a higher one which transcends the Spiritual Cosmos.

More particularly, the Zohar explains that the first four times Emes is mentioned refer to the redemption from Egypt led by Moshe, and the second to the Ultimate Redemption to be led by Mashiach. For redemption is associated with the revelation of the name y-h-v-h, and the revelation of that name lifts one entirely above natural constraints. The redemption from Egypt is associated with the lower level of the name y-h-v-h512* and the Ultimate Redemption with the higher rung (Or HaTorah).ccclxxviii*

Alternatively, the first four mentions of Emes reflect man’s efforts to cling to truth,513* while the last four reflect the revelation of truth from Above that helps us to succeed in our endeavors (Likkutei Torah).ccclxxix*

After the first mention of the word Emes, the passage continues with fifteen words that begin with the letter vav. The form of the letter vav – a straight, vertical line – implies drawing down G-dly energy from Above.514* Similarly, in this instance as well, these fifteen vavvim represent the downward flow of this G-dly energy. Alternatively, these fifteen words recall the fifteen Shir HaMaalos psalms and the fifteen steps leading to the main entrance of the Beis HaMikdash, for fifteen is indicative of a process of ascent.515*

Grammatically, the vav is referred to as a “letter of connection,” i.e., like the word “and” in English, it links two subjects or objects. (An allusion to the letter vav serving this function is the phrase bevavvim tiskasher from the Shabbos evening hymn authored by the AriZal, which non-literally can be rendered as “with the vavvim a bond can be established.” ( Similarly, in the Torah,516* the term vav is used to refer to an implement that connects one entity to another. Onkelos translates the term as meaning “hooks.” Rashi renders it as spikes, the implements used to connect the Sanctuary to the earth. In this context, the implication is that through G-d’s influence drawn down from Above, a bond is created between G-d, the source of the influence, and mankind, its recipients.

The concept of connection is amplified by the fact that, as mentioned above, there are fifteen vavvim. Fifteen is numerically equivalent to y-h, the first two letters of G-d’s name y-h-v-h, which correspond to the Sefiros of Chochmah and Binah that are referred to517* as “two friends who never separate.”

Developing that concept, the first and second passages of the Shema are associated with the first two sons of Yaakov our Patriarch, Reuven and Shimon, respectively,518* and the blessing Emes Veyatziv is associated with Levi, who was so named by his mother, Leah, who exclaimed at his birth:519* “This time my husband will be joined (i.e., ‘bonded’) to me.”

The bond achieved in Emes Veyatziv is of a different nature than the bond achieved in Shemoneh Esreh Emes Veyatziv, “true and certain,” refers to the satisfying love a person feels as a result of an ongoing relationship.520* In Shemoneh Esreh, by contrast, a person stands before G-d in total bittul and humble acknowledgment,521* recognizing how G-d is entirely above our frame of reference522* (Torah Or; Maamarei Admor HaZakein; Or HaTorah Siddur; Toras Shmuel).ccclxxx*
Siddur: The Shema - ëzərät ävoteinu
qryt shm - Ezrat Avoteinu
ëzərät ävoteinu ätah hu meolam, maǥen umoshiä lahëm vəlïvəneihëm ächäreihëm bəchal dor vađor.
For all time, You have been the Help of our fathers, a Shield and a Deliverer for them and for their children after them in every generation.
bərum olam moshavëcha, umïshəpateicha vətsïđəqotəcha äđ äfəsei arëts.
Your dwelling is in the heights of the universe, and Your judgments and Your righteousness [extend] to the ends of the earth.
ëmët, äshərei ish sheeiïshəmä ləmïtsəoteicha, vətorotəcha uđəvorəcha yasim äl lïbo.

ëmët, ätah hu ađon ləämmëcha, umëlëch gïbor lariv rivam ləavot uvanim.
Truly, You are the Master of Your nation and a mighty King Who pleads their cause, for the fathers and the sons.
ëmët, ätah hu rïshon, vəätah hu ächäron, umïbäləađeicha ein lanu mëlëch goel umoshiä.
Truly, You are the first and You are the last; aside from You, we have no King, Redeemer and Deliverer.
ëmët, mïmmïtsəreiïm gəälətanu Adonai ëloheinu, umïbeit ävađim pəđitanu.
Truly, God our Lord, that You delivered us from Egypt and liberated us from the house of bondage.
kal bəchoreihëm haräǥəta, uvəchorəcha yïsərael gaäləta, vyäm suf lahëm baqäəta,
You slew all their firstborn, and redeemed Israel, Your firstborn. You split the Sea of Reeds on their behalf.
vəzeđim tïbäəta, viđiđim hëëvärəta, veiəchässu meiïm tsareihëm, ëchađ mehëm lo notar.
You drowned the brazen and enabled the cherished ones to pass through. The waters covered their foes, not one of them remained.
äl zot shïbəchu ähuvim, vəroməmu lael,
For this, the beloved [people] praised and exalted the Almighty;
vənotənu yəđiđim zəmirot shirot vətïshəbachot, bərachot vəhođaot lamëlëch el chei vəqeeiam.
the cherished ones offered music, songs, praises, blessings and thanks to the King, the living and enduring God.
ram vənïshsa gođol vənora, mäshəpil geim äđei arëts, umäǥəbiäh shəfalim äđ marom,
He is lofty and exalted, great and awesome. He lowers the haughty to the ground, and raises the lowly on high.
motsi äsirim, pođëh änavim, ozer dällim,
He releases prisoners, redeems the humble, helps the poor.
haonëh ləämmo yïsərael bəet shävəam elaiv.
It is He Who answers His nation Israel when they cry out to Him.
ëmët

You are the first and You are the last – G-d in His Essence remains unchanged throughout all the phases of existence. Just as He existed unaffected before Creation, so too does He exist afterwards, without having been affected by Creation at all (Likkutei Torah).ccclxxxiv*
Siddur: The Shema - təhïllot ləe־l ëlyon
qryt shm - Tehilot Lekeil Elyon
təhïllot ləel ëlyon goälam, baruch hu uməvorach,
Here one should stand. [They offered] praises to the supreme God, their Redeemer; blessed is He and He is blessed.
moshëh uvənei yïsərael ləcha anu shirah bəsïməchah räbah, vəoməru chüllam׃
Moses and the Children of Israel sang a song to You with great joy. They all proclaimed:
mi chamochah baelïm Adonai, mi kamochah nëədar bäqqođësh, nora təhïllot oseh fëlë׃
“Who is like You among the mighty, O God! Who is like You, glorified in holiness, awesome in praise, working wonders!”
moshëh uvənei yïsərael ləcha anu shirah bəsïməchah räbah, vəoməru chüllam

Moses and the Children of Israel sang a song to You with great joy. They all proclaimed – Moses and the Jewish people sang this song together, joining in unity without distinction or difference between any of the members of the people.529* For that reason, the song was initiated by Moses, because only Moses, the head of the Jewish people, could inspire such unity. Since Moses is a “collective soul,” he highlights and brings to the surface the spiritual common denominator that binds all Jews together and makes them one (Likkutei Sichos).ccclxxxviii*
Siddur: The Shema - shirah chäđashah
qryt shm - Shira Chadasha
shirah chäđashah shïbəchu ǥəulim ləshïməcha hägađol äl səfät heeiam,
With a new song, the redeemed ones praised Your great name on the shores of the sea.
yächäđ küllam hođu vəhïməlichu vəoməru׃ Adonai yïməloch ləolam vaëđ.
Together, they all gave thanks and accepted Your sovereignty, saying, “God will reign forever and ever.”
vənëëmär׃ goälenu Adonai tsəvaot shəmo qəđosh yïsərael.
And it is said, “Our Redeemer, the God of Hosts is His name, the Holy One of Israel.”
baruch ätah Adonai, gaäl yïsərael׃
Blessed are You, God, Who redeemed Israel.
shirah chäđashah shïbəchu ǥəulim

With a new song, the redeemed ones praised – The importance of joyously praising G-d in appreciation for His miracles cannot be overemphasized. Our Sages related:530* “The Holy One, blessed be He, sought to make Chizkiyahu Mashiach,” but refrained from doing so, because he failed to recite a song of praise (Toras Menachem).cccxci*
Siddur: The Amidah - h׳ səfatei tïfətach
myđh - Hashem Sefatay Tiftach
äđonai, səfatei tïfətach ufi yägiđ təhïllatëcha׃
G-d, open my lips and let my mouth relate Your praise.
äđonai, səfatei tïfətach ufi yägiđ təhïllatëcha

G-d, open my lips and let my mouth relate Your praise536* – By saying “Open my lips…,” King David is making both a personal request as well as a request on behalf of the Jewish people as a whole. As such, his wish is fitting to become the personal request of every individual Jew. Its recitation was ordained before the Shemoneh Esreh because it defines the fundamental approach to prayer as a whole and to the Shemoneh Esreh prayer in particular.

During Shemoneh Esreh, a person stands before G-d without moving, “as a servant stands before his master.”537* Ideally, an individual should stand in utter bittul before G-d. So great should be his bittul that he is incapable of praying on his own initiative – to borrow a phrase,538* “there are no words on my tongue.” Therefore, the person asks G-d to open his lips and allow his “mouth [to] relate Your praise.”

Moreover, the term “Your praise” indicates that he is not reciting his own prayer. Instead, it is G-d’s prayer emerging from his lips, as it were. He is like a person repeating after a reader, repeating and drawing down the praise recited in the spiritual realms.539* On a higher level, it is as if the Divine presence invests itself in the speaker’s voice and it is the Divine presence that is speaking540* (Kesser Shem Tov; Shaarei Orah; Toras Menachem).cccxcviii*

To cite a historical parallel: Before the Splitting of the Sea, Moshe tells the people:541* “And you shall be silent.” The Zohar542* interprets this to mean, “Do not rouse yourselves in prayer at all,” for the initiative must come from Above (Ner Mitzvah).cccxcix*

To explain this concept from a slightly different perspective: By and large, a person must labor within his soul and meditate at length until he evokes an emotional response in prayer. There are, however, times when his prayers simply flow. Effortlessly, he focuses his mind on the oneness of G-d and feelings of love stream forth. This approach reflects the ultimate desirable state for a person to attain as he prepares to recite the Shemoneh Esreh: His mind is not the originator of his prayers. Instead, they emerge as if on their own.

This is also implied by the second half of the verse: “let my mouth relate Your praise.” yǥyđ, translated as “relate,” also has the implication of “drawing down.” Water flows downwards effortlessly. Similarly, the person’s prayer will pour forth on its own accord, without being limited by his intellectual comprehension (Likkutei Torah).cd*

Praying in this manner enables ample influence to be drawn down directly from Above. When a person prays on his own initiative, the influence drawn down is dependent on his individual refinement. If his refinement is insufficient, there may be obstacles preventing the influence that is aroused Above from descending to this material plane. When, however, one recites “G-d’s praise,” the influence aroused by prayer is immediately drawn down in an entirely unobstructed manner (Toras Menachem).cdi*

The above also relates to the concept that the Shemoneh Esreh prayer is recited in a hushed tone.543* Like a person speaking when his mind is absorbed in the core of a concept, he does not choose his words.544* Similarly, when the person’s mind is subsumed in bittul, the words of prayer flow spontaneously, without his mind exercising control (Siddur Im Dach).cdii*

The concept of hushed prayer in Shemoneh Esreh can be associated with the vision that was revealed to the prophet Eliyahu, concerning which it is said:545* “And a great and strong wind tore the mountains, and broke the rocks in pieces… but G-d was not in the wind. And after the wind [came] an earthquake; but G-d was not in the earthquake; and after the earthquake a fire; but G-d was not in the fire; and after the fire a still, small voice.” About that still, small voice, the Zohar states:546* “There, the King comes.”

Similarly on the ladder of prayer, after the fiery love547* aroused during the Shema, one proceeds to a higher level. For “G-d is not in the fire,” i.e., even the fiery love one experiences is but his own feelings, the emotions of a created being. In “the still, small voice” of Shemoneh Esreh, by contrast, a person does not speak his own words; rather, “the King comes,” the person “relates G-d’s praise,” as explained above (Torah Or; Maamarei Admor HaEmtza’i).cdiii*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… maǥen ävəraham
myđh - Baruch… Magein Avraham
baruch ätah Adonai, ëloheinu velohei ävoteinu, ëlohei ävəraham, ëlohei yïtsəchaq, velohei yääqov,
Blessed are You, God, our Lord, and Lord of our Patriarchs, the Lord of Abraham, the Lord of Isaac and the Lord of Jacob,
hael hägađol hägïbor vəhännora, el ëlyon, gomel chäsađim tovim, qoneh häkol,
the great, mighty, and awesome God, the sublime God, Who brings forth generous kindness and brings into being all things,
vəzocher chäsəđei avot, umevi ǥoel lïvənei vəneihëm, ləmään shəmo bəähävah׃
Who remembers the generous deeds of the Patriarchs and Who lovingly brings a redeemer to their children’s descendants for the sake of His name.
(zochərenu ləcheeiim, mëlëch chafets bächeeiim, vəchotəvenu bəsefër hächeeiim, ləmäänəcha ëlohim cheeiim׃)
During the Ten Days of Repentance, one should say: Remember us for life, O King, Who desires life; inscribe us in the Book of Life, for Your sake, O God of Life.
mëlëch ozer umoshiä umaǥen.
[You are] the King, Who helps, delivers and shields.
baruch ätah Adonai, maǥen ävəraham׃
Blessed are You God, Shield of Abraham.
baruch ätah Adonai

Blessed are You G-d –Through the recitation of the Shema, we accept the yoke of G-d’s kingship in thought and speech. Bowing at the beginning of Shemoneh Esreh (and at later points during that prayer) reflects how we lower our heads in submission to Him, thus expressing the acceptance of His yoke in actual deed. So powerfully do we feel His focus upon us that we have no power or personal ego remaining even to raise ourselves up in a desire to cling to Him (Tanya; Likkutei Torah).cccxc*

On one hand, bowing is an act of humble submission – admitting one’s acceptance of another’s dominion. On the other hand, in humbling oneself so, one becomes fit to serve as a medium of influence, drawing down G-dly energy to the lower realms.512* Indeed, that is accomplished by the very act of bowing, for it invites our spiritual counterpart, “the sublime man,” i.e., the heavenly Sefiros, to bow in correspondence with our actions. As a consequence, the Divine energy invested in them is lowered and descends to our material realm513* (Torah Or; Shaarei Orah; Or HaTorah).cccxci*

More particularly, the act of bowing in the Shemoneh Esreh is composed of two actions: one bends his knees at Baruch, “Blessed,” and bows his head at Atah, “You.”514* When a person bends his knees, his head and torso are still erect. Implied is that this gesture does not affect his fundamental will and desires. He is merely bending his knees – implying submission to a higher will – against his own personal desires and tendencies. Bowing his head, by contrast, represents a more complete level of submission. The person submits not only his body but his mind to G-d’s will; i.e., G-d’s will becomes his will, as he gives himself over entirely to His service515* (Or HaTorah).cccxcii*

After bending his knees and bowing, one stands erect when mentioning G-d’s name: standing at attention, as it were. This prepares him to receive and internalize the influence drawn down from G-d through prayer (Or HaTorah).cccxciii*

The eighteen blessings of the Shemoneh Esreh parallel the eighteen vertebrae of the spinal column.516* The spinal column is the medium through which energy is drawn down from the head to the entire body, ending with the legs.

In this regard, there is a unique relationship between the spinal cord and the mitzvos. There are 248 limbs of the body and 248 positive commandments. Now the spinal cord is not considered one of the 248 limbs of the body, nor is the obligation to pray daily considered one of the 248 positive commandments.517* Nevertheless, just as the spinal cord is the medium through which vitality is drawn down to the entire body, prayer is the dimension of our Divine service that draws down spiritual energy to our observance of all the mitzvos (Torah Or; Likkutei Torah; Shaarei Teshuvah; Shaarei Orah).cccxciv*

The recitation of the Shema, the section of the prayer service preceding the Shemoneh Esreh, represents the motif of ratzo, man’s yearning to bond with G-d. The Shemoneh Esreh, by contrast, begins the motif of shov, whereby our attention is turned toward the material world in which we live. We seek to draw Divine blessings into the world and in that way transform it into a dwelling place for Him.

There is a distinction between the term baruch as used in the Shemoneh Esreh and the same term as employed in the blessings over matters from which one derives satisfaction. When baruch is employed in the Shemoneh Esreh, the implication is passive, that G-d has been blessed by others, i.e., those who are praying, as in the verse:518* “And King Shlomoh has been blessed.”

Nevertheless, baruch also possesses another meaning: to extend blessing, enabling it to reach lower planes of existence.519* In that context, the term baruch is associated with a bereichah (a pool of water that descends from a higher to a lower place) and the process of being mavrich a vine.520* These associations indicate that a berachah, blessing, is a process of conveying Divine energy to a lower realm.

In truth, both interpretations are correct. For baruch is identified with Chochmah, and in that Sefirah both of these motifs are given complete expression. On one hand, Chochmah is the source for all the Sefiros that follow; it “blesses” them all. On the other hand, Chochmah itself receives its vitality, i.e., it is “blessed,” from the loftier level of Kesser (Or HaTorah).cccxcv*

Our fundamental intent in prayer is the request that G-d’s infinite light that transcends the Spiritual Cosmos be drawn down within the framework of the Spiritual Cosmos and then into this physical world. This is reflected in the words “Blessed are You, G-d.” The name of G-d employed by the verse is Havayah, the name that reflects the structure of the Spiritual Cosmos: the Yud is identified with Chochmah; the first Hei, with Binah, etc., while “You” refers to G-d’s Essence, transcending all definition. Our request is that “You” be drawn down into Havayah. This essential energy will in turn change the makeup of the entire Spiritual Cosmos – and as a consequence the array of forces on the material plane – resulting in “the sick being healed and the years being blessed,” as we request in the intermediate blessings of the Shemoneh Esreh (Or HaTorah).cccxcvi*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… məcheeiëh hämmetim
myđh - Baruch… Mechaye Hameitim
ätah ǥïbor ləolam äđonai, məcheeiëh metim ätah, räv ləhoshiä.
You are mighty forever, O God; You resurrect the dead. [God is] abounding in deliverance,
(moriđ hättal׃)
in the summer: “He causes the dew to descend,”
(mäshshiv horuäch umoriđ hägëshëm׃)
in the winter: “He causes the wind to blow and the rain to descend.”
məchäləkel cheeiim bəchësëđ, məcheeiëh metim bərächämim räbim,
He sustains the living with kindness. He resurrects the dead with manifold mercies.
somech nofəlim, vərofe cholim, umätir äsurim, uməqeeiem ëmunato lishenei afar.
He supports those who fall, heals the sick and releases the imprisoned. He fulfills His faithful promise to those who repose in the dust.
mi chamocha bääl gəvurot, umi domëh lach, mëlëch memit uməcheeiëh umätsəmiäch yəshuah׃
Who is like You, Master of mighty acts? Who resembles You, O King Who puts to death, brings to life, and causes salvation to flourish?
(mi chamocha av harächäman zocher yətsuraiv ləcheeiim bərächämim׃)
During the Ten Days of Repentance, one should say: Who is like You, O merciful Father, Who remembers His creations for life, with mercy.
vənëëman ätah ləhächäyot metim.
You are trustworthy to resurrect the dead.
baruch ätah Adonai, məcheeiëh hämmetim׃
Blessed are You God, Who resurrects the dead.
ätah ǥïbor

You are mighty – Pirkei Avos581* states: “Who is mighty? He who conquers his natural inclination,” controlling his desires and tendencies. Similarly, G-d’s “might” involves controlling and limiting His infinite light and lowering Himself to enclothe His energy in matters of this world (Derech Mitzvosecha).cdxxvi*

The attribute of Gevurah, “might,” is often associated with tzimtzum, limiting the flow of His energy and fragmenting it into smaller measures. Nevertheless, ultimately, the purpose of this limitation is to enable the life-energy to be received and taken in by the created beings.582*

To illustrate by example: If rain (one of the expressions of Divine goodness mentioned in this blessing) were to descend in a deluge without being broken up into small droplets,583* it would not be a source of growth and blessing but would instead lead to destruction.

Another example of the connection between Gevurah, might, and Divine influence was seen in the Temple. The Table for the Showbread )the source of G-d’s blessings for material prosperity) was positioned in the north even though that direction is associated with Gevurah (might) and not Chessed (kindness). Through Gevurah’s quality of limitation, G-d’s generosity was drawn down into the world.

This explains the sequence of the blessings of the Shemoneh Esreh. The prayer begins by highlighting Avraham and the attribute of kindness. It then focuses on the might necessary for that kindness to descend in a form that can be accepted by the created beings (Maamarei Admor HaZakein; Imrei Binah; Shaarei Orah).cdxxvii*

Alternatively, the positive dimension of Gevurah alluded to in this blessing can be understood as an overpowering outflow of vitality, as found in the expression gevuras hageshamim, “the might of the rain.” Certainly, the Resurrection of the Dead mentioned in this blessing is associated with such a motif (Toras Shmuel).cdxxviii*
Siddur: The Amidah - näqədishach vənääritsach
myđh - Nakdishach Venaaritzach
näqədishach vənääritsach kəńoäm śiäch sođ särəfei q́ođësh häməshälləshim ləcha qəđüshshoh, käkotuv äl yäđ nəvië́cha, vəqora zëh ël zëh vəomär:
Let us sanctify and extol You, echoing the sweet words of the company of the holy Seraphim who three times proclaim “Holy” unto You, as it is written by Your prophet,287*
qađosh, qađosh, qađosh Adonai tsəvaot, məlo chal haárëts kəvođo:
‘Holy, holy, holy is God, the Commander of legions; the whole world is filled with His glory.’”
ləümmatam məshäbəchim vəomərim:
Correspondingly, [other angels] offer praise and declare:
baruch kəvođ Adonai mïmməqomo:
“Blessed be the glory of God from its place.”294*
uvəđïvərei qođəshəcha katuv lemor:
And in Your Holy Scriptures it is written as follows:
yïməloch Adonai ləolam, ëlohéiïch tsion ləđor vađor, häləluyah:
“God will reign forever — your Lord, O Zion — from generation to generation. Halleluyah!”297*
näqədishach vənääritsach

We will sanctify and extol You — The Kedushah recited in the repetition of the Shemoneh Esreh is of a different nature than the Kedushah recited in the blessing Yotzer Or (the first blessing preceding the Shema). In the Kedushah recited in the blessing Yotzer Or, we are not sanctifying G-d, but merely recalling and describing the sanctification conveyed upon Him by His ministering angels.282*Shemoneh Esreh, by saying Nakdishcha (“We will sanctify You”), our recitation is, by contrast, an act of sanctification of G-d (the Alter Rebbe's Shulchan Aruch).283*

Indeed, the angels' ability to sanctify G-d is dependent on our sanctification of Him: “Angels do not sanctity Him Above until the Jews on this physical plane recite Kadosh….”284*Toras Chayim;285*).286*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… hae־l häqqađosh
myđh - Baruch… Hakeil Hakadosh
ätah qađosh vəshïməcha qađosh, uqəđoshim bəchal yom yəhäləĺucha së́lah.
You are holy, and Your name is holy, and holy ones praise You every day for eternity.
baruch ätah Adonai, (hämmë́lëch häqqađosh) hael häqqađosh:
Blessed are You, God, the holy God. (During the Ten Days of Repentance, substitute: the holy King.)
ätah qađosh vəshïməcha qađosh

You are holy and Your name is holy – The preceding blessing focuses on the Resurrection of the Dead, and this blessing, on G-d's essential holiness which will become manifest in the era that will follow. This corresponds with the pattern stated by our Sages:298*Maamarei Admor HaEmtza’i, Kuntreisim).299*

In Jewish thought, the term "holy" means "removed," on a higher plane, and therefore detached and distant. G-d is certainly holy, above the limitations of the world. Moreover, not only is He holy, even His name – i.e., His essential light – the effluence that emanates from Him that is the source for our existence, is also "holy," entirely above the world and its limitations.

Pirkei deRabbi Eliezer300*G-d and His essential lightremain "holy," utterly beyond the entire realm of worldly existence (and therefore unchanged).

Nevertheless, the phrase reads: “You are holy and Your name is holy,” and not, "You and Your name are holy." The separation of the concepts into two clauses indicates that G-d's essential holiness and the holiness of His name represent two different levels, for His light is, after all, merely light. Herein lies the purpose of the Divine service of the Jewish people: to draw down His essential holiness into His name. This is implied by the phrase:301*

There are sources which state that influence from His essence is accomplished through martyrdom, sacrificing one's life for the sanctification of G-d's name. The rationale is that G-d's Essence can be drawn down only through a complete expression of bittul and there is no more complete expression of bittul than the self-sacrifice of martyrdom.302*Maamarei Admor HaZakein;303*Likkutei Torah;304*Toras Menachem;305*Sefer HaMaamarim Melukat)306*

Other sources explain that G-d's essential holiness is drawn down through the joyful performance of the mitzvos because "joy breaks through barriers," enabling His essential holiness to be manifest in a lower realm.307*

And in still other sources, it is explained that His essential holiness is drawn down through prayer. In prayer, a person establishes a connection between the essential G-dliness that lies latent at the core of his soul and his revealed powers.308*evokes a similar motif Above, drawing G-d's essential holiness into His name309*Likkutei Torah; Maamarei Admor HaZakein; Toras Shmuel; Toras Menachem; Sefer HaMaamarim Melukat).
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… chonen hädaät
myđh - Baruch… Chonein Hadaat
ätah chonen ləađam däät, uməlämmeđ lëënosh binah.
You graciously endow knowledge to man and teach understanding to mortals.
chonnenu meïtəcha chochəmah binah vađaät.
Graciously grant us from You wisdom, understanding and knowledge.
baruch ätah Adonai, chonen hädaät׃
Blessed are You, God, Who endows knowledge.
ätah chonen ləađam däät

You graciously endow knowledge to man – The inclusion of this statement in our prayers indicates that prayer is the most propitious time for the knowledge that results from the contemplation of G-dliness to flourish (Torah Or).cdxli*

With this blessing, we acknowledge that our knowledge and understanding is a gift from G-d. On our own, we are not wise; knowledge has been “graciously endow[ed]” us. This is a very humbling realization592* (the Rebbe’s Igros Kodesh).cdxlii*

The Shemoneh Esreh begins with three blessings that relate G-d’s praise. Afterwards, there are twelve intermediate blessings.593* The number twelve is identified with the twelve tribes who, according to Kabbalah, represent the Divine chariot in the world of Beriah, the world where the concept of yeshus, personal existence, begins. Similarly, these twelve blessings represent a turning point in the Shemoneh Esreh; the focus shifts from our praise of G-d to our requests that Divine influence be drawn down to satisfy our individual and collective needs (Toras Shmuel).cdxliii*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… harotsëh bïtəshuvah
myđh - Baruch… Harotze Bitshuva
häshivenu avinu lətoratëcha,
Our Father, cause us to return to Your Torah;
vəqorəvenu mäləkenu läävođatëcha,
draw us near, O King, to Your service,
vəhächäzirenu bïtəshuvah shəlemah ləfaneicha.
and bring us back to You in complete repentance.
baruch ätah Adonai, harotsëh bïtəshuvah׃
Blessed are You, God, Who desires repentance.
häshivenu avinu lətoratëcha

Our Father, cause us to return, to Your Torah – As mentioned above, the order of the blessings is significant. This request is made after our acknowledgment of the knowledge (Daas) with which G-d has endowed us. As our Sages comment,600* “If there is no knowledge, how can a distinction be made?” And the most important distinction man can make is the distinction between good and evil.

A person who is not spiritually conscious will not be motivated to pursue teshuvah; he is unable to sense what a pity it is to be distant from G-dliness. As he grows in knowledge (Daas), however, he will understand the spiritual pitfalls of sin and search for a path of teshuvah (Shaarei Teshuvah).cdxlvi*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… hämmärəbëh lïsəloäch
myđh - Baruch… Hamarbe Lisloach
səläch lanu avinu, ki chatanu,
Forgive us, our Father, for we have sinned.
məchol lanu mäləkenu, ki fashaənu,
Absolve us, our King, for we have transgressed,
ki el tov vəsällach atah.
for You are a good and forgiving God.
baruch ätah Adonai, chännun, hämmärəbëh lïsəloäch׃
Blessed are You, God, Who is gracious and Who forgives abundantly.
səläch lanu avinu, ki chatanu

Forgive us … for we have sinned – Seemingly, this request should be made before we begin to pray, for it is certainly more appropriate for a sinner to first ask for forgiveness before approaching G-d in prayer. However, before praying, a person may not realize his faults. Since he generally does not commit blatant transgressions and, by and large, observes the mitzvos, he may feel spiritually content and not appreciate the need to seek forgiveness.

Only after developing his spiritual awareness and refining his animal soul by ascending the ladder of prayer – praising G-d in Pesukei D’Zimrah and coming to the point of mesirus nefesh in the Shema – does he realize the separation from G-d that his conduct has brought about.

In particular, the higher the level of spiritual awareness the person reaches, the deeper is his realization of his distance from G-d. Therefore it is specifically in the Shemoneh Esreh, the peak of our Divine service, that we request forgiveness (Likkutei Torah; Shaarei Teshuvah; Maamarei Admor HaEmtza’i, Kuntreisim; Toras Shmuel).cdlii*

chy, translate as “for,” can also mean “because.” “Because” implies a cause and effect relationship. Now, this is difficult to understand: Should G-d forgive us because we have sinned and violated His will?

The intent is that G-d has granted us a mode of relating to Him through the observance of the Torah and its mitzvos. When we sin, G-d’s will is turned away from us and this path of connection is no longer viable. Turning to G-d in teshuvah involves entering into a new relationship in which a higher level of His will is drawn down, a level where our misdeeds do not impinge on our relationship with Him. This is our request: Because we have sinned, we cannot depend on our previous relationship and are therefore asking for a bond with a higher level of G-d’s will; a bond that is established through teshuvah (Likkutei Torah; Toras Shmuel).cdliii*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… goel yïsərael
myđh - Baruch… Goeil Yisrael
rəeh na vəonyenu vərivah rivenu,
Please behold our oppression and wage our battle;
uǥəalenu məherah ləmään shəmëcha,
redeem us speedily for the sake of Your name,
ki el goel chazaq atah.
for You G-d are a strong Redeemer.
baruch ätah Adonai, goel yïsərael׃
Blessed are You, God, Redeemer of Israel.
rəeh na vəonyenu

Wage our battle – When the Jewish people’s spiritual level is low and, as a result, there are forces in both the material and spiritual realms that seek to do them harm, they appeal to G-d to act on their behalf. They request that His mercies be aroused and that He confront and vanquish these negative forces even when they would not necessarily prevail on their own based on the Torah’s strict scales of judgment (Maamarim Admor HaEmtza’i, Kuntreisim).cdlvii*

Waging battle requires might. On this basis, we can see the parallel between the intermediate blessings of the Shemoneh Esreh and the Divine attributes expressed by the Sefiros. The first intermediate blessing, asking for “wisdom, understanding, and knowledge,” is associated with the Sefirah of Chochmah. The second, requesting teshuvah, is associated with Binah, for Binah is the source of the higher dimension of teshuvah.611* The third intermediate blessing focuses on forgiveness and thus taps the Divine generosity motivated by the attribute of Chessed.612* Waging battles, the initial request of the blessing under discussion here, is associated with Gevurah, might. The following blessing, requesting healing, is associated with Tiferes, the quality that combines Chessed and Gevurah. After sickness, which also stems from Gevurah, G-d’s mercy which is associated with Tiferes is evoked, bringing about healing. Material prosperity, the theme of the eighth intermediate blessing, is associated with the attribute of Netzach (Derech Mitzvosecha).cdlviii*

Nevertheless, our intent in prayer is not merely to draw down the attributes as they currently exist Above, but to bring about a change in G-d’s will: that the sick be cured, blessings for material prosperity be evoked, and that Redemption become a reality. At present, G-d’s will is drawn down according to the Torah’s scales of judgment.613* To change His will and have His attributes function in a different manner – drawing down new blessings in all, or some, of these areas – it is necessary to tap a level of G-dliness above wisdom, the level identified as “the Master of [all] will”614* (Likkutei Torah; Toras Chayim).cdlix*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… rofe cholei ämmo yïsərael
myđh - Baruch… Rofei Cholei Amo Yisroel
rəfaenu Adonai vənerafe,
Heal us, O God, and we will be healed;
hoshienu vənïvasheah, ki təhïllatenu atah,
deliver us and we will be saved, for we take pride in praising You.
vəhääleh äruchah urəfuah shəlemah ləchal mäkoteinu,
Grant a complete and healing for all our wounds,
ki el mëlëch rofe nëëman vərächäman atah.
for You, Almighty King, are a faithful and merciful Healer.
baruch ätah Adonai, rofe cholei ämmo yïsərael׃
Blessed are You, God, Who heals the sick of His people Israel.
rəfaenu Adonai

Heal us, O G-d – There is a general question which applies to this blessing and to all the requests we make in prayer. Since a person’s judgment is decreed on Rosh HaShanah and sealed on Yom Kippur, how can that judgment be changed through prayer?619*

In resolution: A person’s judgment is indeed delivered and sealed on those days. At that time, the sublime kindness that is allotted to the person’s soul for the coming year is generated in the higher, spiritual realms. Nevertheless, for it to reach this material world and become enclothed in a physical form, it must be filtered through various intermediate levels. Concerning this, our Sages said: “A person is judged every day,” i.e., every day – i.e., in every phase of the above-mentioned descent – there is a judgment whether the person is worthy that the kindness be drawn down to the physical plane or whether he is not worthy of this. In the latter instance, the kindness remains within the spiritual realms.

When G-d’s will is aroused through prayer, His influence is drawn down speedily and does not become delayed in the intermediate spiritual planes. Instead, the influence allotted to the person on Rosh HaShanah and Yom Kippur rapidly becomes manifest on this material plane in all its fullness.

Moreover, in an ultimate sense, prayer has the potential to change a person’s situation entirely. Even if it has been decreed Above that a person will suffer, G-d forbid, prayer has the potential to overturn the decree. In several of our prayers, we say Yehi ratzon, literally “May there be a will.” Implied is that when one sincerely calls out to G-d, he can arouse a new Divine will and draw down health, material sustenance, and other Divine blessings.

Why does man’s prayer have this power? It is written:620* “You (G-d) will desire for the work of Your hands.” Our Rabbis621* interpret this to mean “G-d desires that the work of His hands (man) serve Him.” Extending that concept: Implicit in His desire for a dwelling in the lower realms is the wish that man ask for his needs. As such, those requests draw down influence from G-d’s very Essence (Likkutei Torah; Toras Shmuel; Sefer HaMaamarim Melukat).cdlxii*

In this blessing, a person should [also] have the intent that G-d should heal the spiritual infirmity that he brought upon himself through his sins. After asking for teshuvah, he asks that the blemishes in his soul be healed so that it will be a fit vessel to receive spiritual vitality (Pokeiach Ivrim).cdlxiii*

To explain the healing that is desired: In a physical sense, when a person is ill and runs a fever, his strength is sapped. Similarly, in the spiritual analogue, one can be consumed by “foreign fires” that weaken his devotion to the Torah and its mitzvos. Healing comes from fire from Above, as implied by the verse:622* “And Eliyahu healed the altar of G-d that was destroyed.” In the Biblical narrative, fire actually descended from Above upon the altar. Similarly, in a personal sense, the “fire from Above” consumes the “foreign fire” in one’s heart and enables his G-dly potential to burn brightly. This is the intent of the phrase “Heal us, O G-d, and we will be healed”: “Heal us,” by revealing fire from Above “and we will be healed” and enabled to reveal our own G-dly fire (Toras Shmuel).cdlxiv*

There is also an aspect of sickness that is associated with an advanced spiritual level, as implied by King Shlomoh’s exclamation:623* “I am lovesick,” i.e., the person is consumed by an insatiable yearning for G-dliness. In that vein, the AriZal explains624* that the Hebrew term chvlh, “a person who is sick,” is numerically equivalent to 49. For there are 50 Gates of Understanding.625* When a person has advanced spiritually but has not attained the fiftieth level, he will yearn for G-dliness to the extent that he is “lovesick.” The healing needed for this sickness can only be granted by G-d (Toras Menachem).cdlxv*

Our Sages626* explain that Refaeinu was instituted as the eighth blessing of the Shemoneh Esreh because healing is necessary for circumcision, which is carried out on the eighth day of a child’s life. There is a deeper point here. In a spiritual sense, the covenant of circumcision is identified with teshuvah and “teshuvah brings healing to the world.”627* The interconnection is further highlighted by the fact that both teshuvah and healing have their source in the Sefirah of Binah, the eighth Sefirah628* when counting upward.629* (Toras Shmuel).cdlxvi*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… məvarech häshshonim
myđh - Baruch… Mevareich Hashanim
barech aleinu Adonai ëloheinu ët häshshonoh häzzot,
Bless for us, God our Lord, this year
vəet kal minei təvuatah lətovah, vəten
and all varieties of its produce for good, and grant –
bərachah
in the summer: blessing
täl umatar lïvərachah
in the winter: dew and rain for blessing –
äl pənei haäđamah, vəsäbəenu mïttuvëcha,
upon the face of the earth and satiate us with Your bounty.
uvarech shənatenu käshshonim hättovot lïvərachah,
Bless our years like the good years, for blessing,
ki el tov umetiv ätah uməvarech häshshonim.
for You are a benevolent God Who bestows goodness and Who blesses the years.
baruch ätah Adonai, məvarech häshshonim׃
Bless are You, God, Who blesses the years.
barech aleinu Adonai ëloheinu ët häshshonoh häzzot

Bless for us… this year and all varieties of its produce for good – “Its produce” refers to both barley and wheat, which are interpreted631* as referring to nurture for the animal soul and the G-dly soul respectively632* (Derech Mitzvosecha).cdlxix*

There is a well-known adage of the Rebbe Rayatz:633* When asking [that G-d bless] “all the varieties of its produce for good,” we should have in mind the wheat to be used for matzah, and the esrog for the lulav on Sukkos (One source also adds the wine used for Kiddush). Then, as a matter of course, “all of the varieties of its produce” will prosper.634*

This suggestion does not contradict the simple meaning of the blessing, which refers to all kinds of produce. Rather, [the intent is that] the Torah is the source and the conduit for the creation of all things and for all the beneficent influence in the world. As the Sages say,635* G-d “looked into the Torah and created the world.”… Therefore if all the matters involving the Torah and its mitzvos are as they should be, all the material aspects of creation will also be as they should636* (HaYom Yom; the Rebbe’s Igros Kodesh).cdlxx*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… məqäbets nïđəchei ämmo yïsərael
myđh - Baruch… Mekabeitz Nidchei Amo Yisroel
təqä bəshofar gađol ləcherutenu,
Sound the great shofar for our freedom,
vəsa nes ləqäbets galüyyoteinu,
and raise a banner to gather in our dispersed exiles.
vəqäbətsenu yächäđ meärəbä känəfot haarëts ləärətsenu.
Gather us together from the four corners of the earth to our land.
baruch ätah Adonai, məqäbets nïđəchei ämmo yïsərael׃
Blessed are You, God, Who gathers in the dispersed exiles of His people Israel.
təqä bəshofar gađol

Sound the great shofar – This blessing echoes the verse which speaks of the ingathering of the exiles at the time of Mashiach’s arrival:641* “On that day, the great shofar will be sounded. Those lost in the land of Assyria and those who were banished to the land of Egypt will come and prostrate themselves before G-d on the holy mountain in Jerusalem.” The sounding of “the great shofar” refers to the revelation of G-dly light that transcends the entire framework of the Spiritual Cosmos.642*

When the great shofar will be sounded, even those who are “lost” and “banished” will be motivated to leave exile and flock to Jerusalem. This ingathering of the exiles will not come as a result of a process of intellectual choice, but as a spontaneous response to this revelation of essential G-dliness.643* Even the most estranged will feel as if he has, as it were, no choice but to ascend to Jerusalem (Likkutei Torah; Toras Shmuel Sefer HaMaamarim Melukat).cdlxxiii*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… mëlëch ohev tsəđaqah umïshəpat
myđh - Baruch… Melech Oheiv Tzedaka Umishpat
hashivah shofəteinu kəvarïshonah, vyoätseinu kəvätəchïllah,
Restore our judges as at first and our counselors as in the beginning.
vəhaser mïmmënnu yaǥon väänachah, uməloch aleinu
Remove from us sorrow and sighing, and reign over us,
ätah Adonai ləvädəcha bəchësëđ uvərächämim, bətsëđëq uvəmïshəpat.
You alone, O God, with kindness and mercy, with righteousness and justice.
baruch ätah Adonai, (hämmëlëch hämmïshəpat) mëlëch ohev tsəđaqah umïshəpat׃
During the Ten Days of Repentance, one should conclude: “the King of Justice.” Blessed are You, God, the King Who loves righteousness and justice.
hashivah shofəteinu kəvarïshonah

Restore our judges as at first – Based on our Sages’ interpretation,645* the term “our judges” can be understood as applying to the yetzer tov and the yetzer hara which serve as “judges” determining a Jew’s conduct.646* Now, at Sinai, the Jews’ impurity ceased647* and the tendencies of both of the “judges” were directed toward the good. In this blessing, we are requesting that the judges be restored to this ideal state (Or Torah).cdlxxvi*

And our counselors as in the beginning – This blessing echoes one of Yeshayahu’s prophecies of Redemption:648* “I will restore your judges as in former times and your advisors as of yore.” Since the revelations of the future are dependent on our present conduct,649* it follows that accepting the rulings of our judges and the counsel of our advisors hastens the fulfillment of that prophecy.

The terms “judges” and “counselors” are complementary, not redundant. A judge renders an objective ruling, communicating Torah law. An advisor, by contrast, does not dictate to his listeners. Instead, he relates to them on their level, giving them counsel that they understand and accept because they recognize that it will benefit them.

Both approaches should be incorporated into our Divine service. We must seek out “judges” who deliver clear rulings as to how we must conduct ourselves, and “advisors” who will explain to us how to internalize those rulings and shape our personalities to fit them (Sichos Shabbos Parshas Shoftim, 5751).cdlxxvii*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… shover oiəvim umächəniä zeđim
myđh - Baruch… Shoveir Oivim Umachnia Zeidim
vəlämmäləshinim äl təhi tïqəvah,
Let there be no hope for informers,
vəchal hämminim vəchal häzzeđim kərëǥä yoveđu,
may all the heretics and all the intentional transgressors perish instantly,
vəchal oiəvei ämməcha məherah yïkaretu,
and may all the enemies of Your people speedily be cut off.
umäləchut harïshəah məherah təäqqer utəshäber utəmäger, vətächəniä bïməherah vyameinu.
May You speedily uproot, destroy, crush, and subdue the wicked kingdom, speedily in our days.
baruch ätah Adonai, shover oiəvim umächəniä zeđim׃
Blessed are You, God, Who destroys the enemies and humbles the wicked.
vəlämmäləshinim

For the informers – In this blessing, one should focus his intent against all the accusing forces that were brought into being by his sins and now serve as negative influences against him in the sublime realms. For every undesirable deed that a person commits creates an accusing angel that causes him both spiritual and material difficulties, including problems in earning his livelihood and other types of physical suffering. At this point in prayer, one should request that all of these negative influences be removed from himself and from every member of the Jewish people (Pokeiach Ivrim).cdlxxx*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… mïshəan umïvətach lätstsädiqim
myđh - Baruch… Mishan Umivtach Latzadikim
äl hätstsädiqim vəäl hächäsiđim, vəäl zïqənei ämməcha beit yïsərael,
On behalf of the righteous, on behalf of the pious, on behalf of the elders of Your people, the House of Israel,
vəäl pəleität beit sofəreihëm, vəäl gerei hätstsëđëq vəaleinu,
on behalf of their surviving halls of learning, on behalf of the righteous converts, and on our own behalf:,
yëhëmu na rächämeicha Adonai ëloheinu, vəten sachar tov ləchal häbotəchim bəshïməcha bëëmët,
may Your mercies be aroused, God, our Lord. Grant a good reward for all those who genuinely trust in Your name.
vəsim chëləqenu ïmmahëm, uləolam lo nevosh ki vəcha batochənu.
Let us share their lot. May we never be abashed, because we trust in You.
baruch ätah Adonai, mïshəan umïvətach lätstsädiqim׃
Blessed are You, God, the support and the assurance.of the righteous.
yëhëmu na rächämeicha Adonai ëloheinu

Grant a good reward to all those who genuinely trust in Your name – Bitachon, trust in G-d, is not merely the faith that G-d has the potential to bestow good [upon a person] and save him from adversity. Instead, [it implies that] the person trusts that G-d will actually do so. And his trust is so absolute that he is serene and does not worry at all.

In that vein, the Rebbe Rayatz654* would refer to the adage of the Tzemach Tzedek:655* Tracht gut, vet zain gut (“Think positively, and the outcome will be good”). It is apparent from the Tzemach Tzedek’s words that thinking positively (having bitachon [in G-d]) will bring about a good outcome (in revealed and manifest good).

To explain: Bitachon is not merely a particular element (and a natural corollary) of the faith that everything is in G-d’s hands and that G-d is generous and merciful. Instead, bitachon means that a person will rely and depend solely on G-d to the extent that he casts his lot entirely upon Him, as it is written:656* “Cast your burden upon G-d,” i.e., the person depends on nothing in the world except G-d. And this effort and labor in developing bitachon in G-d itself evokes G-d’s kindness. Certainly, the person will not sit with “folded hands.” Instead, he will make a medium through which G-d’s blessings can be manifest in a natural manner. He will not, however, trust in his own efforts, but rather on G-d’s blessings.

When a person truly trusts in G-d alone from the depths of his soul — to the extent that he has no worry at all — his arousal [of trust] itself causes G-d to conduct Himself in an appropriate manner toward him, granting him kindness (even when, [on his own accord,] without taking this trust into account, he would be unworthy of such kindness)657* (Likkutei Sichos).cdlxxxiii*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… boneh yərushalaiïm
myđh - Baruch… Bonei Yerushalayim

vətïshəkon bətochah kääshër dïbärəta,
dwell within it, as You declared.
vəchïsse đavïđ ävədəcha məherah bətochah tachin,
Speedily establish the throne of David, Your servant, within it;
uvəneh otah bəqarov byameinu bïnyän olam.
rebuild it soon in our lifetime as an eternal structure.
baruch ätah Adonai, boneh yərushalaiïm׃
Blessed are You, God, Who rebuilds Jerusalem.
uvəneh otah bəqarov byameinu bïnyän olam

And build it soon, in our days, as an eternal structure – This refers to the building of the Third Beis HaMikdash, a G-dly building that will descend from heaven and enclothe itself in the physical Beis HaMikdash built by man. G-d’s presence will rest in it in a consummate manner. Hence, it will be an eternal structure658* (Igros Kodesh of the Rebbe Rashab).cdlxxxiv*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… mätsəmiäch qërën yəshuah
myđh - Baruch… Matzmiach Keren Yeshua
ët tsëmäch davïđ ävədəcha məherah tätsəmiäch,
Speedily cause the scion of David Your servant to sprout forth.
vəqärəno tarum bishuatëcha,
Raise his standard653* high with Your deliverance,
ki lishuotəcha qïuinu kal heeiom.
for we hope for.Your deliverance every day.
baruch ätah Adonai, mätsəmiäch qërën yəshuah׃

For we hope for Your deliverance the entire day – The root of the word qvynv, translated as “hope,” is qv, which also means “line.” A builder does not begin constructing a home until he has first drawn the blueprints of the structure. Similarly, through our good deeds, we have already charted the lines and created the mediums through which the Redemption will become manifest (Torah Or).cdlxxxv*

chy, translated as “for,” can also mean “because.” Even if we have no other merit, we are asking that G-d cause “the scion of David… to flourish” because “we have hoped for Your salvation” (Likkutei Sichos).cdlxxxvi*

The intent is not merely that every day we pray for Mashiach to ultimately come, but that every day, we pray for him to come that day. And we make this request not only every day, but “the entire day,” at every hour and at every moment throughout the day (Likkutei Sichos; Hisvaadios).cdlxxxvii*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… shomeä təfïllah

Hear our voice – This prayer in particular should be recited from the very depths of one’s heart, with bitterness of soul for his past sins and the intent of arousing manifold Divine mercies (Pokeiach Ivrim).cdlxxxviii*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… hämmächäzir shəchinato lətsion
myđh - Baruch… Hamachazir Shechinato Letzion
rətseh Adonai ëloheinu bəämməcha yïsərael vəlïtəfïllatam shəeh,
God, our Lord: Favor Your people Israel and heed their prayer.
vəhashev haävođah lïđəvir beitëcha, vəïshshei yïsərael utəfïllatam bəähävah təqäbel bəratson,
Restore the service to Your Sanctuary, and accept the fire-offerings of Israel and their prayers with love and with favor.
utəhi ləratson tamiđ ävođät yïsərael ämmëcha׃
May the service of Your people Israel always find favor.
vətëchëzeinah eineinu bəshuvəcha lətsion bərächämim.
May our eyes behold Your return to Zion in mercy.
baruch ätah Adonai, hämmächäzir shəchinato lətsion׃
Blessed are You, God, Who returns His Presence to Zion.
