G-d our Lord: Favor Your people Israel – rtsh shares the same root letters as the word rtsvn, meaning “will.” We are asking G-d to look at us from the standpoint of His ultimate will and desire (raava dichol raavin, rđch״r), i.e., from the level where He loves and desires us unconditionally, even when there might be logical reasons why these feelings would not be elicited from Him (Yahel Or).cdxci*
Siddur: The Amidah - mođim änächənu lach
myđh - Modim Anachnu Lach
mođim änächənu lach, shaätah hu Adonai ëloheinu velohei ävoteinu ləolam vaëđ,
We thankfully acknowledge You, that You are God, our Lord, and Lord of our fathers forever.
tsur cheeieinu, maǥen yïshəenu, ätah hu ləđor vađor,
You are the Rock of our lives, the Shield of our deliverance, from generation to generation.
nođëh ləcha unəsäper təhïllatëcha, äl cheeieinu hämməsurim byađëcha,
We will give thanks to You and recount Your praise – for our lives which are consigned to Your hand
vəäl nïshəmoteinu häpəquđot lach, vəäl nïsseicha shëbəchal yom ïmmanu,
and for our souls that are entrusted to You, for Your miracles that are with us each day,
vəäl nïfələoteicha vətovoteicha shëbəchal et, ërëv vavoqër vətsaharaiïm,
and for Your wonders and Your acts of goodness at all times, evening, morning and noon.
hättov, ki lo chalu rächämeicha,
[You are] the Beneficent One, for Your mercies have not ceased.
hämərächem, ki lo tämmu chäsađeicha,
[You are] the Merciful, for Your kindnesses have never ended.
ki meolam qïuinu lach׃
From the beginning of time, we have put our hope in You.
mođim änächənu lach

We thankfully acknowledge You - This is the literal meaning of the phrase. Nevertheless, as explained previously,668* the term modim, “acknowledge,” also possesses a second meaning: to accept an intellectual concept that one does not fully comprehend. One appreciates and acknowledges the truth of another’s position even though that position is above one’s own level of understanding and, as a result, cannot be altogether comprehended and internalized.

To explain: It is written:669* -l đvt y-h-v-h, meaning “G-d is a G-d of knowledge,” i.e., He is all-knowing.670* Nevertheless, the term đvt (knowledge) employs a plural form, indicating that G-d possesses two types of knowledge:671* one in which He knows the creations on His terms (daas elyon); i.e., He sees Himself as true existence (yesh amiti) and everything else as absolute nothingness (ayin);672* and another in which He knows the world as the created beings perceive it (daas tachton); that they exist as individual beings with their own identities (yesh), but they derive from a source that they cannot perceive (ayin).

Our hodaah, acknowledgment, implies our acceptance of G-d’s perspective. Even though we do not understand it and it runs contrary to our fundamental conception of our own existence, we go beyond ourselves and acknowledge that His perspective is the one that is most valid. We bow when reciting this blessing, giving physical expression to this inner process of self-transcendence.

This acknowledgment lies at the very core of our being, as indicated by the fact that the Hebrew term for Jew, Yehudi (yhvđy) shares the same root letters as the term hodaah (hvđh), acknowledgment. Who is a Jew? One who by nature goes beyond his own way of looking at the world and strives to view it from G-d’s perspective. (Torah Or; Likkutei Torah; Derech Mitzvosecha).cdxcv*

More particularly, this acknowledgment connects us with G-d’s Essence. For hodaah is not necessary to relate merely to the limited dimension of G-dliness that enclothes itself within the created beings (the level of memale kol almin). On the contrary, this lower dimension of G-dliness can – and should – be perceived through contemplation. To a certain extent, this is true even of the level of G-dly light that transcends our existence, the level that is sovev kol almin. For even though we cannot comprehend that level in the same manner we understand finite existence, we can gain some understanding of this level of light through the process called yedias hashelilah (negative knowledge).673* His Essence, by contrast, is utterly above comprehension. At this level, all that is possible is to acknowledge His being (Likkutei Torah; Toras Shmuel).cdxcvi*

Hod is also one of the Sefiros. Kabbalistically it is identified with the left thigh. Now, among the limbs of the body, the thighs are among the most physically distant from the brain. Similarly, their function is not related to intellectual contemplation. This relates to the concept of acknowledgment mentioned previously; that one accepts a principle that he does not understand. Nevertheless, it is with his thighs that a person strides forward; advancing even in the face of obstacles674* (Shaarei Orah).cdxcvii*

There are several levels of hodaah that we express in the course of our daily Divine service. Immediately upon arising in the morning, we recite Modeh Ani. At the beginning of our prayers, we proclaim Hodu LaA-donai. In the Shemoneh Esreh, we recite the blessing Modim Anachnu Lach. And at the conclusion of our prayers, we state: Ach Tzaddikim Yodu Lishmecha (“Indeed, the righteous will thankfully acknowledge Your name”).

The initial stage of thankful acknowledgment is not at all an intellectual one. On the contrary, the person has just arisen. He is not ready for contemplation; indeed, before washing, it is forbidden for him to think thoughts of Torah.675* His acknowledgment of G-d is visceral; an instinctive response to his G-dly soul being returned to him.

The acknowledgments made in prayer, by contrast, are associated with one’s contemplation of G-d’s greatness.676* Implied is that the person’s acknowledgment filters through and changes the approach of his intellectual powers. He acknowledges G-d, not only with the dimension of his soul that transcends reason and logic, but also with his reason and logic themselves. His mind comprehends that it must acknowledge truth above understanding. As such, these acknowledgments are far more encompassing, both in the appreciation of G-d and their effect on an individual’s character677* (Likkutei Sichos).cdxcviii*
Siddur: The Amidah - mođim đəräbanan
myđh - Modim Derabbanan
mođim änächənu lach, shaׁätah hu yəhovah ëloheinu velohei ävoteinu, ëlohei chal-bashaׁr, yotsərenu yotser bəreshïׁyt.
We thankfully acknowledge You, for You are God, our Lord, and God of our fathers, the Lord of all flesh, our Creator, the Creator of the universe.
bərachot vəhođaot ləshïׁməcha hägađol vəhäqqađosh, äl shëׁhëchëyitanu vəqiiämətanu.
[We will recite] blessings and prayers of thanksgiving to Your great and holy name for having granted us life and having maintained our existence.
ken təcheiienuutəchannenuvətëësof galüyyoteinu ləchätsərot qođəshëׁcha,
May You continue to grant us life and maintain our existence, and may You gather our dispersed exiles to Your holy courtyards.
lïshׁmor chüqqeicha vəlääsot rətsonəcha uləovəđəcha vəlevav shaׁlem,
We will return to You, observe Your decrees, perform Your will, and serve You wholeheartedly.
äl shëׁänächənu mođim lach, baruch el hähođaot.
[We are grateful for the privilege] of thankfully acknowledging You. Blessed is God, [to Whom] thanksgiving [is befitting].
mođim änächənu lach, shaׁätah hu yəhovah ëloheinu

We thankfully acknowledge You: that You are G-d our Lord – Elokeinu, translated as "our Lord,"is the possessive form of G-d's name Elokim. Elokim is associated with the natural vitality and strength the Creator imbued in every created being. "G-d" is translating the name Havayah, the name of G-d that refers to His transcendence and is rooted in His inner thought. By saying Havayah Elokeinu, we are emphasizing that our strength and vitality is rooted in G-d's name Havayah;i.e., His transcendence and His inner thought.319*

As a natural consequence of His being "G-d our Lord" and our being rooted in His inner thought, our souls instinctively acknowledge His existence. They have no need for signs or wonders to prove His being, as it were.

Although this acknowledgment is an inherent tendency of our G-dly souls, our bodies' influence creates a conflict and this awareness does not naturally arise within our thought. To highlight the need for us to bring this acknowledgment into our conscious thinking, our Sages ordained the recitation of Modim by the congregation in the repetition of the Shemoneh Esreh (Modim D'Rabbanan).

Coupling the beginning of this prayer with its conclusion produces the concept: mvđym nchnv lch . . . l shnv mvđym, "We thankfully acknowledge You… [for the privilege] of thankfully acknowledging You."

To explain: There is a level of acknowledgment that is associated with comprehension. For example, a wise man acknowledges the supremacy of a wiser person's wisdom. He understands what wisdom is and appreciates that the other person's wisdom is greater than his own. (This appreciation is still considered "acknowledgment," because he does not fully comprehend the depth of that person's wisdom.) On a lower rung, there is a level of acknowledgment below understanding. For example, a simple and uneducated person will term a scholar wise. He does not appreciate any of his wisdom, but he does recognize that this is a wise man. Similarly, as the soul exists within the body, it loses awareness of spiritual reality and does not comprehend G-dliness, it merely acknowledges that G-d must be acknowledged (Siddur Im Dach).clxvii*

Our Sages state320*Modim will not arise at the time of the Resurrection of the Dead. To explain: At the time of the Resurrection, the souls who have passed on will again be enclothed in physical bodies entirely similar to the bodies in which our souls are housed.321*Nevertheless, people will not require physical food because their bodies will derive satisfaction and nourishment from the revelation of the Divine presence, as Moshe did when he ascended to receive the Tablets of the Ten Commandments. Moshe did not eat or drink for forty days and forty nights322*323*

The rewards of the era of the Resurrection are dependent on our Divine service at the present time.324*Modim, he is acknowledging – even though he may not fully understand the matter – that there is a transcendent Divine life-force that "grants us life and sustains us." Now, in the era of the Resurrection, the G-dliness that energizes the world will become openly apparent: "All flesh will see that the mouth of G-d has spoken."325*Maamarei Admor HaZakein HaKetzarim; Toras Chayim).clxviii*

Instead, our Sages relate326*Modim – will become a snake, the animal used to symbolize the very antithesis of holiness. As long as a person is able to summon up the spiritual energy to make this most basic acknowledgment of G-d, he has a connection to the realm of holiness and there is hope that his bond will eventually blossom into fullness. If, however, he lacks this fundamental awareness, holiness is utterly foreign to him and he has cut himself off from its vitalizing energy (Likkutei Torah; Toras Menachem).clxix*

To explain yet another connection between bowing during the recitation of Modim and the Resurrection of the Dead: As mentioned above, one’s acknowledgment of G-d relates to His very Essence327*Maamarei Admor HaZakein).clxx*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… hättov shïməcha uləcha naëh ləhođot
myđh - Baruch… Hatov Shimcha Nae Lehodot
vəäl küllam yïtəbarech vyïtəromam vyïtənäshse shïməcha mäləkenu tomiđ ləolam vaëđ׃
For all of these, may Your name, our King, be blessed, uplifted and elevated continually and for all time.
(uchətov ləcheeiim tovim kal bənei vəritëcha׃)
During the Ten Days of Repentance add: Inscribe all the members of Your covenant for a good life.
vəchal hächeeiim yođucha sëlah,
And all living beings shall give thanks to You for eternity,
vihäləlu shïməcha hägađol ləolam ki tov,
and they shall praise Your great name forever, for it is good;
hael yəshuatenu vəëzəratenu sëlah, hael hättov.
God is our salvation and our everlasting Help, the benevolent God.
baruch ätah Adonai, hättov shïməcha uləcha naëh ləhođot׃
Blessed are You, God, Whose name is goodness; to You it is fitting to offer thanks.
vəchal hächeeiim yođucha sëlah

And all living beings shall give thanks to You for eternity – G-d’s infinite light shines into the souls of the Jewish people, enabling them to continually ascend to higher levels of Divine light. At each level, their connection with G-d begins with hodaah, thankful acknowledgment. Thus the process of thanksgiving is ongoing and eternal (Likkutei Torah).dviii*
Siddur: The Amidah - baruch… häməvarech ët ämmo yïsərael bäshsholom
myđh - Baruch… Hamevarech Et Amo Yisrael Bashalom
sim shalom, tovah uvərachah, cheeiim chen vachësëđ vərächämim, aleinu vəäl kal yïsərael ämmëcha.
Bestow peace,696* goodness, blessing, life, grace, kindness and mercy upon ourselves and upon all of Israel, Your people.
borəchenu avinu küllanu kəëchađ bəor paneicha,
Bless us,697* our Father,698* all as one, in the light699* of Your countenance.
ki vəor paneicha natäta lanu Adonai ëloheinu torät cheeiim vəähävät chësëđ,
For in the light of Your countenance, God our Lord, You have given us the Torah of life700* and a love of kindness,701*
utsəđaqah uvərachah vərächämim vəcheeiim vəshalom,
righteousness,702* blessing, mercy, life,703* and peace.704*
vətov bəeineicha ləvarech ët ämməcha yïsərael bəchal et uvəchal shaah bïshəlomëcha.
May it be favorable in Your eyes to bless Your people Israel705* at all times706* and at every hour707* with Your peace.
(uvəsefër cheeiim bərachah vəshalom ufärənasah tovah, yəshuah vənëchamah uǥəzerot tovot, nïzzacher vənïkatev ləfaneicha, änächənu vəchal ämməcha beit yïsərael, ləcheeiim tovim uləshalom.)
During the Ten Days of Repentance add: And in the Book of life, blessing, peace, generous sustenance, deliverance, consolation, and good decrees, may we and Your entire people, the House of Israel, be remembered and inscribed before You for a good life and for peace.
baruch ätah Adonai, häməvarech ët ämmo yïsərael bäshsholom׃
Blessed are You, God, Who blesses His people Israel with peace.708*
sim shalom

Bestow peace – After drawing down G-d’s blessings in the preceding blessings of the Shemoneh Esreh, we conclude by praying for peace. As our Sages state,709* “The Holy One, blessed be He, could not find a medium to contain His blessing other than peace.”710* Peace draws down abundant blessing even for transgressors. As our Sages comment711* regarding the soldiers of King Achav: “Even though they were idolaters, they were protected and granted blessing because of the peace and unity that prevailed among them.” Certainly, this applies to those who observe His will (Or HaTorah).dx*
Siddur: The Amidah - yïhyu ləratson
myđh - Yihyu Leratzon
yïhyu ləratson ïmərei fi vəhëǥyon lïbi ləfaneicha, Adonai tsuri vəǥoäli׃
May the words of my mouth and the thoughts of my heart find favor before You, God, my Rock and my Redeemer.
Siddur: The Amidah - ë־lohei, nətsor ləshoni mera
myđh - Elokay Netzor Leshoni Meira
ëlohei, nətsor ləshoni mera, usəfatei mïdäber mïrəmah,
My God, guard my tongue from evil and my lips from speaking deceitfully.
vəlïməqäləlei näfəshi tïdom, vənäfəshi këafar läkol tïhyëh.
Let my soul be mute to those who curse me and let my soul be as dust before all.
pətäch lïbi bətoratëcha, uvəmïtsəoteicha tïrədof näfəshi,
Open my heart to Your Torah and let my soul pursue Your commandments.
vəchal hächoshəvim alei raah, məherah hafer ätsatam vəqäləqel mächäshävətam.
May You speedily nullify the counsel and ruin the designs of all those who devise evil against me.
yïhyu kəmots lïfənei ruäch umäləäch Adonai dochëh.
May they be like chaff before the wind; may the angel of God thrust them away.
ləmään yecholətsun yəđiđeicha, hoshiah yəminəcha vääneni.
So that Your cherished ones will be rescued, bring deliverance with Your right hand and answer me.
äseh ləmään shəmëcha, äseh ləmään yəminëcha,
Do this for the sake of Your name; do this for the sake of Your right hand;
äseh ləmään toratëcha, äseh ləmään qəđüshshotëcha.
do this for the sake of Your Torah; do this for the sake of Your holiness.
yïhyu ləratson ïmərei fi vəhëǥyon lïbi ləfaneicha, Adonai tsuri vəǥoäli׃
May the words of my mouth and the thoughts of my heart find favor before You, God, my Rock and My Redeemer.
osëh (häshsholom) sholom bïməromaiv,
May He Who brings about peace – During the Ten Days of Repentance, one should say HaShalom, “the peace”
hu yääsëh shalom aleinu vəäl kal yïsərael, vəïməru amen׃
in His lofty realms bring about peace for us and for all Israel. Let all say: Amen.
yəhi ratson mïlləfaneicha, Adonai ëloheinu velohei ävoteinu,
May it be Your will God – our Lord, and Lord of our fathers –
sheeiïbanëh beit hämmïqədash bïməherah vyameinu, vəten chëləqenu bətoratëcha׃
that the Temple be built speedily in our days, and grant us our portion in Your Torah.
vəlïməqäləlei näfəshi tïdom

May my soul be as dust to all – Dust is an analogy for a consummate level of humility; everyone treads on it.718* Similarly, a person whose “soul is like dust” has no independent will of his own. His motivation is solely G-d’s will as revealed in the Torah (Igros Kodesh of the Rebbe Rayatz; Toras Menachem).dxvii*

As mentioned,719* the recitation of the Shemoneh Esreh should be characterized by bittul, standing before G-d like “a servant before his master.”720* By saying “May my soul be as dust” at the conclusion of the Shemoneh Esreh, we request that this mindset accompany us throughout the remainder of the day (Likkutei Torah).dxviii*

Such humility enables a person to reveal his inner spiritual powers. In that vein, it is explained that “the dust,” hfr, shares the same letters as Pharaoh (frh). In this context, Pharaoh is understood as a positive force, a power of revelation, for its root letters reflect that meaning as indicated by the verse,721* “And he will reveal (fr) the [hairs] of the woman’s head.” Similarly, humility, making oneself like dust, enables a person to strip away the haughtiness and self-concern that leads to material desire and stubbornness. Even if a person has not sinned, he must realize that there is a shell of kelipah covering him. Humility removes this shell and enables his inner spiritual powers to gain expression. As our Sages state:722* It is when an olive is crushed that it releases its oil.

Ideally, a person should bring out this state of humility of his own accord; he should not wait for hardship and difficulty to do so for him. In that vein, the Torah commands us,723* “And you shall circumcise the foreskin of your hearts,” removing the thick-skinned layers of ego that conceal our inner spiritual powers, on our own initiative (Torah Or; Likkutei Torah).dxix*

Experiencing the bittul of “May my soul be as dust to all” in a consummate manner will save the Jewish people from the purifying step of “return[ing] to dust” before the Resurrection (Sefer HaMaamarim Melukat).dxx*
Siddur: Viduy And Tachnun - ë־loheinu ve־lohei ävoteinu
vyđvy vtchnvn - Elokeinu Velokei Avoteinu
ëloheinu velohei ävoteinu, tavo ləfaneicha təfïllatenu,
Our God and God of our fathers, may our prayer come before You.
vəäl tïtəälläm mïtəchïnnatenu, shëein anu äzzei fanim uqəshei orëf,
Do not ignore our pleas, for we are not so brazen and stubborn as –
lomär ləfaneicha Adonai ëloheinu velohei ävoteinu,
to say before You, God, our Lord, and Lord of our fathers,
tsädiqim änächənu vəlo chatanu, äval änächənu väävoteinu chatanu׃
“We are righteous and we have not sinned,” for we and our fathers have sinned:
ëloheinu velohei ävoteinu

Our G-d and G-d of our fathers – On the surface, one might ask: Why is it necessary to recite this confessional prayer verbally? G-d, in His omniscience, sees into our hearts and is aware of our regrets even without our verbal confession.

In resolution, it can be explained that the confessional prayer is recited verbally in order to arouse G-d’s mercies Above. Spelling out the extent of the descent the soul has experienced evokes G-d’s mercy.

The concept that the purpose of reciting this prayer is to arouse G-d’s mercy enables us to understand why we begin this prayer by saying “Our G-d….” As explained frequently, this term refers to G-d as “our strength and our vitality,” pointing to the G-dly soul that exists within each of us. Focusing on the inner Divine potential that we all possess highlights the radical descent that our souls have undergone in becoming enclothed in our bodies and the unfortunate consequences that sometimes result from this descent. When a person makes such a statement, great mercy is aroused Above that in turn awakens a love within the person for G-d (Likkutei Torah).dxxxiv*
Siddur: Viduy And Tachnun - ashämənu
vyđvy vtchnvn - Ashamnu
ashämənu. baǥäđənu. gazälənu.
We have been culpable, we have been unfaithful, we have robbed,
dïbärənu dofi׃ hëëvinu. vəhïrəshäənu.
we have cast aspersions; we have been perverse, and we have acted wickedly,
zäđənu. chamäsənu. tafälənu shëqër׃
we have sinned intentionally, we have acted violently, we have falsely ascribed guilt;
yaätsənu ra. kïzzävənu. lätsənu. maräđənu.
we have given bad counsel, we have lied, we have scoffed, we have rebelled,
nïätsənu. sarärənu. avinu. pashäənu.
we have vexed, we have been defiant, we have committed iniquity, we have transgressed,
tsarärənu. qïshshinu orëf׃ rashäənu.
we have oppressed, we have been stiff-necked; we have committed evil,
shïchätənu. tïävənu. tainu. tïətaənu׃
we have acted decadently, we have acted abominably, we have strayed, and we have led others astray.
särənu mïmmïtsəoteicha umïmmïshəpateicha hättovim vəlo shavah lanu׃
We have deviated from Your good commandments and precepts without gain.
vəätah tsädiq äl kal häba aleinu, ki ëmët asita väänächənu hïrəshaənu׃
You are just in all that has come upon us, for You have acted in truth, whereas we have acted wickedly.
ashämənu

We have been culpable – Seemingly, this confessional prayer should be recited at the very beginning of our prayers, for a sinner should ask for forgiveness before embarking on prayer.

In resolution: before prayer, a person may be spiritually complacent and insensitive to the subtle dimensions of evil within his soul. In prayer, however, when he meditates on G-d’s greatness, desires to come close to Him, and yet feels he cannot, he will find vestiges of evil that are acting as a barrier between G-d and himself and must be removed. For sin causes separation not only between man and G-d, but between the person’s conscious thought and his inner Divine potential.749* The greater one’s desire to come close to G-d, the more aware he will be of the obstacles placed in his path by the evil he created within his soul through his sins,750* and the more he will desire to remove them (Toras Shmuel).dxxxv*

Teshuvah involves sincere regret over one’s misdeeds. These penitential feelings correct the blemishes created by the desires and cravings that motivated his sins. Nevertheless, these feelings of regret cannot expunge the actual deed of sin. In His kindness, however, G-d has allowed for the recitation of the confessional prayer to be considered as deed and thereby obliterate the influence of those negative deeds.751* (Moreover, the letters of his words of confession correct the blemishes of the letters of the foreign thoughts that plague a person at all times.)

Regret and confession, however, must be coupled together. For obviously, it does not suffice to merely recite the words of confession. Moreover, it is the feelings in one’s heart that awaken and draw down a new will from G-d, causing Him to accept a person despite his sins (Likkutei Torah; Derech Mitzvosecha; Toras Menachem).dxxxvi*

The above concepts can be amplified through an explanation of our Sages’ statement:752* “Great is teshuvah because it brings healing to the world.” Physically, health is associated with an unimpeded flow of blood throughout the body. Any obstruction in the circulatory system is dangerous and damages the person’s health. So too, a person’s spiritual health involves drawing down spiritual vitality from “the heart” – corresponding to the outpouring of his spiritual emotions in prayer – to energize and inspire the observance of the mitzvos, his spiritual limbs and organs.753* Sin, however, creates an obstruction, preventing this flow of spiritual energy. Through teshuvah and confession, the obstruction is removed, enabling a person to function with spiritual vitality in all of his activities throughout the day (Torah Or).dxxxvii*

Confession is a humbling experience and it thus humbles the forces of kelipah that have taken control of the person. Subjugating the forces of the sitra achra in this manner arouses G-d’s mercy and love. Moreover, the fact that the person makes this request while feeling distant from Him arouses His unbounded mercy and love. Spiritual advances made within one’s ongoing pattern of Divine service arouse only incremental Divine love. When, however, one calls to Him from a distance, the Divine love aroused is without limits (Likkutei Torah; Maamarei Admor HaZakein).dxxxviii*

The confessional prayer is recited by everyone, even by individuals who are far removed from the sins to which they confess. The rationale is that all Jews are spiritually interrelated and thus responsible for each other’s actions (rvym zh vzh).754* Thus the Jewish people as a whole are described with the analogy of the human body. Just as the healthy head feels the pain of a wounded foot, so too, those who are righteous and spiritually developed feel the pain caused by the conduct of sinners. By reciting the confessional prayer, a righteous man purges the effect of the sins of the wicked from his own soul. Furthermore, because of the interrelationship mentioned above, his confession also has an effect on the sins of the wicked themselves, rectifying them to a certain degree.

Moreover, in truth, it is fitting for every person, even individuals who are far removed from sin, to recite the confessional prayer not only because of others, but for himself as well. No matter how refined his conduct is, when one contemplates the lofty source of his soul in the spiritual realms Above and the descent it has undergone, he will find his deeds lacking. (True, he may not have committed the precise sins mentioned, but when considered in the abstract, he can find parallels in his conduct to all of them.) (Maamarei Admor HaZakein; Or HaTorah; Sefer Maamarim Melukat).dxxxix*
Siddur: Viduy And Tachnun - e־l ërëch äpeiïm
vyđvy vtchnvn - Keil Erech Apayim

Almighty God, You are slow to anger and You are called the Master of mercy. You have shown the path of repentance.

On this day, and on every day, remember the greatness of Your mercies and Your kindness to the descendants of Your loved one.
tefën eleinu bərächämim, ki ätah hu bääl harächämim.
Turn to us in mercy, for You are the Master of mercy.

We will approach Your Presence with supplication and prayer, in the manner that You made known to the humble one in days of yore.

“He invoked the name of God,” and there it was said:
Siddur: Viduy And Tachnun - veeiäävor h׳ äl panaiv
vyđvy vtchnvn - Vayaavor Hashem Al Panav
veeiäävor Adonai äl panaiv veeiïqəra׃
The following Thirteen Attributes of Divine Mercy are recited only when praying with a quorum: And G-d passed before him and proclaimed:
Adonai yya el rächum vəchännun ërëch äpeiïm
God, God, the Almighty Who is merciful, gracious, slow to anger,
vəräv chësëđ vëëmët׃ notser chësëđ laälafim
abounding in kindness, and true. He preserves kindness for thousands of generations;
nose aon vafëshä vəchättaah vənäqqeh׃
He forgives iniquity, transgression, and sin; He cleanses.
veeiäävor Adonai äl panaiv

And G-d passed before him – In a literal context, the subject of the pronoun in the Hebrew term l fnyv, translated as “before him,” is Moshe – G-d passed before Moshe. On a deeper level, the term can be interpreted as referring to G-d Himself: that He “passed over His face.” “His face” (fnyv) refers to the ten Sefiros. They are identified with G-d to the extent that they are referred to as “His names.” Nevertheless, they are but garments that cover and veil G-d’s Essence.755* When G-d reveals the Thirteen Attributes of Mercy, He “passes over” these veils so that His inner and essential dimension shines forth.

The complete revelation of this motif will be in the Ultimate Future when, in our Sages’ words,756* G-d will “remove the sun from its sheath.” In a spiritual sense, however, a microcosm of this revelation is also possible within our souls at present. We can call forth this revelation through our humble and sincere arousal of Divine mercy over the great descent that our souls have undergone through its descent within a physical body. Beseeching His Divine mercy enables His mercy to reach us even as we exist on these lower levels (Likkutei Torah).dxl*
Siddur: Viduy And Tachnun - rächum vəchännun
vyđvy vtchnvn - Rachum Vechanun
rächum vəchännun chatanu ləfaneicha rächem aleinu vəhoshienu׃
Merciful and gracious One, we have sinned before You; Have mercy on us and save us.
rächum vəchännun chatanu ləfaneicha rächem aleinu vəhoshienu

The following passage – known as nefilas apayim, prostration – is recited while seated. – There are two stages of bittul that converge at this stage in prayer:

The first is the bittul that accompanies the Shemoneh Esreh prayers: they are recited in a hushed tone, while standing. Although the manner in which this prayer is recited reflects bittul,761* the person is, nevertheless, still capable of speaking;

The second is the prostration that follows in the Tachanun prayers. The person is so overwhelmed with bittul that he cannot even stand on his feet. Instead, he prostrates himself, lying prone with his head and feet on the same level.762* At this point, he is silent, unable to speak at all.763*

All of a person’s spiritual ascents involve bittul, nullifying oneself to a higher truth. Generally, however, the person’s own identity is not effaced entirely. When, however, he ascends close enough to gain an awareness of the essence of the higher level, he reaches a second and more encompassing level of bittul, that of prostration and utter silence

To explain by analogy: A simple villager who has never seen a king or his court will be overcome with awe and dread from his first impressions of the king, his retinue and his palace. Nevertheless, this does not represent an all-encompassing awareness of the king. On the contrary, his perception is underdeveloped, almost childish. As a result, his selfhood is also not shaken to the core. It is only when the villager becomes more familiar with the king and his court that he is able to gain a genuine appreciation of the king’s greatness. Only then does his bittul become truly comprehensive (Siddur Im Dach; Likkutei Torah; Shaarei Teshuvah).dxliv*

When a penitent falls on his face, he should humble himself greatly, accepting the spiritual punishments for his sins, even the four forms of death as stated in the recitation of the Shema before retiring. This bittul enables the person to elevate the sparks of holiness that have fallen into the realm of kelipah764* (Pokeiach Ivrim; Toras Chayim).dxlv*

In one sense, falling on one’s face after the recitation of the Shemoneh Esreh represents a descent. The person identifies with the sparks of G-dliness that have fallen, so that he can elevate them. This connects with the theme mentioned previously: that this state of prayer represents utter self-effacement to the point that it is comparable to death. In that vein, the writings of the AriZal associate765* falling on one’s face with the Ten Martyrs.766* In other sources767* it is stated that it reflects complete mesirus nefesh, self-sacrifice. For it is only through utter self-sacrifice that one can motivate oneself to descend to the place where the sparks have fallen in order to elevate them.

The descent required for this type of Divine service involves both challenge and danger. Ultimately, to navigate this path successfully, one must be bonded with the leaders of the Jewish people. When such a connection is established, then – as the Rebbe Rayatz would say768* – “when one is connected Above, he does not fall below” (Toras Menachem).dxlvi*
Siddur: Viduy And Tachnun - ləđavïđ, eleicha h׳
vyđvy vtchnvn - Ledavid Elecha Hashem
ləđavïđ, eleicha Adonai näfəshi ëshsa׃
For David: To you God, I present my soul.

ləđavïđ

To You, God, I present my soul – According to the Kabbalah,769* after prostrating oneself in Nefilas Apayim, a person should recite this psalm.770* To explain the motif: In the Shemoneh Esreh prayer, and particularly in the prostration after the Shemoneh Esreh prayer, we bond with G-d to the extent that we lose our individual identities entirely.

By saying, “To You, O G-d, I will raise up my soul,” we express our desire for this bond to: a) relate to G-d’s very Essence, above all revealed levels; and b) be entirely complete, to the extent of total self-sacrifice. In this vein, the Zohar interprets “raising up one’s soul to G-d” as dedicating one’s soul to Him in a consummate manner. The person should be empty of personal feelings and desires as if he died, feeling nothing of his personal self at all. His bittul should be so complete that it is as if he has ceased to exist.

Expressing this bittul at this point in prayer enables a person to extend his bond with G-d throughout the day, even when one is involved in his physical activities. Making this declaration thus serves as a pledge to maintain this bond in an ongoing manner, connecting our thought to G-d’s thought, our speech to His speech through the letters of the Torah and prayer, and our deeds to His deeds through the performance of His mitzvos. Such conduct is indeed an expression of self-sacrifice. For self-sacrifice does not mean shouting loudly, visibly demonstrating one’s burning love for G-d, but rather involves an ongoing commitment never to separate oneself from Him, entirely subjugating one’s will to His.771* For what greater self-sacrifice is there than living one’s life without thinking of material matters at all, but instead binding oneself to G-d through the Torah and its mitzvos. Indeed, a person should feel as if his soul has already left his body, a state where material desires no longer entice him (Tanya; the Alter Rebbe’s Shulchan Aruch; Likkutei Torah; Maamarim Admor HaEmtza’i, Kuntreisim; Toras Shmuel; the series of maamarim entitled BeShaah SheHikidimu, 5672; Toras Menachem).dxlvii*dxlviii*

vəhu rächum yəchäper

He is merciful, forgiving — In chassidic thought, a distinction is made between addressing G-d in the second person, “You,” or referring to Him in the third person, “He.” “You” refers to a level of G-dliness which we can comprehend; as a result, we address Him directly. "He" refers to a level of G-dliness too lofty to be perceived directly. Indeed, it cannot be described by any name and for that reason, a pronoun is used. In an ultimate sense, it can be seen as referring to G-d's Essence, which defies all description.

There are levels of Divine mercy that are generous, but which conform to the limits of the Spiritual Cosmos. These levels of mercy are not sufficient to bring about abundant forgiveness. To accomplish that, unbounded mercies must be drawn down from G-d's Essence, a level where no limits exist (Peirush HaMilos; Sichos Admur HaRayatz).clxxi*
Siddur: Viduy And Tachnun - hätteh ëloqei ozənəcha

chonnénu väänénu, ki ləcha Adonai hätstsəđaqah, oseh nïfəlaot bəchal et:
Be gracious unto us and answer us, for charity is Yours, O God, Who performs wonders at all times.
hätteh ëlohei ozənəcha ushəma

Incline Your ear, my G-d, and listen — In chassidicthought, this verse is cited as the springboard for a discussion of a question of a more general nature: When we call to G-d in prayer and refer to Him with one of His names, are we relating to the Sefirah associated with that particular name or are we referring to His Essence?

The Baal Shem Tov explains that although every one of the names of G-d is associated with a given Sefirah, when we call to Him, we are calling to His Essence. Nevertheless, the request we make of Him is addressed to one of His names, for it is through the medium of these names that His Essence provides influence (Or HaTorah).clxxv*

For You, O God, we hope; for You, O God, we are waiting; for You, O God, do we long.

zəchor läävađéicha ləävəraham lyïtsəchaq ulyääqov

Remember for the sake of Your servants, for Avraham, Yitzchak and Yaakov — To explain by analogy: a businessman will undertake a long journey because he expects to turn a considerable profit. In order to make the journey, he must make many preparations and set up the groundwork for his activities. Sometimes, it is possible that in the process of planning these activities, he will get so swept up in the momentum of his preparations that he will focus on the secondary aspects of the journey and forget the fundamental purpose: the profit he seeks to gain.

Similarly Above, G-d created the world because He desired a dwelling in the lower realms, and that dwelling is brought about through the Divine service of the Jewish people. To make that possible, He also created an entire world in which that purpose can be fulfilled. Although there is a Divine desire for every element of existence, that desire is of a secondary nature. Since He desires the Torah observance of the Jewish people, He also desires the entire framework in which that desire can be expressed.345*346*Or HaTorah).clxxx*

The request is not that G-d remember the Patriarchs themselves, but that He remember and see their merit as manifest in our own Divine service. Each of the Patriarchs endowed us with a dimension of love for G-d, as reflected in the threefold command: "Love G-d with all your heart, with all your soul, and with all your might." When the Jewish people manifest these three forms of love for G-d, they highlight and evoke the recollection of the merit of their ancestors on High (Toras Shmuel).clxxxi*

vyđvy vtchnvn - Haposeach Yad

äl tïshəkachénu në́tsäch, q́umah vəhoshiénu.
Do not forget us forever. Arise and deliver us.
vəäl tïshəpoch chäronəcha aléinu, ki änä́chənu ämməcha bənei vəritë́cha.

orərah ǥəvurotəcha vəhoshiénu ləmä́än shəmë́cha,
Arouse Your might and deliver us for the sake of Your name.
vəäl yïməätu ləfanéicha təlaotéinu.

mäher yəqädəḿunu rächäméicha bəet tsaraténu,

äl tïshəkachénu në́tsäch

Do not forget us forever — On the physical plane, forgetfulness results from limitations in one's knowledge. Were a person to have thoroughly mastered a subject with all its details and complexities, he would not forget what he learned. Since, however, his knowledge is limited, it will weaken and fade over the course of time. Similarly, in the spiritual realms, forgetfulness — the possibility that the awareness of the importance of a given entity will fade — comes from a level of G-dliness that is limited in nature and can thus be affected by the conduct of the created beings.

How can we assure that we will not be forgotten? By expressing an unlimited and boundless commitment toG-d. This, in turn, will call forth Divine light that knows no limitation, the G-dly encompassing light that is sovev kol almin. When this level of Divine light is revealed within the world, the prominence of the Jewish people becomes manifest (Sefer HaMaamarim Melukat).clxxxiv*

vyđvy vtchnvn - Shuv Mecharon Apecha

God, Lord of Yisrael, turn away from the fury of Your wrath and relent from the evil [to be brought against] Your people.*
Siddur: Viduy And Tachnun - häbet mïshshoméiïm urəeh
vyđvy vtchnvn - Habeit Mishamayim Uray
häbet mïshshoméiïm urəeh, ki haíinu lä́äǥ vaqë́lës bägoiïm,
Gaze down from heaven and see that we have become an object of scorn and derision among the nations.
nëchəshä́vənu kətson lättë́väch yuval, lähäroǥ uləäbeđ uləmäkah uləchërəpah.
We have become considered like sheep led to the slaughter, to be slain, to be obliterated, to be stricken and to be disgraced.
uvəchal zot shïməcha lo shacháchənu, na, äl tïshəkachénu:
Nevertheless, we have not forgotten Your name. Please, do not forget us.
häbet mïshshoméiïm urəeh

Look down from Heaven and see — The Tachanun prayer was instituted primarily to evoke Divine compassion in the era of exile. On this basis, we can understand the nature of this request. In the era of exile, "the Holy One, blessed be He, has withdrawn to the higher reaches [of the celestial rungs]"353*k'li, a medium, that must adjust itself in order to receive the light. As such, the gentile nations are also capable of receiving this light.

To cause G-d's light to be focused on the Jewish people, we ask him to "Look down from Heaven." "Heaven" (shmym) is a composite of the words shm mym, "water is there," referring to the Torah which is described as water.354*

Alternatively, shmym can be seen as a composite of the words sh and mym, fire and water, which correspond to the emotional attributes of gevurah ("might") and chessed ("kindness").355*"Look down from Heaven" is a plea that He not shine His light in an encompassing manner, but instead have it drawn down in an internalized manner through His attributes. For when G-dly light is channeled through the emotional attributes of gevurah and chessed, the Jews are given primacy because these attributes are reflected in their Divine service of awe and love of G-d )Torah Or; Toras Shmuel; Maamarei Admur HaRayatz).clxxxv*

"Look[ing] down" and “see[ing]” reflect two different approaches of Divine providence. As reflected in the Midrash,356* "Looking down" refers to gazing from Above downward, watching from a distance. “Seeing,” by contrast, refers to perceiving from up close, as a created being would see itself, as it were. These two levels correspond to the two forms of Divine knowledge, daas elyon and daas tachton. From the perspective of daas elyon, the sublime understanding, G-d looks at the Creation on His terms. As such, there can be no interference or hiddenness brought about through the conduct of the created beings, for who or what can stand in His way? From the perspective of daas tachton, the lower understanding, by contrast, He knows the world as the created beings perceive themselves, as they exist as individual beings with their own identities (yesh). From this standpoint, the concealment of G-dliness is possible.Indeed, in the era of exile, the concealment is so great that "seeing" cannot be the first step in the process of Divine revelation. First, He must "look down from Heaven" and cause His encompassing light to be focused inward.357*maamarim entitled BeShaah SheHikidimu, 5672; Toras Menachem).clxxxvi*

vyđvy vtchnvn - Shuv Mecharon Apecha
Adonai ëlohei yïsərael, shuv mechäron äpë́cha, vəhïnnachem äl haraah ləämmë́cha:

Siddur: Viduy And Tachnun - shomer yïsərael
vyđvy vtchnvn - Shomer Yisrael
shomer yïsərael, shəmor shəerit yïsərael,
Guardian of Yisrael, guard the remnant of Yisrael.
vəäl yoväđ yïsərael, haomərim shəmä yïsərael:
Do not allow Yisrael — those who say “Hear O Yisrael” — to perish.
shomer yïsərael,

Guardian of Israel — In halachah,361*the term shomer, translated as "guardian,"refers to a shell that surrounds and covers a fruit, protecting it from outside influences. The spiritual parallel refers to an encompassing light that protects the Jewish people from all negative forces.

To explain: Our Sages relate362*Beis HaMikdash,363*the Levites would chant the verse:364*365*slumbers nor sleeps.” Implied is that there are two levels of Divine providence in the era of exile: one in which G-d sleeps, as it were; i.e., just as when a person sleeps, his vitality is reduced and his powers are revealed in a confused manner, so too, in exile, the revelation of G-dly power within the world is lessened and the events that occur do not reflect His desired order of precedence. Thus gentile nations are given greater power in the world at large.

Nevertheless, even in the era of exile,366*367*a person may be saved by a Divine miracle, but he himself may not recognize that anything special has transpired. Similarly, on a larger scale, outwardly, it may appear that G-d is sleeping, as it were, but in a way that transcends our perception there is an essential, inner dynamic at work, watching over the Jewish people — and every individual Jew — enabling them to advance G-d's purpose (Imrei Binah; Toras Shmuel).clxxxvii*

vəäl yoväđ goi ëchađ, hämyächäđim shïməcha Adonai ëlohéinu Adonai ëchađ:
Do not allow that one nation — who proclaim the unity of Your name, saying, “God is our Lord, God is one” — to perish.

Siddur: Viduy And Tachnun - avinu mäləkenu
vyđvy vtchnvn - Avinu Malkeinu
avinu mäləkenu avinu atah.
Our Father, our King, You are our Father.
avinu mäləkenu ein lanu mëlëch ëlla atah.
Our Father, our King, we have no King other than You.
avinu mäləkenu rächem aleinu.
Our Father, our King, have mercy upon us.
avinu mäləkenu chonnenu väänenu ki ein banu määsim,
Our Father, our King, be gracious unto us and answer us; although we have no deeds [to rely upon],
äseh ïmmanu tsəđaqah vachësëđ ləmään shïməcha hägađol vəhoshienu׃
act charitably and kindly with us and deliver us.
avinu mäləkenu

Our Father, our King – Our relationship with G-d is multi-dimensional. From the perspective of our souls, we are intrinsically connected with G-d like a son is inherently attached to his father, for our souls are “an actual part of G-d Above.” From the perspective of our bodies, however, we possess an independent identity and therefore accept His authority as a subject (vđ) accepts the authority of his king.

Our service as “sons” is a natural expression of our inner spiritual identity. Like a son who naturally desires to do his father’s will, we possess an inherent desire to carry out G-d’s will and generate pleasure for Him through our prayer, study and good deeds.

A subject, i.e., the manner in which we relate to Him because of our bodies, by contrast, does not possess a natural desire to carry out his master’s will. He would much rather be involved in his own affairs. Nevertheless, out of fear and awe of his master, he accepts his will and ultimately makes it his own.

There is no need to explain the advantage of the son’s intimate relationship with his father over that of a subject’s relationship to his master. Nevertheless, there is an advantage to the relationship of the subject as well, for the subject overcomes his natural tendencies, acting entirely for the sake of his master and not for his own self at all (Shaarei Orah; the series of maamarim entitled Yom Tov Shel Rosh HaShanah, 5666).dlvi*
Siddur: Viduy And Tachnun - väänächənu
vyđvy vtchnvn - Veanachnu
väänächənu lo neđä mäh nääsëh, ki aleicha eineinu׃

zəchor rächämeicha Adonai, vächäsađeicha, ki meolam hemmah׃

äl tïzəkar lanu äonot rïshonim, mäher yəqädəmunu rächämeicha, ki đällonu məođ׃

chonnenu Adonai chonnenu, ki räv saväənu vuz׃
Be gracious unto us, O God, be gracious unto us, for we have been overly sated with scorn.
bəroǥëz rächem tïzəkor, bəroǥëz äqeđah tïzəkor,
When wrathful, remember the merciful one [Abraham]; when wrathful, remember the binding [of Isaac];
bəroǥëz təmimot tïzəkor, bəroǥëz ähävah tïzəkor.
when wrathful, remember the simple faith [of Jacob]. When wrathful, remember the love [manifest by David].
Adonai hoshiah, hämmëlëch yäänenu vyom qorəenu׃
God, deliver us. May the King answer us on the day we call.
ki hu yađä yïtsərenu, zachur ki afar änochənu׃
For He knows [with what impulses] we were formed; He is mindful that we are but dust.
ozərenu ëlohei yïshəenu äl dəvär kəvođ shəmëcha,
Help us, O God of our deliverance, for the sake of the honor of Your name.
vəhätstsilenu vəchäper äl chättoteinu ləmään shəmëcha׃
Save us and atone for our sins for the sake of Your name.
bəroǥëz rächem tïzəkor

When in anger, remember the [trait of] mercy [shown by Abraham] – As is characteristic of the trait of mercy, in this request, we find a combination of two opposite qualities. The phrase mentions both anger and mercy. The quality of mercy transforms the attributes of judgment and righteous wrath into positive energy. For mercy does not mean absolving a person in judgment. Instead, mercy’s quality is that even when judgment would hold a person liable for his misdeeds, there is compassion for the person. Thus the attribute of mercy evokes generosity and kindness787* (Toras Chayim).dlix*

Siddur: The Reading Of The Torah - veiəhi bïnəśoä haaron
sđr qryt htvrh lchvl - Vayehi Binsoa Haaron
veiəhi bïnəśoä haaron veeíomër moshëh: qumah Adonai vyafǘtsu oiəvéicha vyanǘsu məsänəéicha mïpanéicha:
Whenever the Ark set forth, Moshe would say: “Arise, God, and Your enemies will be dispersed; those who hate You will flee before You.”371*
ki mïtstsion tetse torah uđəvär Adonai mirushaláiïm:
For the Torah shall go forth from Zion and the word of God from Jerusalem.378*
baruch shënnatän torah ləämmo yïsərael bïqəđüshshoto:
Blessed is He Who gave the Torah to His people, Yisrael, in His holiness.
veiəhi bïnəśoä haaron veeíomër moshëh: qumah Adonai vyafǘtsu oiəvéicha vyanǘsu məsänəéicha mïpanéicha:

Whenever the ark set forth, Moses would say: “Arise, G-d, and Your enemies will be dispersed…." — Moses would make this statement before the Jewish people embarked on one of the stages of their journey through the desert. The desert is a place of negative forces. For this reason, it is unfit for human habitation.368*presence, and all the negative forces were humbled before it. This was the intent of Moses' outcry: "Arise, G-d…," i.e. reveal Yourself in an upraised and elevated manner so that the negative forces will be nullified.

Developing this concept: Moses' call, “Arise, G-d, and Your enemies will be dispersed…,” can be contrasted with the proclamation of David and Shlomo:369*370*Beis HaMikdash, by contrast, introduced the potential to elevate the material dimensions of the world even while at rest. Due to the great holiness revealed therein, the influence of the material dimensions of existence waned. Indeed, the sparks of holiness were elevated as if on their own accord. For example, the Queen of Sheba brought gifts to King Shlomo, elevating the sparks of G-dliness contained in those material entities. Although this motif was manifest at the time of the Beis HaMikdash, it will not be until the Era of Mashiach that it will reach consummate expression and evil will be banished entirely (the series of maamarim entitled BeShaah SheHikidimu, 5672; Or HaTorah).clxxxviii*

baruch ätah Adonai, noten hätorah:

borəchu

The blessing recited before the reading of the Torah reflects the Giving of the Torah from Above: that G-d chose the Jewish people and desired to give them the Torah as it exists within His Essence. This gift makes it possible for every soul to cleave to the letters of the Torah389*

The blessing after the reading of the Torah emphasizes not the Giving of the Torah from Above, but the acceptance of the Torah by the Jewish people below. This blessing focuses on how the soul receives its life-force from the letters of the Torah, acknowledging that G-d gave us the Torah and implanted it in our midst (Shaarei Orah).cxciv*

amen. mi shëgəmoləcha tov, hu yïǥəmoləcha kal tov së́lah:
Amen. May He Who granted you kindness grant you all [kinds of] kindness forever.

äshərei yoshəvei veitëcha

Fortunate are those who dwell in Your house… A psalm of praise by David – The Zohar states792* that a person who recites this psalm, Tehillah LeDavid, three times each day is guaranteed a portion in the World to Come. More particularly, it explains that the psalm is recited twice as a prayer for our livelihood and once, strictly as praise of G-d.

The Talmud793* also states that such a reward is granted for reciting Tehillah LeDavid three times each day. In his gloss to that Talmudic passage, Rashi explains that the three recitations of this prayer correspond to the three prayer services.

Rashi’s statement raises questions. For according to Rashi’s logic, the psalm should seemingly be recited once in each of the three prayer services rather than twice in the Morning Service, once in the Afternoon Service, and not at all during the Evening Service, as is our practice.

Among the resolutions offered is that that the repetition of the psalm in the Morning Service compensates for its omission in the Evening Service.794* The Tzemach Tzedek does not accept this resolution, stating that if it is not appropriate to recite this psalm in the Evening Service, there would be no reason to compensate for its omission by repeating it in the Morning Service. Therefore the Tzemach Tzedek maintains that the opinion which requires that the psalm be recited three times follows the view that the recitation of the Evening Service is obligatory. According to our Sages’ final ruling concerning the issue – that the recitation of the Evening Service is optional795* – it is sufficient to recite the psalm twice. Thus, its repetition in the Morning Service is for another reason entirely.

Likkutei Levi Yitzchak offers a different perspective, explaining that there is a parallel between the recitation of Tehillah LeDavid and our prayer services. The Morning and the Afternoon services are obligatory, while the Evening Service is voluntary.*

The emphasis of Likkutei Levi Yitzchak is that according to pnimiyus haTorah, the Torah’s mystic dimension, there is a reason to recite this psalm in connection with the Evening Service – as praise of G-d and not as a prayer for our sustenance, as cited above from the Zohar. Nevertheless, because of the voluntary nature of the Evening Service, Tehillah LeDavid is not recited in the Evening Service itself, but rather twice in the Morning Service.

According to both the Tzemach Tzedek and Likkutei Levi Yitzchak, man’s fundamental obligation is to recite the psalm twice, once for each of the two obligatory prayer services. According to Likkutei Levi Yitzchak, the rationale as to why one should recite the psalm a third time is dependent on the clarification of the concept that the Evening Service is optional. From a mystical perspective, the intent is that the unity established in the upper worlds through the Evening Service is not something that can be achieved through man’s initiative. Instead, it is drawn down in and of itself, on G-d’s initiative without the need for any activity on man’s part.

Now, when Divine influence is drawn down in this manner, there are two general approaches:

a) to do nothing, lest one’s activity interfere with drawing down the Divine influence. Thus at the time of the Splitting of the Sea of Reeds, when it was “G-d” Who “will fight for you,”796* the Jews were commanded: “And you shall keep silent.”* Not only were they not to battle the Egyptians, they were also not to pray during that time.

b) to make a medium for the influence from Above to be received effectively within this world. For example, our Sages797* state that there is no need to request that dew descend, because the descent of dew will never cease. Nevertheless, we do pray for dew, asking that it descend “for blessing”; i.e., our request facilitates its descent from the lofty spiritual realms into our material world and causes the descent of dew to be beneficial for man.

This is why we recite the Evening Service. The unity established in the spiritual realms in the Evening Service is too lofty to be drawn down by man’s efforts. Our recitation of the Shemoneh Esreh, however, creates a setting for the positive influence drawn down through that unity, facilitating its expression in the most beneficial manner possible.

On this basis, we can understand the Tzemach Tzedek’s perspective as to why the psalm Tehillah LeDavid is not recited in connection with the Evening Prayer. In the Morning and Afternoon Services, the recitation of this psalm is a preparatory step, helping to generate the influence drawn down by the Shemoneh Esreh. Since the Divine influence associated with the Evening Service is drawn down on its own, there is no need to recite Tehillah LeDavid.798* For there is no need for man’s effort, nor is it of any avail, in generating this influence.

This reflects the perspective of Nigleh, Torah law. However, the perspective of pnimiyus haTorah is that even such lofty levels of G-dliness can be facilitated by man’s activity. Nevertheless, since, ultimately, the matter is not dependent on man, his recitation of these prayers is not obligatory. It merely contributes to G-d’s praise.

To emphasize that our recitation of Tehillah LeDavid for the third time only facilitates the drawing down of this energy – rather than serving as a necessary component in the preparation for drawing it down – Tehillah LeDavid is not recited in the Evening Service itself, but a second time in the Morning Service (Yahel Or; Likkutei Sichos).dlx*

May G-d answer you – It is suggested that this psalm be recited when a woman suffers difficulty in childbirth799* because it contains seventy words and it is an established tradition that a woman cries out seventy times in childbirth.800* Similarly, the seventy words of this psalm parallel the seventy years of the Babylonian exile.801* That exile, however, made possible an experience of birth and renewal for the Jewish people (Kesser Shem Tov; Maamarei Admor HaEmtza’i).dlxi*

ruchi äshër aleicha

My words which I have placed in your mouth – This phrase endows us with a fundamental understanding of what the Torah is. The Torah is not merely a collection of “wondrous insights,” “profound truths,” or any other praise that man can heap upon it. The Torah is “G-d’s word.” Our Sages speak808* of “the Divine presence speaking from Moshe’s mouth.” In microcosm, this same process recurs every time a Jew studies the words of Torah with bittul, as implied by the verse:809* “My tongue shall repeat Your sayings” (Tanya; Torah Or; Likkutei Torah).dlxix*

[They will say] that You are great and work wonders – You, God, alone.
horeni Adonai därəkëcha ähällech bäämïtëcha, yächeđ ləvavi lyïrəah shəmëcha׃
Show me Your way, O God, so that I may walk in [the path of] Your truth; unify my heart to fear Your name.
ođəcha äđonai ëlohei bəchal ləvavi, väächäbəđah shïməcha ləolam׃
I will thankfully acknowledge You, my God, my Lord, with all my heart; I will honor Your name forever,
ki chäsədəcha gađol alai, vəhïtstsäləta näfəshi mïshshəol tächətiah׃
for Your kindness to me has been great, and You have saved my soul from the depths of the grave.
ëlohim | zeđim qamu alei, vääđät aritsim bïqəshu näfəshi, vəlo samucha lənëǥədam׃
O God, the brazen have risen up against me, and a company of ruthless men have sought my soul; they are not mindful of you.
vəätah äđonai el rächum vəchännun, ërëch äpeiïm vəräv chësëđ vëëmët׃
You, my God, are Almighty, merciful and gracious, slow to anger, abounding in kindness and true.
pəneh elei vəchonneni, tənah üzzəcha ləävədëcha, vəhoshiah ləvën ämatëcha׃
Turn to me and be gracious unto me; endow Your servant with Your strength and deliver the son of Your handmaiden.
äseh ïmmi ot lətovah, vyïrəu sonəei vyevoshu,
Grant me a sign of favor so that my foes will see and be ashamed,
ki ätah Adonai äzärətäni vənïchämətani׃
for You, God, have helped me and comforted me.
təfïllah ləđavïđ, hätteh Adonai ozənəcha äneni, ki ani vəëvyon ani

A prayer by David: Incline Your ear, O G-d, and answer me, for I am poor and destitute – This verse is problematic on several accounts. Firstly, here King David pleads to G-d that his prayers be answered because of his poverty, while in the following verse, he requests that they be answered because of his piety. Piety and poverty can be seen as opposites, for the true definition of poverty is poverty of knowledge, as our Sages say,858* “There is no poverty other than poverty of knowledge.” Now, a person who has a dearth of knowledge cannot be pious, as our Sages say,859* “A boor is not sin-fearing.” How then was it possible for David to be both poor in knowledge and pious?

Moreover, the very nature of David’s request raises questions: Why is poverty a reason for G-d to answer one’s prayers?

Nevertheless, the Zohar860* equates – and indeed, sees an advantage – in the prayer of a poor man even over the prayer of Moshe.

What is the advantage of a poor man? He feels constant pressure and distress, and as a result, he cries out to G-d, as it is written:861* “They called out to G-d in their distress.” When a person prays out of distress, his prayers emanate from the depths of his heart. And within the depths of one’s heart is lodged a truly unlimited dimension of G-dliness. Moreover, crushed and humbled as he is by his poverty, he will be totally invested and absorbed in his prayers. Now, when one prays in this manner, he arouses a level Above that is similarly unlimited, the level of sovev kol almin, and thus his prayers are answered speedily.

For these reasons, even though David also possessed the quality of piety, when praying, he sought to highlight his poverty, because that quality evokes a higher dimension of prayer and a loftier Divine response (Toras Shmuel; Toras Menachem).dxcv*

The same motif applies in the spiritual realms. King David is identified with the Sefirah of Malchus, kingship. Malchus – and thus David as well – is also identified with the theme of poverty, since “Malchus has nothing of its own”;862* all it possesses is granted to it by the higher Sefiros. David served as a medium for the expression of Malchus in this world. His prayer thus represents the bonding and bittul of Malchus to the Sefiros that are above it (Toras Menachem).dxcvi*

The kapitle begins, “A prayer by David.” Now, in general, David’s prayers were treasured in heaven, for they are characterized by selflessness. There are, however, certain lofty heavenly gates that even David’s prayers cannot open. Nevertheless, at those times when David’s – or any other person’s – prayers are energized by feelings of extreme poverty and bittul, there is no gate which these prayers cannot break open (Toras Menachem).dxcvii*
Siddur: Shacharit For Weekdays - beit yääqov
shchryt lchvl - Beit Yaakov
beit yääqov, ləchu vəneləchah bəor Adonai׃
House of Jacob, come let us walk by the light of God.
ki kal haämmim yeləchu ish bəshem ëlohaiv,
For all the nations will each walk in the name of its god,
väänächənu nelech bəshem Adonai ëloheinu ləolam vaëđ׃
but we will walk in the name of God, our Lord, forever and ever.
yəhi Adonai ëloheinu ïmmanu, kääshër haiah ïm ävoteinu, äl yääzəvenu vəäl yïttəshenu׃
May God, our Lord, be with us as He was with our fathers; may He not forsake us, nor abandon us,
ləhättot ləvavenu elaiv, lalëchët bəchal dərachaiv
so that He will turn our hearts to Him, to follow in all His ways
vəlïshəmor mïtsəotaiv vəchüqqaiv umïshəpataiv, äshër tsïvah ët ävoteinu׃
and to observe His commandments, His statutes and His judgments that He commanded our fathers.
vyïhyu đəvarei ellëh äshër hïtəchännänəti lïfənei Adonai, qərovim ël Adonai ëloheinu yomam valaiəlah,
And may these words of mine that I have offered in supplication before God be close to God, our Lord, day and night,
lääsot mïshəpät ävədo umïshəpät ämmo yïsərael dəvär yom byomo׃
so that He will provide what is justly due His servant and what is justly due His people Israel, each day’s needs in its day –
ləmään däät kal ämmei haarëts ki Adonai hu haëlohim, ein ođ׃
so that all the peoples of the earth shall know that God is the Lord; there is no one else.
beit yääqov, ləchu vəneləchah bəor Adonai

House of Jacob, come let us walk by the light of G-d – This verse refers to the ultimate revelation of G-d’s light that will shine forth to the Jewish people in the era of Mashiach. At that time, the physical substance of the world will be elevated and the entire world will be able to receive the radiance of the G-dly light that will shine to the Jewish people as a result of their connection with the Torah (Tanya).dciv*

The term veneilcha, translated as “let us walk,” connotes unlimited progression. The Jewish people are able to accomplish this because they are the “House of Jacob.” Jacob is identified with the middle vector which extends from the highest level to the lowest. This potential enables the Jews to advance from one spiritual level to another without obstruction (Or HaTorah).dcv*

The name of G-d used in the phrase vvr h׳, “in the light of G-d,” is the name Havayah, which refers to an unbounded light. In particular, there are two interpretations of the phrase “the light of Havayah”: a) the light that exists inherently in the name Havayah; and b) the light that is drawn down into the name Havayah from the infinite levels above it. This latter degree of light is drawn down by the Jewish people through their observance of the Torah and its mitzvos.

To explain: The name Havayah relates to the word mehaveh873* which means “to bring into being.” It refers to the level of G-dly light that serves as a source for the world’s creation. The Jews’ Divine service, however, draws down a light that is far above the limited G-dly light that is the source of creation (Or HaTorah; Toras Shmuel).dcvi*

The verse uses the expression “House of Jacob.” The name Jacob refers to the lowermost levels of the Jewish people, for the name, Jacob (Yaakov), yqv in Hebrew, can be divided as y qv, i.e., the yud, the light of G-dliness, shines within the ekev, the heel. These “heel souls” are beset with manifold spiritual challenges, for it is extremely difficult for people with such lowly souls to overcome the natural desires stemming from their bodies and animal souls. Even when these people intellectually understand the truth of G-dliness, that realization is not strong enough to empower them to overcome their natural desires. Moreover, their understanding itself is somewhat superficial and thus is not strong enough to motivate sincere change.

Even in such a state, however, such a person can “go forth [and] walk in the light of G-d.” For when a person in such a state cries out to G-d and beseeches His mercy, humbling himself and feeling embittered because of his previous conduct, he calls forth abundant Divine compassion, drawing down a G-dly light that transcends the ordinary limits of Divine mercy (the series of maamarim entitled BeShaah SheHikidimu, 5672).dcvii*
Siddur: Shacharit For Weekdays - shir hämmäälot ləđavïđ
shchryt lchvl - Shir Hamaalot Ledavid
shir hämmäälot ləđavïđ, lulei Adonai shëhaiah lanu, yomär na yïsərael׃
A song of ascents by David. Were it not for God Who was with us – let Israel declare –
lulei Adonai shëhaiah lanu, bəqum aleinu ađam׃
were it not for God Who was with us when men rose against us,
äzei cheeiim bəlaunu, bächärot äpam banu׃
then they would have swallowed us alive when their fury raged against us.
äzei hämmeiïm shətafunu, nächəlah avär äl näfəshenu׃
Then the waters would have swept us away; the current would have surged over our souls.
äzei avär äl näfəshenu, hämmeiïm häzzeiđonim׃
Then it would have surged over our souls [with its] raging waters.
baruch Adonai, shëllo nətananu tërëf ləshïnneihëm׃
Blessed is God Who did not make us prey for their teeth.
näfəshenu kətsïpor nïmələtah mïpäch yoqəshim, häpäch nïshəbär, väänächənu nïməlotənu׃
Our soul is like a bird that has escaped from the hunters’ snare; the snare broke and we escaped.
ëzərenu bəshem Adonai, oseh shameiïm vaarëts׃
Our help is in the name of God, the Maker of heaven and earth.
lulei Adonai shëhaiah lanu, bəqum aleinu ađam

Were it not for G-d Who was with us – The name of G-d used in the verse is Havayah, yet the word lanu, translated as “with us,” is numerically equivalent to 86, the numerical equivalent of the name Elokim. Now the name Havayah is inherently connected to the Jewish people, as it is written:881* “For the lot of Havayah is His people.” Nevertheless, for G-dliness to be internalized within us as we exist in this material world, as souls within bodies, G-d must conceal and contract Himself, as it were, and that concealment and contraction is accomplished through G-d’s name Elokim. Thus for Havayah to be truly “with us,” i.e., internalized within us, the medium of the name Elokim is necessary (Yahel Or).dcxviii*
Siddur: Song of the Day - heeiom, yom rïshon
shyr shl yvm - Hayom Yom Rishon
heeiom, yom rïshon bäshshäbot, shëbo haiu häləviïm omərim bəveit hämmïqədash׃
Today is the first day of the week, on which the Levites serving in the Temple would say:
ləđavïđ mïzəmor, leiya haarëts uməloah, tevel vyoshəvei vah׃
A psalm by David. The earth and all that it contains, the world and all its inhabitants, are God’s.
ki hu äl yämmim yəsađah, vəäl nəharot yəchonənëha׃
He established it upon the seas and positioned it firmly upon the rivers.
mi yäälëh vəhär Adonai, umi yaqum bïməqom qođəsho׃
Who may ascend the mountain of God? Who may stand in His holy place?
nəqi chäpeiïm uvär levav, äshër lo nasa läshshovə näfəshi, vəlo nïshəbä ləmïrəmah׃
He who has clean hands and a pure heart and who has not taken My name in vain, nor taken a deceitful oath.
yïshsa vərochoh meet Adonai, utsəđaqah meëlohei yïshəo׃
He will receive a blessing from God and due kindness from the Lord of his salvation.

Who is the King of Glory? God, Who is strong and mighty; God, Who is mighty in war.

Lift up your heads, O gates; Lift [yourselves] up, O the eternal portals, so that the King of Glory may enter.
mi hu zëh mëlëch häkavođ, Adonai tsəvaot, hu mëlëch häkavođ sëlah׃
Who is the King of Glory? God, Commander of legions; He is the King of Glory forever.
hoshienu Adonai ëloheinu vəqäbətsenu mïn hägoiïm, ləhođot ləshem qođəshëcha, ləhïshətäbeäch bïtəhïllatëcha׃
Deliver us, God our Lord, gather us from among the nations, so that we may thankfully acknowledge Your holy name and glory in Your praise.
baruch Adonai ëlohei yïsərael mïn haolam vəäđ haolam, vəamär kal haam amen, häləluyah׃
Blessed is God, the Lord of Israel, from this world until the World to Come – and let all the people say, “Amen; praise God!”
baruch Adonai mïtstsion shochen yərushalaiïm, häləluyah׃
Blessed is God from Zion, Who dwells in Jerusalem. Praise God!
baruch Adonai ëlohim ëlohei yïsərael, oseh nïfəlaot ləvädo׃
Blessed is God, the Lord, the Lord of Israel, Who alone performs wonders.
uvaruch shem kəvođo ləolam, vyïmmale chəvođo ët kal haarëts, amen vəamen׃
Blessed be His glorious name forever; may His glory fill the entire earth. Amen and Amen.
heeiom, yom rïshon bäshshäbot

Today is the … day of the week – The phrase “the day of the week” is a non-literal translation. Verbatim, the phrase would be rendered “…the [first, second, third, etc.] day of the Shabbos.”

Shabbos is entirely above time. Hence, each week the cycle of time begins anew. Therefore even though several thousands of years have passed since Creation, we say: “Today is the first day…,” “Today is the second day…,” etc. For indeed, it is the first day, i.e., the same spiritual energies that were revealed on the first day of Creation are revealed on the first day of every week.

As implied by the phrase886* “Every day performs its own service,” the changing revelations from Above specific to each day should evoke a corresponding variation in our Divine service. As alluded to in the conclusion of Tractate Tamid, the song sung by the Levites each day in the Beis HaMikdash reflects the nature of the Divine service appropriate for that particular day and thus alludes to the direction our Divine service should take on that day (Sefer Maamarim Melukat; the Rebbe’s Igros Kodesh; Toras Menachem).dcxxii*

Among the implications of the phrase “the… day of the Shabbos” is that the spirit of Shabbos should be extended and connected to each of the days of the week.887*

The Zohar888* states that all the days of the week are blessed from Shabbos. On Shabbos, a Jew is removed from connection to mundane activities. His energies are devoted to spiritual pursuits. By drawing down the holiness of Shabbos into the days of the week, he causes the blessings generated on Shabbos to be manifest in his mundane reality, including his efforts to earn his livelihood (the Rebbe’s Igros Kodesh; Toras Menachem).dcxxiii*
