Today is the fourth day of the week, on which the Levites serving in the Temple would say:
el nəqamot Adonai, el nəqamot hofiä׃
O Lord, God of vengeance; O God of vengeance, reveal Yourself.
hïnnase shofet haarëts, hashev gəmul äl geim׃
Show Your loftiness, O Judge of the earth; bring retribution upon the proud.
äđ matei rəshaim | Adonai, äđ matei rəshaim yäälozu׃
Until when shall the wicked, O God – until when shall the wicked exult?
yäbiu yəđäbəru ataq, yïtəämməru kal poälei avën׃
They freely express themselves and speak insolently; all the workers of iniquity glorify themselves.
ämməcha Adonai yəđäkəu, vənächälotəcha yəännu׃
They crush Your people, O God, and oppress Your heritage.
äləmanah vəǥer yähäroǥu, vitomim yərätstsechu׃
They kill the widow and the stranger and murder orphans.
veeioməru lo yïrəëh yah, vəlo yavin ëlohei yääqov׃
They say: “God does not see, nor does the God of Jacob pay heed.”
binu boärim baam, uchəsilim matei täsəkilu׃
Fools among the people, understand. When, senseless ones, will you grow wise?
hänotä ozën hälo yïshəma, ïm yotser eiïn hälo yäbit׃
Shall He Who implants the ear not hear? Shall He Who forms the eye not see?
häyoser goiïm hälo yochiäch, häməlämmeđ ađam daät׃
Shall He Who chastises nations not rebuke [the wicked]? He grants man understanding; [shall He not know his thoughts]?
Adonai yođeä mächəshəvot ađam, ki hemmah havël׃
God knows the thoughts of man, that they are emptiness.
äshərei hägëvër äshër tyässərënnu yah, umïtorotəcha təlämməđënnu׃
Fortunate is the man whom You chastise, O G-d, and whom You instruct from Your Torah,
ləhäshəqit lo mimei ra, äđ yïkarëh larasha shachät׃
so that he is granted tranquility [and spared] from the days of evil until a pit is dug for the wicked.
ki lo yïttosh Adonai ämmo, vənächälato lo yääzov׃
For God will not forsake His people, nor will He abandon His heritage.
ki äđ tsëđëq yashuv mïshəpat, vəächäraiv kal yïshərei lev׃
For the judgment [of retribution] will continually be visited until righteousness is reached; afterwards, all will be upright of heart.
mi yaqum li ïm məreim, mi yïtyätstsev li ïm poälei avën׃
Who will rise up on my behalf against the doers of evil? Who will stand on my behalf against the workers of iniquity?
lulei Adonai ëzəratah li, kïməät shochənah đumah näfəshi׃
Had God not been my help, my soul would soon have dwelt in the silence of the grave.
ïm amärəti matah räǥəli, chäsədəcha Adonai yïsəađeni׃
When I said, “My foot falters,” Your kindness, O God, supported me.
bərov särəäpei bəqïrəbi, tänəchumeicha yəshääshəu näfəshi׃
When my bothersome thoughts abounded within me, Your consolation brought delight to my soul.
heiəchovərəcha kïsse häuot, yotser amal älei choq׃
Can the throne of the workers of destruction, who make iniquity law, be compared to You?!
yaǥodu äl nëfësh tsädiq, vəđam naqi yärəshiu׃
They join together against the soul of a righteous man, and they condemn the blood of the innocent.
veiəhi Adonai li ləmïsəgav, velohei lətsur mächəsi׃
God has been my Fortress, and my Lord, the Rock of my shelter.
veeiashëv äleihëm ët onam uvəraatam yätsəmitem, yätsəmitem Adonai ëloheinu׃
God will turn their violence against them and with their own evil, He will cut them off; God our Lord will surely cut them off.
ləchu nərännənah leiya, nariah lətsur yïshəenu׃
Come, let us sing joyously to God; let us call out to the Rock of our deliverance in jubilation.
nəqädəmah fanaiv bətođah, bïzəmïrot nariä lo׃
Let us greet Him with thanksgiving; let us call out to Him with singing.
ki el gađol Adonai, umëlëch gađol äl kal ëlohim׃
For the Lord is a great God, and a great King over all supernal beings.
hoshienu Adonai ëloheinu vəqäbətsenu mïn hägoiïm, ləhođot ləshem qođəshëcha, ləhïshətäbeäch bïtəhïllatëcha׃
Deliver us, God our Lord, gather us from among the nations, so that we may thankfully acknowledge Your holy name and glory in Your praise.
baruch Adonai ëlohei yïsərael mïn haolam vəäđ haolam, vəamär kal haam amen, häləluyah׃
Blessed is God, the Lord of Israel, from this world until the World to Come – and let all the people say, “Amen; praise God!”
baruch Adonai mïtstsion shochen yərushalaiïm, häləluyah׃
Blessed is God from Zion, Who dwells in Jerusalem.
baruch Adonai ëlohim ëlohei yïsərael, oseh nïfəlaot ləvädo׃
Praise God! Blessed is God, the Lord, the Lord of Israel, Who alone performs wonders.
uvaruch shem kəvođo ləolam, vyïmmale chəvođo ët kal haarëts, amen vəamen׃
Blessed be His glorious name forever; may His glory fill the entire earth. Amen and Amen.
heeiom, yom rəvii bäshshäbot

Today is the … day of the week – The phrase “the day of the week” is a non-literal translation. Verbatim, the phrase would be rendered “…the [first, second, third, etc.] day of the Shabbos.”

Shabbos is entirely above time. Hence, each week the cycle of time begins anew. Therefore even though several thousands of years have passed since Creation, we say: “Today is the first day…,” “Today is the second day…,” etc. For indeed, it is the first day, i.e., the same spiritual energies that were revealed on the first day of Creation are revealed on the first day of every week.

As implied by the phrase952* “Every day performs its own service,” the changing revelations from Above specific to each day should evoke a corresponding variation in our Divine service. As alluded to in the conclusion of Tractate Tamid, the song sung by the Levites each day in the Beis HaMikdash reflects the nature of the Divine service appropriate for that particular day and thus alludes to the direction our Divine service should take on that day (Sefer Maamarim Melukat; the Rebbe’s Igros Kodesh; Toras Menachem).dclxvii*

Among the implications of the phrase “the… day of the Shabbos” is that the spirit of Shabbos should be extended and connected to each of the days of the week.953*

The Zohar954* states that all the days of the week are blessed from Shabbos. On Shabbos, a Jew is removed from connection to mundane activities. His energies are devoted to spiritual pursuits. By drawing down the holiness of Shabbos into the days of the week, he causes the blessings generated on Shabbos to be manifest in his mundane reality, including his efforts to earn his livelihood (the Rebbe’s Igros Kodesh; Toras Menachem).dclxviii*

Siddur: Song of the Day - heeiom, yom chämishi
shyr shl yvm - Hayom Yom Chamishi
heeiom, yom chämishi bäshshäbot, shëbo haiu häləviïm omərim bəveit hämmïqədash׃
Today is the fifth day of the week, on which the Levites serving in the Temple would say:
lämənätstseäch äl hägïtit ləasaf׃
To the lead musician, on the gittis, by Asaf.
härəninu lelohim uzzenu, hariu lelohei yääqov׃
Sing joyously to God, our strength, sound the shofar before the God of Jacob.
səu zïmərah utənu tof, kïnnor naim ïm navël׃
Raise your voice in song, sound the drum, the pleasant-sounding harp and the lyre.
tïqəu vächođësh shofar, bäkësëh lyom chägenu׃
Sound the shofar at the new moon, the appointed time for our festival.
ki choq lyïsərael hu, mïshəpat lelohei yääqov׃
For it is a statute for Israel, a [day of] judgment before the God of Jacob.
eđut bihosef samo bətseto äl ërëts mïtsəraiïm, səfät lo yađäəti ëshəma׃
He established it as a testimonial [recalling] Joseph, when he went forth [as a ruler] over the land of Egypt and said, “I heard a language that I did not know.”
häsiroti mïssevël shïchəmo, käpaiv mïduđ täävorənah׃
I (God) freed his shoulder of the burden, and his hands of the [prisoner’s] cauldron.
bätstsarah qarata vaächällətsëëcha, ëënəcha bəsetër rääm, ëvəchonəcha äl mei mərivah sëlah׃
In distress, you called out and I released you; [while you called to Me] in hiding, I answered you with thunder, [even though] I tested you at the waters of Merivah; Selah.
shəmä ämmi vəaiđah bach, yïsərael ïm tïshəmä li׃
Listen, My people, and I will caution you; Israel, if you would only heed Me!
lo yïhyëh vəcha el zar, vəlo tïshətächävëh ləel nechar׃
Let there be no strange gods within you, nor shall you bow down to a foreign deity.
anochi Adonai ëloheicha hämmääləcha meërëts mïtsəraiïm, härəchëv picha väämäləehu׃
I am God, your Lord, Who lifted you up from the land of Egypt; open wide your mouth [to state your desires] and I will fulfill them.
vəlo shamä ämmi ləqoli, vyïsərael lo avah li׃
But My people did not heed My voice; Israel did not desire [to listen to] Me.
vaäshälləchehu bïshərirut lïbam, yeləchu bəmoätsoteihëm׃
So I sent them after the illusions of their heart. Let them follow their own counsels.
lu ämmi shomeä li, yïsərael bïđərachei yəhällechu׃
If only My people would heed Me; if only Israel would walk in My ways!
kïməät oiəveihëm ächəniä, vəäl tsareihëm ashiv yađi׃
I would subdue their enemies without delay and turn My hand against their foes.
məsänəei Adonai yəchächäshu lo, vihi ïtam ləolam׃
Those who hate God will deny Him; the time [of their retribution] will endure forever.
veeiäächilehu mechelëv chïttah, umïtstsur dəväsh äsəbiëëcha׃
He (God) would feed him from the cream of wheat, and [God promises that] “from the rock, I will satiate you with honey.”
hoshienu Adonai ëloheinu vəqäbətsenu mïn hägoiïm, ləhođot ləshem qođəshëcha, ləhïshətäbeäch bïtəhïllatëcha׃
Deliver us, God our Lord, gather us from among the nations, so that we may thankfully acknowledge Your holy name and glory in Your praise.
baruch Adonai ëlohei yïsərael mïn haolam vəäđ haolam, vəamär kal haam amen, häləluyah׃
Blessed is God, the Lord of Israel, from this world until the World to Come – and let all the people say, “Amen; praise God!”
baruch Adonai mïtstsion shochen yərushalaiïm, häləluyah׃
Blessed is God from Zion, Who dwells in Jerusalem.
baruch Adonai ëlohim ëlohei yïsərael, oseh nïfəlaot ləvädo׃
Praise God! Blessed is God, the Lord, the Lord of Israel, Who alone performs wonders.
uvaruch shem kəvođo ləolam, vyïmmale chəvođo ët kal haarëts, amen vəamen׃
Blessed be His glorious name forever; may His glory fill the entire earth. Amen and Amen.

Siddur: Song of the Day - heeiom, yom shïshshi
shyr shl yvm - Hayom Yom Shishi
heeiom, yom shïshshi bäshshäbot, shëbo haiu häləviïm omərim bəveit hämmïqədash׃
Today is the sixth day of the week, on which the Levites serving in the Temple would say:
Adonai malach geut lavesh, lavesh Adonai, oz hïtəäzzar,
[In the Ultimate Future, it will be said:] God has reigned. He has garbed Himself in grandeur. God has garbed Himself, and girded Himself with strength.
äf tïkon tevel bäl tïmmot׃
The world is firmly established, so that it will not falter.
nachon kïsəächa meaz, meolam atah׃
Your throne stands firm from the beginning of time; You have existed forever.
nasəu nəharot Adonai, nasəu nəharot qolam, yïsəu nəharot dochyam׃
The rivers have raised, O God – the rivers have raised their voice; the rivers raise their crushing [waves].
mïqqolot meiïm räbim ädirim mïshəbərei yam, ädir bämmarom Adonai׃
More than the sound of many waters, more powerful than the breakers of the sea, is God mighty on high.
eđoteicha nëëmənu məođ, ləveitəcha naävah qođësh, Adonai ləorëch yamim׃
Your testimonies are most trustworthy. Your house will be resplendent in holiness, O God, until the end of days.
hoshienu Adonai ëloheinu vəqäbətsenu mïn hägoiïm, ləhođot ləshem qođəshëcha, ləhïshətäbeäch bïtəhïllatëcha׃
Deliver us, God our Lord, gather us from among the nations, so that we may thankfully acknowledge Your holy name and glory in Your praise.
baruch Adonai ëlohei yïsərael mïn haolam vəäđ haolam, vəamär kal haam amen, häləluyah׃
Blessed is God, the Lord of Israel, from this world until the World to Come – and let all the people say, “Amen; praise God!”
baruch Adonai mïtstsion shochen yərushalaiïm, häləluyah׃
Blessed is God from Zion, Who dwells in Jerusalem.

Praise God! Blessed is God, the Lord, the Lord of Israel, Who alone performs wonders.
uvaruch shem kəvođo ləolam, vyïmmale chəvođo ët kal haarëts, amen vəamen׃
Blessed be His glorious name forever; may His glory fill the entire earth. Amen and Amen.

Siddur: Song of the Day - hoshiénu
shyr shl yvm - Hoshiaynu
hoshiénu Adonai ëlohéinu vəqäbətsénu mïn hägoiïm, ləhođot ləshem qođəshë́cha, ləhïshətäbéäch bïtəhïllatë́cha:
Deliver us, God our Lord, gather us from among the nations, so that we may thankfully acknowledge Your holy name and glory in Your praise.
baruch Adonai ëlohei yïsərael mïn haolam vəäđ haolam, vəamär kal haam amen, häləluyah:
Blessed is God, the Lord of Yisrael, from this world until the World [to Come] — and let all the people say, “Amen; Halleluyah!”395*
baruch Adonai mïtstsion shochen yərushaláiïm, häləluyah:
Blessed is God from Zion, Who dwells in Jerusalem. Halleluyah!”396*
baruch Adonai ëlohim ëlohei yïsərael, oseh nïfəlaot ləvädo:
Blessed is God, the Lord, the God of Yisrael, Who alone performs wonders.
uvaruch shem kəvođo ləolam, vyïmmale chəvođo ët kal haárëts, amen vəamen:
Blessed be His glorious name forever; may His glory fill the entire earth. Amen and Amen.397*
Siddur: Song of the Day - borəchi näfəshi
shyr shl yvm - Barchi Nafshi
borəchi näfəshi ët Adonai, Adonai ëlohei gađä́ləta məođ, hođ vəhađar laváshəta:
My soul, bless God! God, my Lord, You are sublimely exalted: You have donned glory and splendor.
́otëh or käshsäləmoh, notëh shoméiïm keiərioh:
You wrap [the world] in light as with a garment; You spread the heavens like a curtain.
häməqarëh vämméiïm äliotaiv, häshsam ovim rəchuvo, häməhällech äl känəfei ŕuäch:
He roofs His lofty chambers with water; He makes the clouds His chariot; He speeds them on the wings of the wind.
osëh mäləachaiv ruchot, məshorətaiv esh lohet:
He makes the winds His messengers; flashes of fire, His attendants.
yásäđ ë́rëts äl məchonéiha, bäl tïmmot olam vaëđ:
He established the earth on its foundations, so that it will not falter for eternity.
təhom källəvush kïssito, äl harim yä́äməđu máiïm:
You covered it with the watery depths as with a garment; the waters stand above the mountains.
mïn gäärotəcha yənusun, mïn qol rääməcha yechafezun:
From Your rebuke, they flee; from the rumble of Your thunder, they rush away.
yäälu harim yerəđu vəqaot, ël məqom zëh yasä́đəta lahëm:
They ascend mountains; they descend into valleys, to the place You established for them.
gəvul sä́məta bäl yäävorun, bäl yəshüvun ləchässot haárëts:
You set a boundary over which they cannot pass, so that they will not return and cover the earth.
häməshälléäch mäyanim bännəchalim, bein harim yəhällechun:
You send forth springs into streams that make their way between the mountains.
yäshəqu kal cheiəto sađai, yïshəbəru fəraim tsəmaam:
They water all the beasts of the field; the wild animals quench their thirst.
äleihëm of häshshoméiïm yïshəkon, mïbein afayïm yïtənu qol:
The birds of the heavens dwell over them; from among the foliage, they raise their voices.
mäshəqëh harim meäliotaiv, mïpəri määséicha tïsəbä haárëts:
He waters the mountains from His lofty chambers. Yea, the earth is satiated from the fruit of Your work:
mätsəḿiäch chatsir läbəhemah, vəésëv läävođät haađam, ləh́otsi lë́chëm mïn haárëts:
You make grass grow for cattle, vegetation which requires man’s work, to produce food from the earth.
vyéiïn yəsämmäch ləväv ënosh, ləhätsəhil panim mïshshámën, vəlë́chëm ləväv ënosh yïsəođ:
And wine that gladdens the heart of man, oil that makes a face glow, and bread that sustains the heart of man.
yïsəbəu ätsei Adonai, ärəzei ləvanon äshër nata:
The trees of God are satiated, the cedars of Lebanon that He planted.
äshër sham tsïparim yəqännénu, chäsiđah bəroshim beitah:
There birds make their nest; the stork makes its home among the cypress.
harim hägəvohim leeiəelim, səlaim mächəsëh läshəfännim:
High mountains [are the home] of the wild goats; the crags are a refuge for the rabbits.
asah yaréäch ləmoäđim, shë́mësh yađä məvoo:
He made the moon [to indicate] the festivals; the sun knows the time of its setting.
táshët chóshëch v́ihi láiəlah, bo tïrəmos kal cheiəto yáär:
You bring on darkness and it becomes night, when the beasts of the forest prowl.
häkəfirim shoäǥim lättárëf, uləväqqesh meel ochəlam:
The young lions roar for prey, to seek their food from the Almighty.
tïzəräch häshshë́mësh yeosefun, vəël məonotam yïrəbotsun:
When the sun shines forth, they are gathered in and lie down in their dens.
yetse ađam ləfaalo, vəläävođato äđei árëv:
[And at that time,] man goes out to his work, to his labor until evening.
mah räbu määséicha Adonai, küllam bəchochəmah aśita, moləah haárëts qïnyanë́cha:
How manifold are Your works, O God! You have made them all with wisdom; the earth is filled with Your possessions.
zëh heeiam gađol urəchäv yađéiïm, sham rë́mës vəein mïsəpar, cheeiot qətännot ïm gəđolot:
Behold this sea, so vast and broad, where there are countless creeping things, living beings both small and large.
sham aniot yəhällechun, lïvyatan zëh yatsä́rəta ləsä́chëq bo:
There ships make their way; in it is the Leviasan that You created to frolic with.
küllam eléicha yəsäberun, latet ochəlam bəïto:
They all look hopefully to You, to give them their food in its time.
tïten lahëm yïləqotun, tïfətäch yođəcha yïsəbəun tov:
When You grant it to them, they collect it; when You open Your hand, they are satiated with goodness.
täsətir panéicha yïbahelun, tosef rucham yïǥəvaun, vəël äfaram yəshuvun:
When You grant it to them, they collect it; when You open Your hand, they are satiated with goodness. When You hide Your face, they are dismayed.
təshälläch ruchächa yïbareun, utəchädesh pənei äđamah:
When their spirits expire, they perish and return to their dust. When You send forth Your spirit, they are created anew; You renew the face of the earth.
yəhi chəvođ Adonai ləolam, yïsəmäch Adonai bəmääsaiv:
May the glory of God endure forever; may God rejoice in His works.
hämmäbit laárëts vätïrəađ, yïgä bëharim vyëëshánu:
He looks to the earth and it trembles; He touches the mountains and they smoke.
ash́irah leiya bəcheeiai, äzämmərah lelohei bəođi:
I shall sing to God while I live; I shall make music to My Lord while I exist.
yëëräv alaiv sichi, anochi ësəmäch beiya:
May my words be pleasant to Him; I shall rejoice in God.
yïtä́mmu chättaim mïn haárëts urəshaim ođ einam,
May sinners cease from the earth and the wicked be no more.
borəchi näfəshi ët Adonai, häləluyah:
My soul, bless God! Halleluyah.414*
borəchi näfəshi ët Adonai

My soul, bless G-d…. You have donned glory and splendor. You wrap [the world] in light as with a garment — Based on the opening phrase of this psalm,398*399*400*401*402*

In particular, the vitality within our souls is of a twofold nature. There is a chayos klali, a general, all-inclusive vitality, which gives life to the body as a whole; i.e., no distinction is made between the individual limbs and organs. A person feels alive and the collective identity of his "I" resonates throughout his body as a whole.

Afterwards, there is a chayos perati, an individual vitality that enclothes itself in every particular limb and organ, enabling it to function in a distinctive and unique manner. This level of vitality is tailored to fit the structure and function of the particular limb or organ. Consequently, there is a difference between the particular vitality enclothed in each particular limb and organ.

A parallel exists regarding the Divine vitality that gives life to our world. There is one aspect of that vitality that radiates within all the realms equally. From the standpoint of this level of G-dliness, there is no difference between one level and another. The highest spiritual realms and our lowly physical world are all equal before this level of G-dly light. In kabbalisticterminology, this light is referred to as being sovev kol almin, light that encompasses all worlds.

There is a second dimension of G-dliness that enclothes itself in every created being individually, providing it with its particular nature and qualities. Since every created being is different, the light that enclothes itself within them also varies according to the individual nature of the particular created being. This light is referred to as being memale kol almin, light that fills all the worlds.

After the opening phrase that, as stated above, establishes the parallel between the soul and G-d's creative light, the psalm alludes to both these dimensions by stating, "You have donned glory and splendor," referring to the light that enclothes itself in the worlds, and "You wrap [the world] in light," referring to the light that encompasses the worlds. Following that introduction, the psalm proceeds to describe the particular dimensions of G-d's greatness that are manifest in the Creation (Tanya; Likkutei Torah; Toras Shmuel; Igros Kodesh Admur HaRayatz; Likkutei Sichos).cxcv*
Siddur: Song of the Day - ləđavïđ h׳ ori
shyr shl yvm - Ledavid Hashem Ori
ləđavïđ, Adonai ori vyïshəi mïmmi ira,
By David. God is my light and my deliverance; whom shall I fear?
Adonai maoz cheeiei mïmmi ëfəchađ:
God is the strength of my life, whom shall I dread?

When evildoers approached me to consume my flesh, my tormentors and my enemies, it is they who stumbled and fell.

If an armed camp would besiege me, my heart would not fear; if a war would arise against me, I trust in this.

Put your hope in God; be strong, let your heart take courage, and put your hope in God.465*
ləđavïđ

G-d is my light and my salvation — This verse alludes to the Thirteen Attributes of Mercy that are drawn down in the month of Elul. The first of these Thirteen Attributes is associated with G-d's name Keil, which — as reflected in the verse:415*Keil, Havayah, shines light to us” — is identified with the revelation of Divine light.

The intentof this light is to illuminate darkness. Thus it is written:416*Yahel Or).ccii*

Elsewhere, it is explained: "G-d is my light" on Rosh HaShanah, "my salvation," on Yom Kippur. Implied is that on Rosh HaShanah, a ray from the level of Chochmah (which is identified with Divine light)417*418*Atik Yomin, a spiritual rung far above any connection to material existence (Yahel Or).cciii*

Saying "G-d is my light," relates how G-dliness illumines one's life, enabling him to distinguish the path of light and goodness. Nevertheless, there are obstacles on that path, including internal obstacles like the yetzer hara, "the evil inclination." To enable man to overcome those obstacles, G-d serves as "my salvation."

Our Divine service must involve continued progress, "going from strength to strength," proceeding from one level of good to an even higher level. To encourage one to undertake such efforts, G-d serves as "the strength of my life," generating new energy. This enables the cycle of "my light," "my salvation," and "the strength of my life" to repeat itself on ever-increasing levels of goodness (the Rebbe's Igros Kodesh).cciv*

"G-d is my light" refers to light that is drawn down in an internalized manner, enabling it to be revealed within one's soul. "My salvation" refers to an encompassing light that is too high to be internalized. Nevertheless, even the encompassing light must have a k'li, "vessel," in order for it to remain on the material plane. Otherwise, it will ascend upward, like a fire without a wick.

What is the vessel that enables G-d's light to remain on this physical plane? Torah study. On this basis, we can understand the background behind the connection between Elul and Torah study hinted at in the verse:419*hrvh vshvshnym, "who pastures among the roses," concerning which our Sages420*shvshnym, read shshvnym, 'who review,' i.e., the verse refers to Torah scholars who review Jewish Law." For the study of the Torah is the medium that draws the Thirteen Attributes of Mercy revealed in Elul into expression in this world.421*Likkutei Torah;ccv*Toras Shmuel;ccvi* the series of maamarim entitled BeShaah SheHikidimu, 5672ccvii*

On this phrase, our Sages state: "'My light' at the sea and 'my salvation' at the sea," i.e., at the Splitting of the Sea, there was a revelation of G-dliness that transcended the natural order. In subsequent eras, this transcendent quality is revealed through the Torah and its mitzvos. This is alluded to by the fact that the words vry vyshy, "my light and my salvation," are numerically equivalent to 613. The implication is that both the internal lights and the encompassing lights are drawn down through the 613 mitzvos. For some mitzvos draw down internal lights and other mitzvos draw down encompassing lights (Toras Shmuel).ccviii*

Simply put, the intent of the verse is that a person should know that since G-d is the Master of the entire world and everything depends on Him, He is "my light and my salvation." Hence, as the psalm continues, “whom shall I fear?” (the Rebbe's Igros Kodesh).ccix*

Siddur: Shacharit For Weekdays - qäueh ël h׳
shchryt lchvl - Kavei El Hashem
qäueh ël Adonai, chäzäq vyäämets lïbëcha, vəqäueh ël Adonai׃
Put your hope in God; be strong, let your heart take courage, and put your hope in God.
ein qađosh keiya, ki ein bïlətëcha, vəein tsur keloheinu׃
There is no one holy like God, for there is nothing aside from You; there is no rock like our God.
ki mi ëloäh mïbäləäđei Adonai, umi tsur zulati ëloheinu׃
For who is Divine other than God, and who is a Rock other than our God?
ein qađosh keiya

There is no one holy like G-d – The Zohar1007* states: “There are many who are holy… but none are holy like G-d.” In Jewish thought, kadosh, “holy,” implies “separate,” removed, because of its elevated spiritual nature.

The name of G-d used in this verse is Havayah. The name Havayah relates to the word mehaveh,1008* “to bring into being,” and is thus identified as the active force within G-d’s light that brings all existence into being, vitalizes it, and maintains it at all times. Nevertheless, even as G-d (Havayah) brings the world into being and maintains it, He remains holy – separate and removed from creation. For G-d does not maintain the world in the same manner that the soul gives life to the body. The soul is affected by the events that occur to the body. G-d, by contrast, remains totally unchanged and unaffected by the creation.

To explain: Within the Spiritual Cosmos, there are numerous levels that are holy. Nevertheless, their holiness is relative. Why is one level higher and holier than another? Because it is above the lower level and removed from it; it does not express itself within the lower level at all. And if, by contrast, it does express itself within the lower level, it is not removed from it and therefore is not “holy” in comparison to it. The uniqueness of G-d’s name Havayah is that even as it brings the worlds into existence and maintains them, the name Havayah remains holy and above them. As the Zohar states:1009* “He takes hold of all the worlds and none takes hold of Him.” This refers to the G-dly light that is sovev kol almin, “encompassing all the worlds” (Likkutei Torah; Toras Shmuel).dccxii*

When one entity conveys energy to another following the pattern of ilah v’alul (“cause and effect”), the higher potential (the ilah) enclothes itself in the lower one (the alul) and is affected by it. G-d’s manner of bringing existence into being is unique in that even though the Divine vitality is present within the creation – and indeed must be so to continually bring it into being – the Divine life-force remains removed and holy (Derech Mitzvosecha).dccxiii*

Even as G-d’s light enclothes itself in the keilim (vessels) to give vitality to them and to the worlds that derive from them, G-d’s light remains removed and holy (the series of maamarim entitled BeShaah SheHikidimu, 5672).dccxiv*

The maamar from Likkutei Torah cited above explains G-d’s holiness as referring to His light that is sovev kol almin (the light that transcends the worlds) In the series of maamarim entitled BeShaah SheHikidimu, 5672, the Rebbe Rashab develops a further insight: that this statement can also be made about the light that is memale kol almin (the light that is enclothed in the worlds). Even this lower level of Divine light does not resemble the soul which enclothes itself in the body. Instead, even as it is enclothed in the worlds, it remains holy. The fact that it is enclothed in the keilim only has an effect on the manner in which the light is projected outside the keilim. Regarding the light itself, it remains holy even as it is enclothed within the keilim (Sefer HaMaamarim Melukat).dccxv*
Siddur: Shacharit For Weekdays - ein keloqeinu
shchryt lchvl - Ein Kelokeinu
ein keloheinu, ein käđoneinu, ein kəmäləkenu, ein kəmoshienu׃
There is none like our God; there is none like our Lord; there is none like our King; there is none like our Deliverer.
mi cheloheinu, mi chäđoneinu, mi chəmäləkenu, mi chəmoshienu׃
Who is like our God? Who is like our Lord? Who is like our King? Who is like our Deliverer?
nođëh leloheinu, nođëh läđoneinu, nođëh ləmäləkenu, nođëh ləmoshienu׃
Let us thankfully acknowledge our God; let us thankfully acknowledge our Lord; let us thankfully acknowledge our King; let us thankfully acknowledge our Deliverer.
baruch ëloheinu, baruch äđoneinu, baruch mäləkenu, baruch moshienu׃
Blessed is our God; blessed is our Lord; blessed is our King; blessed is our Deliverer.
ätah hu ëloheinu, ätah hu äđoneinu, ätah hu mäləkenu, ätah hu moshienu, ätah toshienu׃
You are our God; You are our Lord; You are our King; You are our Deliverer; You will deliver us.
ätah taqum tərächem tsion ki et ləchënənah ki va moeđ׃
You will arise and show mercy to Zion, for it is time to be gracious to her; the appointed time has come.
ätah hu Adonai ëloheinu velohei ävoteinu, shëhïqətiru ävoteinu ləfaneicha ët qətorët hässämmim׃
You are God, our Lord, and the Lord of our fathers before Whom our fathers burned the incense offering.
ein keloheinu

There is none like our G-d… Who is like our God?... Let us thankfully acknowledge our God… Blessed is our God… You are our God…. – The five bars of this hymn proceed in ascending order. “There is none like our G-d” reflects the world of Asiyah. In that realm, it is impossible to err and think that some entities resemble the Divine, for in the lowly world of Asiyah there is indeed none like G-d. “Who is like our G-d?” reflects the world of Yetzirah. Regarding Yetzirah, an error can be made because there are exalted spiritual beings like Metatron who bear a resemblance to the Divine.1012* Nevertheless, by stating “Who is like our G-d?” we indicate that we will not confuse any other entity – no matter how lofty – with G-d. “We will thankfully acknowledge our G-d” refers to the world of Beriah where there is also no possibility of error, for in that realm, G-dliness can already be appreciated and the difference between G-d and His celestial beings is obvious. “Blessed is our G-d,” and “You are our G-d,” reflect the world of Atzilus where not only is there no possibility of error, but one actually approaches G-d and speaks to Him directly (Kesser Shem Tov).dccxvii*
Siddur: Shacharit For Weekdays - pïttum häqqətorët
shchryt lchvl - Pitum Haketoret
pïttum häqqətorët, hätstsari, vəhätstsïporën, hächëləbənah, vəhälləvonah, mïshəqäl shïvəim shïvəim manëh,
As compounded, the incense offering [comprised 11 types of fragrant spices]: 1) stacte; 2) onycha; 3) galbanum; 4) frankincense, each component weighing 70 maneh;
mor ,uqətsiah, shïbolët nerəd, vəchärəkom, mïshəqäl shïshshoh asor shïshshoh asor monëh,
5) musk; 6) cassia; 7) spikenard; 8) saffron, each component weighing 16 maneh;
häqqoshət shəneim asar, qïllufah shəloshah, qïnnamon tïshəah.
9) costus; 12 maneh; 10) aromatic bark, three [maneh]; and 11) cinnamon, nine [maneh].
borit kärəshinah tïshəah qäbin, yein qäfərisin səin təlata vəqäbin təlata, vəïm ein lo yein qäfərisin mevi chämär chïuäryan ätiq.
[The following were also included:] Carshina lye, nine kabin; and wine from Cyprus, three se’ah and three kabin. If there was no wine from Cyprus, they would use aged white wine.
mëläch səđomit rovä, määlëh ashan kal shëhu.
[Also included were] a quarter [of a kab] of salt from Sodom, and a minute amount of a smoke-raising herb.
räbi natan häbävəli omer׃
Rabbi Nassan, the Babylonian says:

A minute amount of Jordanian amber [was also added]. If honey was added, [the offering] became disqualified.
vəïm chïssär ëchađ mïkal sämməmaneiha cheeiav mitah׃
If one omitted any of its spices, he was liable to the death penalty.
räban shïməon bën gäməliel omer׃
Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:
hätstsari eino ëlla səraf hännotef meätsei häqqətaf,
Stacte is simply the sap that drips from the balsam tree.
borit kärəshinah shëshshofin boh ët hätstsïporën, kəđei shëtəhe naah;
Carshina lye [was used] to rub on the onycha to improve its appearance.
yein qäfərisin shëshshorin bo ët hätstsïporën, kəđei shëtəhe äzzah.
Wine from Cyprus served for steeping the onycha, to intensify its fragrance.
vähälo mei räǥəleiïm yafin lah, ëlla shëein mächənisin mei räǥəleiïm bämmïqədash mïpənei häkavođ׃
Although the water of Raglayim could have served that purpose, the water of Raglayim is not brought into the Temple out of respect.
pïttum häqqətorët

As compounded, the incense offering – The root letters of the word qtrt form the Aramaic termqtr, which has the same meaning as the Hebrew word qshr, “bond.”1013* The incense offering establishes a bond between G-d’s infinite dimensions and the Spiritual Cosmos (Maggid Devarav LeYaakov; Likkutei Torah).dccxviii*

The incense offering was comprised of eleven spices. The number eleven is associated with the forces of kelipah, unholiness To explain: Holiness is structured in sequences of ten. Thus there are ten sparks of holiness, paralleling the ten Sefiros. In the realm of Asiyah, these sparks are swallowed up by kelipah and are in a state of exile within it.

The eleventh spice, frankincense, refers to a dimension of holiness that cannot be contained within kelipah but instead shines over it as an encompassing light, providing vitality for the entire realm of kelipah. Since this G-dly influence shines only in an encompassing manner, the realm of kelipah is insensitive to its G-dly source and instead, lifts itself up proudly, as if it were a self-sustaining entity. Thus the kabbalists speak of eleven crowns of impurity (Torah Or).dccxix*

In Moreh Nevuchim,1014* Rambam explains the motivating rationale for the incense offering: the offering of sacrifices in the Temple caused an unpleasant smell, and the pleasant fragrance of the incense offering caused the entire Beis HaMikdash complex to be aromatic.

Rambam was not only speaking in a simple physical sense. Instead, his intent was spiritual as well: the incense offering removed the spiritual stench and filth caused by the yetzer hara (the evil inclination).1015* Moreover, as will be explained, not only does it push away the unpleasant influences, it transforms them (Likkutei Sichos).dccxx*

In contrast to the sacrifices which involved the offering of entities that could be eaten as food, the incense offering involved entities that were flavorless and lacked nutritional value. Instead, burning them generated – to borrow a phrase1016* – “a pleasant fragrance unto G-d.” This pleasant fragrance causes Divine influence to flow downward.

These concepts are interrelated. Transforming the negative dimensions of kelipah to good arouses a pleasant fragrance Above. Just as fragrance “restores the soul,” so too, the fragrance of the incense offering generates influence from G-d’s Essence. This influence flows toward the worlds, binding them in unity with Him. As a result, “judgments are sweetened in their very source”1017* and favorable outcomes are brought about on this earthly plane as well. Indeed, the incense offering is so potent that it can cause a plague to cease”1018* (Torah Or; Likkutei Torah; Imrei Binah).dccxxi*

To explain the contrast between the sacrifices and the incense offering in greater depth: by and large, the sacrificial offerings involved burning fat and blood – symbolic of our quality of pleasure, and our vitality – on the altar. This reflected the elevation of the emotional attributes of kelipas nogah and their inclusion in the fire of holiness. Therefore they are called “food for My fire.”1019* The spiritual parallel of the sacrifices is the service of prayer. Here, too, the analogy of food is appropriate, for just as the ingestion of physical food provides a person with energy, so too, the service of prayer nourishes our connection with G-d.

The incense offering, by contrast, involves the refinement of the encompassing lights that transcend the realm of intellect. The forces of kelipah have the potential to derive nurture from these lights, but through the ketores offering, those energies are instead drawn down into the realm of holiness.

On this basis, we can comprehend the advantage of the incense offering over the other sacrifices and why the incense offering can elevate the eleven crowns of impurity and the eleven “curses”1020* associated with kelipah. The fragrance generated by incense is of a different type than the fragrance generated by foods. The fragrance generated by foods, like the foods themselves, invigorates the body. The fragrance generated by incense, by contrast, invigorates the soul.1021* The rationale is that the spiritual energy vested in fragrance comes from a higher source than that vested in food. Therefore it can fall lower and be associated with the power of kelipah. Ultimately, however, through the ketores offering, these energies can be elevated and their potent energy directed to holiness (Shaarei Orah).dccxxii*

Another analogy is used to illustrate the difference between the sacrifices and the incense offering: the difference between food and medications. Food endows the body with positive energy, but it is of a limited nature and dependent on the quantity ingested. Medicines, by contrast, are far more powerful; even a very small quantity can have a significantly beneficial effect on the body. This is possible, because they come from a higher source (Maamarei Admor HaZakein).dccxxiii*

The incense offering is brought on the inner altar in contrast to the sacrifices that are brought on the outer altar. The two altars correspond to two different levels of love for G-d. The external dimension of the heart follows the intellect. When a person contemplates that G-d is his life-force, he will be motivated to love Him. Just as animal sacrifices were offered on the outer altar, this type of love can affect the animal soul and motivate it to love G-d. The inner dimension of the heart emanates from the person’s deep inner potential that transcends the realm of intellect, and is characterized by a love that knows no limits. This relates to the incense offering brought on the inner altar1022* (Toras Shmuel).dccxxiv*
Siddur: Shacharit For Weekdays - tana đəvei eliahu
shchryt lchvl - Tana Devei Eliyahu
tana đəvei eliahu, kal häshshonëh hälochot bəchol yom müvətäch lo shëhu bën olam häba,
It was taught in the School of Elijah: Whoever studies Torah laws every day is assured of life in the World to Come,
shënnëëmär׃ hälichot olam lo, äl tïqərei hälichot ëlla hälachot׃
for it is said: “The ways (halichos) of the world are his.” Do not read halichos (“ways”), but rather halachos (Torah laws).
tana đəvei eliahu

Whoever studies Torah laws daily is assured of life in the World to Come – “Assured of life in the World to Come” serves as a broad translation of the phrase vn h״v (ben Olam HaBa). Translated literally, ben Olam HaBa means “a son of the World to Come.” The World to Come refers here to the era of the Resurrection1045* when G-d’s transcendent light will be revealed on this material plane. Through Torah study, a person is “born” from – and thus becomes “a son of” – “the World to Come,” i.e., he is a product of this transcendent G-dly light. In the present era, the inherent limitations of the Spiritual Cosmos prevent this light from being revealed on the material plane. In the World to Come, this will change and this transcendent light will be manifest on the earthly plane as well (Likkutei Torah).dccxxxi*

The Torah – particularly Torah Law – is identified with G-d’s essential light, for He invested His Essence into the Torah. Through its study, a person draws that essential light into this material world leading ultimately to that light being manifest in a revealed manner. The revelation of that essential light is what will characterize and define the World to Come. Since Torah study brings about this revelation, one who studies it is assured that he will partake in its revelation1046* (Toras Shmuel).dccxxxii*

This statement of our Sages uses the expression ben Olam HaBa literally, “a son of the World to Come” in contrast to the frequently used expression, yesh lo chelek b’Olam HaBa, literally, “he has a portion in the World to Come.” A “portion” implies that he receives a limited dimension (according to our Rabbis, a fourth).1047* “A son,” by contrast, is an heir who receives everything, carrying on and continuing the legacy – material and also spiritual – of the testator. Through the study of the Torah, one receives and internalizes G-d’s essential light. The revelation of that essential light will characterize the World to Come. Hence through such study, one does not receive a mere portion of the World to Come, but becomes a ben Olam HaBa – he inherits everything (Yahel Or).dccxxxiii*

The connection of the study of Torah Law to the World to Come can also be explained as follows: Torah Law is derived by sifting through and clarifying Torah teachings until one arrives at a definitive ruling. Similarly, the World to Come reflects existence as it has been refined and purified (Maamarei Admor HaZakein; Toras Chayim).dccxxxiv*
Siddur: Shacharit For Weekdays - amär räbi ëləazar
shchryt lchvl - Amar Rabbi Elazar
amär räbi ëləazar amär räbi chänina׃ täləmiđei chächamim märəbim shalom baolam, shënnëëmär׃
Rabbi Elazar said in the name of Rabbi Chaninah: Torah scholars increase peace in the world, as it is said:
vəchal baneiïch lïmmuđei Adonai, vəräv shəlom banaiïch׃
“And all your children will be students of God, and your children will [enjoy] abundant peace.”
äl tïqərei banaiïch, ëlla bonaiïch׃
Do not read banayich (“your children”), but bonayich (“your builders”).
shalom rav ləohävei toratëcha, vəein lamo mïchəshol׃
Those who love Your Torah will enjoy abundant peace and there will be no obstacles for them.
yəhi shalom bəcheilech, shäləvah bəärəmənotaiïch׃
May there be peace within your ramparts, tranquility within your palaces.
ləmään ächei vəreai, äđäbərah na shalom bach׃
For the sake of my brethren and friends, I will ask for peace within you.
ləmään beit Adonai ëloheinu, äväqəshah tov lach׃
For the sake of the House of God our Lord, I will seek your well-being.
Adonai oz ləämmo yïten, Adonai yəvarech ët ämmo väshsholom׃
God will give strength to His people; God will bless His people with peace.
amär räbi ëləazar amär räbi chänina׃ täləmiđei chächamim märəbim shalom baolam, shënnëëmär

Torah sages increase peace in the world…. Do not read banayich (“your children”), but bonayich (“your builders”). – Our Sages1061* state that Torah study is considered “building the world.” Maharsha1062* connects that statement with the Midrash1063* that the world was created through Torah. Just as an architect builds using blueprints, the Torah provided the design through which G-d created the world.

Creation completed only the physical dimension of the world’s existence, since physicality remained separate from its spiritual source. The separation between these two dimensions was so acute that our Sages1064* speak of a Divine decree separating the physical from the spiritual. Accordingly, they describe1065* the world as “trembling” until the Giving of the Torah, at which time – due to the fusion of the physical with the spiritual as a result of the Giving of the Torah – it became tranquil. In this way, the Torah creates peace. Just as peace comes from the fusion of opposites, the Torah fuses together opposites – the physical and the spiritual.

All the above describes not only the spiritual dynamic of the revelation of the Torah from Above, but also the outcome of man’s Torah study. As the Zohar states:1066* “The Holy One, blessed be He, looked into the Torah and created the world. Man looks into the Torah and maintains the world (Toras Shmuel; Maamarei Admor HaRayatz; Toras Menachem).dccxliv*

The letters of the Torah are referred to as the “stones” that build “the city of our L-rd,” transforming the world into a dwelling for G-d. Thus the scholars who produce these building blocks are referred to by our Sages1067* as “builders.”

The connection between Torah study and the transformation of the world into a dwelling for G-d is further highlighted by our Sages’ statement1068* that from the time of the destruction of the Beis HaMikdash, “the Holy One, blessed be He, has nothing in this world but the four cubits of Torah Law.” Implied is that Torah Law creates a dwelling for G-d parallel to the Beis HaMikdash (Or HaTorah; Toras Shmuel).dccxlv*

Not only will Torah scholars be themselves granted peace, they will bring about peace in the world, as Rambam writes:1069* “The entire Torah was given to bring about peace in the world, as it is written:1070* ‘Its ways are pleasant ways and all its paths are peace.’” Even in this material world, which contains many influences that appear to run contrary to the Torah, the Torah is able to bring about peace.

This relates to the previous teaching that speaks of “the paths of the world.” Torah Law provides instruction as to how to conduct oneself in the world and, in that way, creates “paths for G-d” in the world, enabling the world to be transformed into a dwelling for Him (Toras Menachem).dccxlvi*
Siddur: Shacharit For Weekdays - aleinu
shchryt lchvl - Aleinu
aleinu ləshäbeäch lääđon häkol, latet gəđüllah lyotser bəreshit,
It is our obligation to praise the Master of everything, to ascribe greatness to the Primal Creator
shëllo asanu kəǥoiei haäratsot, vəlo samanu kəmïshəpəchot haäđamah,
for not making us like the nations of the world, nor causing us to be like the families of the earth,
shëllo sam chëləqenu kahëm, vəǥoralenu kəchal hämonam
for He has not endowed us with a portion like theirs, nor [made] our lot like that of their multitudes.
shëhem mïshətächävim ləhëvël vəlariq.
For they prostrate themselves before vanity and nothingness.
väänächənu korəim umïshətächävim umođim lïfənei mëlëch mäləchei hämməlachim, häqqađosh baruch hu.
But we bend the knee, prostrate ourselves, and give thanks before the King of kings, the Holy One, blessed be He.
shëhu notëh shameiïm vyoseđ arëts, umoshäv yəqaro bäshshomeiïm mïmmääl, ushəchinät üzzo bəǥovəhei məromim.
For He extends the heavens and establishes the earth; the seat of His glory is in the heavens above and the abode of His strength is in the loftiest heights.
hu ëloheinu ein ođ, ëmët mäləkenu, ëfës zulato, käkatuv bətorato׃
He is our God, there is no one else. Our King is true; aside from Him, there is nothing. As it is written in His Torah:
vyađäəta heeiom vähäshevota ël ləvavëcha, ki Adonai hu haëlohim,
“Know this day and take unto your heart that God is the Lord;
bäshshomeiïm mïmmääl vəäl haarëts mïtachät, ein ođ׃
in the heavens above and upon the earth below, there is nothing else.”
vəäl ken nəqäuëh ləcha Adonai ëloheinu, lïrəot məherah bətïfəërët üzzëcha,
We therefore put our hope in You, God, our Lord, that we may speedily behold the splendor of Your might,
ləhäävir gïllulim mïn haarëts, vəhaëlilim karot yïkaretun, lətäqqen olam bəmäləchut shädei,
that You] remove idols from the earth, [so that] the false deities will be utterly cut off, to perfect the world under the sovereignty of the Almighty.
vəchal bənei vasar yïqərəu vïshəmëcha, ləhäfənot eleicha kal rïshəei arëts.
All flesh will invoke Your name, causing all the wicked of the earth to turn to You.
yäkiru vyeđəu kal yoshəvei tevel, ki ləcha tïchərä kal bërëch, tïshshovä kol lashon.
All the inhabitants of the earth will recognize and know that every knee should bend to You, [that] every tongue should swear [by Your name].
ləfaneicha Adonai ëloheinu yïchərəu vyïpolu, vəlïchəvođ shïməcha yəqar yïtenu.
Before You, God, our Lord, they will kneel and prostrate themselves and give honor to the glory of Your name.
viqäbəlu chüllam äleihëm ët ol mäləchutëcha, vətïməloch äleihëm məherah ləolam vaëđ.
They will all accept upon themselves the yoke of Your kingdom. May You speedily reign over them forever and ever.
ki hämmäləchut shëlləcha hi, uləoləmei äđ tïməloch bəchavođ,
For sovereignty is Yours and to all eternity You will reign in glory,
käkatuv bətoratëcha׃ Adonai yïməloch ləolam vaëđ׃
as it is written in Your Torah: “God will reign forever and ever.”
vənëëmär׃ vəhaiah Adonai ləmëlëch äl kal haarëts, beeiom hähu yïhyëh Adonai ëchađ ushəmo ëchađ׃
And it is said: “God shall be King over the entire earth. On that day, God will be one, and His name, one.”
aleinu ləshäbeäch

It is our obligation to praise – This phrase is not merely a statement of responsibility, it is also an expression of thanksgiving. We are happy that we have been given the privilege and responsibility of praising G-d (Or HaTorah).dcclvii*

This phrase also points to the purpose of our Divine service – to draw down the glory of G-d’s kingship through our praise, as the concluding words of the phrase say: “to convey greatness upon the Creator…”

According to tradition,1083* the passage Aleinu was authored by Yehoshua bin Nun. This is alluded to by the fact that the words lynv lshvch are numerically equivalent to the term shvr, “ox.” Rashi identifies Yehoshua with an ox in his commentary to the verse:1084* “The sovereignty of an ox and its glory is granted to him.”

The word tvl, “worm,” shares the same numerical equivalent as shvr, “ox.” In Yechezkel’s vision of the Divine chariot, the ox is identified with the left vector1085* which is associated with the contraction and the concealment of Divine light. The lowliness of a worm reflects the quality of bittul. The bittul associated with the lowly worm enables the undesirable influences associated with the left vector to be corrected.

Our Sages1086* state that a worm kills a cedar with its mouth. In a metaphorical sense, the implication is that the bittul of a worm can conquer the towering height of a proud cedar. More particularly, the worm’s power is said to be in its mouth; i.e., the words of G-d’s praise that we recite with bittul (Or HaTorah).dcclviii*
Siddur: Shacharit For Weekdays - äl tira
shchryt lchvl - Al Tira
äl tira mïpächäđ pïtəom, umïshshoät rəshaim ki tavo׃
Do not fear sudden terror, nor the ravaging disaster of the wicked should it come.
ütsu etsah vətüfar, däbəru đavar vəlo yaqum, ki ïmmanu el׃
They contrive a scheme, but it will be foiled; they talk of a plot, but it will not materialize, because God is with us.
vəäđ zïqənah äni hu, vəäđ seivah äni ësəbol;
Until [your] old age, I am [with you], and until [your] hoary years, I will sustain [you].
äni asiti vääni ëshsa vääni ësəbol väämället׃
I made [you], and I will carry [you], I will bear [you] and deliver [you].
äl tira mïpächäđ pïtəom

Do not fear sudden terror… They contrive a scheme… Until old age… – The linkage of these three verses is found in the Midrash,1119* which relates that after Haman publicized the decree to annihilate the Jewish people, Haman and his entire entourage went to observe Mordechai’s reaction. At that time, Mordechai saw three children coming out of school. He approached them and asked them to repeat the verses they were studying. The first said: Al tirah…, “Do not fear…”; the second said, utzu etza…, “They contrive a scheme…”; and the third said, v’ad ziknah…, “Until old age….” When Mordechai heard these verses, he considered them as messages of assurance from Above1120* and rejoiced.

The message of these verses is, of course, not confined to that time alone, but applies to all times and in all situations. (And for that reason, it was ordained that these verses be recited after the conclusion of the prayer service1121* as one prepares to go about his day-to-day existence and face any and all challenges that might arise from it.)

The first verse, “Do not fear sudden terror,” speaks about fear from an obvious source of danger. No reason is given for the assurance granted. The second verse, “They contrive a schem…,” speaks about circumstances where the danger has not yet materialized, but is lurking. The Jews are promised that all designs against them will be foiled, because – and this reason is explicitly stated in the verse – “G-d is with us.” The third verse, “Until old age,” does not address a situation of danger. Instead, it speaks about weathering the changes a person faces as he proceeds through the course of his life. He is told that he can approach those changes with confidence, because G-d “has made [him] and will carry [him].”

Thus the verses represent three stages in a Jew’s faith and trust in G-d. “Do not fear sudden terror” teaches that even when there is full reason to fear imminent danger and harm, a Jew should be serene, confident in the knowledge that G-d will help him. Moreover, he does not need any explanation for this. It is his natural, inherent reaction. Innately, he trusts G-d and realizes that “Everything the Merciful One does is for the good.”1122* A deeper level of assurance is manifest by a person who understands that “G-d is with him.” He not only trusts and believes, he knows with certainty that all designs against Judaism will ultimately be unsuccessful. An even more encompassing sense of security is possessed by one who appreciates that such trust need not be merely a response to a given situation, but should be an ongoing force directing his life, for he comprehends that nature as a whole is controlled by G-d, and He is the Master of all the changes and challenges a person confronts.

As mentioned, Mordechai was told these verses by young children. The implication is that they are reflections of the simple faith that lies at the core of every Jewish soul. A child’s natural sensitivity to spirituality enables him to instinctively appreciate these truths.1123* Seeing the children’s trust can arouse their elders to align themselves with this core faith and understanding (Likkutei Sichos). Vol. 21, p. 206ff.).
Siddur: Shacharit For Weekdays - äch tsädiqim
shchryt lchvl - Ach Tzadikim
äch tsädiqim yođu lïshəmëcha, yeshəvu yəsharim ët paneicha׃
Indeed, the righteous will thankfully acknowledge Your name; the upright will dwell in Your presence.
äch tsädiqim yođu lïshəmëcha, yeshəvu yəsharim ët paneicha

Indeed, the righteous will thankfully acknowledge Your name; the upright will dwell in Your Presence – Our Sages cite1124* this verse as a prooftext teaching that after prayer – alluded to by the phrase, “the righteous will thankfully acknowledge Your name” – one should linger in the synagogue, “abiding in Your presence.” Implied is that the person should possess the serenity and security to continue his state of meditative contemplation, internalizing the lessons of prayer.

This verse also serves as a promise that “the upright will abide” in security and tranquility. This state will enable “the righteous” – which refers to the entire Jewish people, because “Your nations are all righteous”1125* – to “thankfully acknowledge Your name” in a more complete fashion; i.e., they will be able to devote their energies to prayer without any distracting or disturbing thoughts or worries.

As a result of such prayer, the security and tranquility of the upright will be increased. For such prayer hastens the coming of the complete and Ultimate Redemption, when the Jewish people will once again “abide in Your presence,” in the Third Beis HaMikdash1126* (Likkutei Sichos, Vol. 25, p. 373ff.).

As mentioned previously, hodaah,1127* the thankful acknowledgment of G-d’s bringing our existence into being, lies at the very foundation of our relationship with Him. Therefore, such acknowledgment is made as soon as we awake, with our pronouncement Modeh Ani, and at the beginning of our prayers with the statement Hodu L’Adonai.

Hodaah implies accepting a truth even though one does not fully comprehend it intellectually. Because his soul is “an actual part of G-d,”1128* a person is willing to go beyond his own understanding and acknowledge and accept G-d’s truth. The ultimate intent, however, is not that this acknowledgment run contrary to our conceptual processes, but that it filter through them and elevate them. Therefore, after that initial acceptance is made, effort should be made to elevate one’s thought and align it with this fundamental acknowledgment. This is accomplished through meditation and contemplation in prayer.

The different stages of acknowledgment in prayer thus represent the integration of our essential spiritual awareness into our conceptual processes. Our minds become attuned to truths that transcend the intellect. The consummate stage in this process is the acknowledgment made with the recitation of this verse. yshvv, translated as “abide,” relates to the term htyyshvvt, hisyashvus, which implies a settled and composed approach. The intent is that the fundamental acceptance of G-d’s truth expressed through hodaah has become entirely integrated and settled within one’s intellectual processes (Likkutei Sichos).dcclxxxviii*

which He swore to your fathers to give to you, a land flowing with milk and honey, you shall perform this service in this month.

bəchozëq yađ hotsianu yəhovah mïmmïtsəreiïm mïbeit ävađim:
‘With a mighty arm, God brought us out of Egypt, from the House of Bondage.
veiəhi ki hïqəshah färəoh ləshälləchenu. veeiähäroǥ yəhovah kal bəchor bəërëts mïtsəreiïm. mïbəchor ađam vəäđ bəchor bəhemah.
And when Pharaoh stubbornly refused to release us, God slew every firstborn in the land of Egypt, the firstborn of both man and beast.
äl ken äni zoveäch leihovah kal pëtër rëchëm häzzəcharim vəchal bəchor banei ëfədëh:
Therefore, I offer to God every male that first opens the womb, and all the firstborn of my sons I redeem.’
vəhaiah ləot äl yođəchah ulətotafot bein eineicha. ki bəchozëq yađ hotsianu yəhovah mïmmïtsəraiïm:
“And this shall be a sign on your arm and an ornament between your eyes, for God brought us out of Egypt with a strong arm.”478*
shəmä yïsərael

In the halachic tradition, there are four different patterns suggested by the Rabbis regarding the order in which the passages of the head tefillin are placed: that of: a) Rashi, b) Rabbeinu Tam, c) Shimusha Rabba and d) Raavad. Although the halachah follows the opinion of Rashi, the Shulchan Aruch467*tefillin whose passages are ordered according to the opinion of Rabbeinu Tam.

Rabbeinu Yaakov of Corbeil, one of the authors of the Tosafos and author of Shaalos U’Teshuvos Min HaShamayim, was accustomed to having his queries answered through a dream-quest; i.e., he would leave a paper on his desk at night with a questionand in the morning find an answer from Heaven inscribed upon it. With regard to the order of the passages in tefillin, he received the following answer: “Just as there is a dispute in the earthly realm, there is a dispute in the spiritual realm.”

In general, the mystical tradition explains that wearing tefillin is associated with drawing down the sublime intellectual faculties of Chochmah, Binah, and Daas. In particular, tefillin with passages ordered according to each of the authorities mentioned draws down a different level of intellectual influence from Above.

It is explained that the tefillin whose passages follow the order favored by Rashi primarily draw down influence from the Sefirah of Binah, the realm that is the source of understanding and comprehension. These intellectual faculties are most closely associated with the intent of the mitzvah of tefillin: the subjugation of the mind and the heart to the service of G-d.468*

The tefillin of Rabbeinu Tam are primarily associated with drawing down influence from the realm of Chochmah, the level of intellect that leads to self-transcendence. And the tefillin of Shimusha Rabba and Raavad are primarily associated with the source of our intellectual powers in the realm of Kesser.

Since the influences elicited by the tefillin of Rashi are the most essential, wearing such tefillin is an obligation for every Jew. And since those elicited by the tefillin of Rabbeinu Tamare also significant, the directive of the Alter Rebbe — that “every Jew whose heart has been touched by the fear of G-d should put on the tefillin of Rabbeinu Tam”469*tefillin of Shimusha Rabba and Raavad is far less widespread becausetheir subtle spiritual dynamics are attuned only to individuals of a rare degree of both spiritual refinement and bodily purity.

To a lesser extent, the need for the latter qualities also apply to the tefillin of Rabbeinu Tam.For this reason, even in many communities that observe the custom of putting on the tefillin of Rabbeinu Tam, men refrain from doing so until marriage, or at least until several years after bar-mitzvah. This was also the custom in Chabad-Lubavitch470*until Purim, 5736 (1976), when the Rebbe said:

Not only according to the Kabbalah, but also based on the final rulings of the halachic authorities, one should put on the tefillin of Rabbeinu Tam after the morning prayers. This is not merely a custom, but an obligation.... Nevertheless, so that one should not falter in his observance, he should own tefillin of Rabbeinu Tam or be able to easily borrow them so that he can put them on every day that tefillin are worn.

This is relevant to every Jewish man and to the Jewish people as a whole. This directive should be made public.

At that time, he emphasized that this also included boys from the age of bar-mitzvah and indeed, even before the age of bar-mitzvah, in preparation for the fulfillment of the mitzvah.471*In explanation of the reason for the change, he explained that the AriZal stated that in the time of ikvesa deMeshicha, because of the spiritual darkness of the era, wearing Rabbeinu Tam tefillin has become an obligation for everyone. That is certainly true in the present age, when everyone is more exposed to secular knowledge due to various media and a far greater degree of information than in previous years. In such a climate, it is necessary to draw down the influence of sublime Chochmah which leads to bittul and self-transcendence by wearing Rabbeinu Tam tefillin (Likkutei Sichos; Toras Menachem;ccxxxv* Sichos Purim 5736).
Siddur: The Six Rememberances - ləmä́än tïzəkor
shsh zchyrvt - Lemaan Tizkor
ləmä́än tïzəkor ët yom tsetəcha meë́rëts mïtsəréiïm kol yəmei cheeiéicha:
[The Exodus from Egypt:] “…so that you will remember the day of your exodus from the land of Egypt all the days of your life.”485*
ləmä́än tïzəkor ët yom tsetəcha meë́rëts

The Hebrew term for Egypt, Mitzrayim, relates to the term meitzarim, meaning "boundaries" or "limitations." In our own Divine service, going out of Egypt refers to rising above the limitations of our bodies and animal souls,479*480*481*

Constantly remembering and reliving the Exodus in our personal experience is mandated by our Sages in their statement:482*483*484*
Siddur: The Six Rememberances - räq hïshshámër ləcha
shsh zchyrvt - Rak Hishomer Lecha
räq hïshshámër ləcha ushəmor näfəshəcha məođ.
[The Giving of the Torah:] “Only take care and guard your soul scrupulously,
pën tïshəkäch ët hädəvarim äshër rau einéicha.
lest you forget the things that your eyes saw,
ufën yaśuru mïlləvovəcha kol yəmei cheeiéicha.
and lest they depart from your heart all the days of your life.
vəhođäətam ləvanéicha vəlïvənei vanéicha:
Make known to your children and children’s children
yom äshër amä́đəta lïfənei yəhovah ëlohéicha bəchorev:
[the events of] the day on which you stood before God your Lord at Chorev.”489*
yom äshër amä́đəta lïfənei yəhovah ëlohéicha

Just as, in a personal sense, there is an Exodus from Egypt every day, so too, every person should realize that the Torah is given anew daily. For whenever a person studies the Torah, G-d studies opposite him, as it were.486*

Accordingly, the person's emotional reaction to Torah study should also mirror the Sinai experience, as our Sages comment:487*Toras Shmuel; Sefer HaMaamarim Melukat).488*
Siddur: The Six Rememberances - zachor ämaleq
shsh zchyrvt - Zachor Amalek
zachor et äshër asah ləcha ämaleq bädë́rëch bətsetəchëm mïmmïtsəráiïm:
[Amalek’s Attack:] “Remember what Amalek did to you on the way, as you came out of Egypt,
äshër qorəcha bädë́rëch veiəzännev bəcha kal hännëchëshalim ächäréicha. vəätah aief vyaǥéä.
how he encountered you on the way and cut down all the weak who straggled after you, when you were weary and exhausted.
vəlo yare ëlohim: vəhaiah bəhańiäch yəhovah ëlohéicha ləcha mïkal oiəvéicha mïssaviv
[Amalek] did not fear God. [Therefore,] when God grants you respite from all the enemies around you,
baárëts äshër yəhovah ëlohéicha noten ləcha nächälah lərïshətah.
in the land that God is giving you as a heritage to inherit,
tïməchëh ët zë́chër ämaleq mïtä́chät häshshomáiïm. lo tïshəkoch:
erase the memory of Amalek from under the heavens. Do not forget.”496*
zachor et äshër asah ləcha

Though the name Amalek refers to a specific nation in history, it also describes a character trait that may well exist within ourselves. Just as Amalek epitomized the opposite of everything the Jewish people stand for, the trait symbolized by Amalek defies the very foundations of our Divine service.

The Midrash490*491*qrch(“he encountered you”) can also be rendered as “he cooled you off.” Amalek represents icy rationality that causes doubt and hesitation, cooling the ardor of everything we do or experience.492*Amalek (mlq) shares the numerical equivalent493*safek (sfq) meaning “doubt.”494*Likkutei Sichos).495*
Siddur: The Six Rememberances - äl tïshəkäch
shsh zchyrvt - Al Tishkach
zəchor äl tïshəkäch et äshër hïqətsä́fəta et yəhovah ëlohéicha bämïđəbar:
[The Golden Calf:] “Remember, do not forget, that you angered God your Lord in the desert.”499*
zəchor

This remembrance focuses on the worship of the Golden Calf — and other failures of faith — that tested G-d’s patience with the Jewish people. Although, at present, bowing down to statues of false deities is not very common, the theoretical premise that motivated the ancients to serve such deities is still followed by many. Why did the ancients create such gods? To quote Rambam:497*

Thus, in an abstract sense, the worship of false divinities entails attaching importance to the intermediaries through which G-d conveys His influence. Just as in a physical sense, the worship of false divinities involves bowing one’s head, in a more abstract sense, it means bending and even subjugating one’s thinking process to the powers that are perceived as controlling the natural order.

In ancient times, the people’s worship of these intermediaries was expressed by making statues and bowing down to them. In contemporary terms, it is expressed through submission to the forces that one perceives as controlling one’s sustenance, be it one’s employers, the larger system of powers that control commerce and finance, or the myriad intermediate levels in between (Maamarei Admur HaRashab; Sefer Maamarim HaMelukat).498*
Siddur: The Six Rememberances - zachor… ləmïryam
shsh zchyrvt - Zachor… Lemiriam
zachor et äshër asah yəhovah ëlohéicha ləmïryam bädë́rëch bətsetəchëm mïmmïtsəráiïm:
[Punishment for Improper Speech:] “Remember what God your Lord did to Miriam on the way, as you came out of Egypt.”502*
zachor et äshër asah yəhovah ëlohéicha

One might ask: Why is the admonition against speaking lashon hara associated with Miriam? She was a righteous woman. Moreover, in this instance, the words she spoke were not intended to harm Moshe. To quote Rambam:500*"She did not speak derisively of him… and [Moshe] did not object to this at all."

In resolution, it can be explained that generally, there are two negative dimensions of lashon hara: a) that it reflects the undesirable character traits of the speakerand brings these traits to the surface; and b) the fundamental nature of this type of speech, that it plunges the speaker into a downward spiral from which it is difficult for him to extricate himself.

To highlight this second dimension, the Torah associates the admonition against lashon hara with Miriam. In her instance, her speech contained no undesirable character traits or negative intents. Her error consisted merely in speaking improperly, an entirely external quality. As such, she was punished with tzaraas, i.e., her skin, the external dimension of her body, became afflicted. The affliction manifested itself in an obvious manner, demonstrating that there was a problem that had to be corrected, rather than left to fester and grow (Likkutei Sichos).501*
Siddur: The Six Rememberances - zachor ët yom häshshäbot
shsh zchyrvt - Zachor Et Yom Hashabbat
zachor ët yom häshshäbot ləqädəsho:
[Shabbos:] “Remember the Sabbath day to make it holy.”504*
zachor ët yom

The spirit of Shabbos is to be extended and connected to each of the days of the week. Just as Shabbos is a day of spiritual awareness, so too, during each of the week days there is a time when a person rises above his material concerns. This is the time of prayer. This spiritual activity elevates all of the Torah the person studies and the mitzvos he performs throughout the entire day (Likkutei Torah).503*
